nexttext:
\subsubsection{}

We can thus proceed to the next inductive step, and this completes
Definition \ref{def:theory}.



{\oldsection{{Simple variants and basic constructions}}\setcounter{subsection}{-1}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}\setcounter{equation}{-1}}
\label{sec:variant-construction}

{\oldsubsection{{Introduction}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}

In this section, we shall first discuss a planar variant of higher
theories, which iteratevely theorize associative algebra.
In particular, we shall find the structure of a planar ($n-1$)-theory
formed by endomorphisms in a symmetric $n$-theory.
This will lead to a discussion of other theorized structures similarly
residing in a symmetric higher theory.
We shall further discuss less coloured variants of higher theory,
relation of higher theory to higher categorified structure, and a
construction for a higher theory which generalizes the ``delooping''
construction for a symmetric monoidal category.



{\oldsubsection{{Planar theories}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}
\label{sec:planar-theory}

\subsubsection{}

The notion of symmetric multicategory had variants such as planar and
braided.
While a generalization of these will appear in Section
\ref{sec:grading}, the notion of \emph{planar} $n$-theory is
particularly simple to describe, and turns out to be also fundamental,
so we shall discuss it here.

The definition of a {\textbf}{planar $n$-theory} is the same as the
definition of a symmetric $n$-theory except that one uses the
category ${\mathrm}{Ord}$ instead of ${\mathrm}{Fin}$.
Namely, $I^0$ (and $S$) appearing in the definition \ref{def:theory}
of an $n$-theory should now be in ${\mathrm}{Ord}$, and everything else is as it
makes sense under this modification.

In particular, one obtains a planar $n$-theory from a symmetric
$n$-theory ${\mathcal}{U}$ by restricting the data defining ${\mathcal}{U}$,
through the forgetful functor ${\mathrm}{Ord}\to{\mathrm}{Fin}$.


\subsubsection{}

The notion of planar $n$-theory is fundamental for the following
reason.
Given a symmetric $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{U}$, and its object $x$, the
structure of a planar ($n-1$)-theory underlies the
structure formed by endomorphisms (i.e., unary endomultimaps) of $x$.

The idea is that if one intends to take as the part ($0'$) of an
input datum for ${\mathcal}{U}$, the constant elemental $I^1_0$-nerve
${*}\to\cdots\to{*}$, and as the part ($0''$), the constant family
at $x$,
then the rest of the required input data is of the same form as the
form for an input datum for a \emph{planar} ($n-1$)-theory.

Thus, a planar ($n-1$)-theory ${\mathcal}{V}={\mathcal}{M}ap_{\mathcal}{U}(x,x)$ is
obtained as follows.
Suppose inductively in $k$, that an input for the datum ($k$) for the
planar ($n-1$)-theory ${\mathcal}{V}$ is given by $J^\nu$,
$\psi^\nu$, $v^\nu$ for all integers $\nu$ in the suitable range.
Then one obtains an input for the datum ($k+1$) for ${\mathcal}{U}$ by
letting
\begin{itemize}
\item $I^\nu:=J^{\nu-1}$, $\phi^\nu:=\psi^{\nu-1}$ for $\nu\ge 1$,
\item $I^0$ and $\phi^0$ constant as above, as well as $u^0$ constant
  at $x$,
\item $u^\nu:=v^{\nu-1}$ for $\nu\ge 1$,
\end{itemize}
so we use the output for this by ${\mathcal}{U}$ as the datum ($k$) for
${\mathcal}{V}$ for the original input.

For example, the collection of the objects of ${\mathcal}{V}$ is
${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}(x;x)$, where $\pi$ is the identity map of
$I^0_1=\{1\}$.



{\oldsubsection{{More related higher theorizations.}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}

In Section \ref{sec:planar-theory}, we have found the structure of a
planar ($n-1$)-theory within the structure of every $n$-theory.
The case $n=1$ of this is the associative algebra of endomorphisms
within a multicategory, and by no accident, a planar $n$-theory is an
$n$-th theorization of an associative algebra.

Since we can also find other structures within the structure of a
multicategory, we can find higher theorized forms of them within the
structure of an $n$-theory.

For example, if we focus on, instead of endormophisms on a selected
object, all unary multimaps between arbitrary objects within an
$n$-theory, then we find that they naturally form a structure which is
an ($n-1$)-th theorization of the structure of a category.
We have seen examples of theorized categories in Section
\ref{sec:theorize-category}.
We have also noted there that theorized category was a `more coloured'
version of planar multicategory.
Higher theorizations of category relates to planar higher theories in
a similar manner.

For another example, if we fix one object of an $n$-theory to look at,
but allow all endomultimaps of arbitrary arities (and arbitrary higher
multimaps between them), then we find the
structure of an ($n-1$)-th theorization of an uncoloured operad.
The theorizations can have colours at `shallower' levels, and these
will be precisely defined as \emph{($n-1$)-tuply coloured}
$n$-theories in Section \ref{sec:stratum-for-colour}.



{\oldsubsection{{Restricting strata for colours}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}
\label{sec:stratum-for-colour}

\subsubsection{}

The datum of a multicategory, or a coloured operad, enriched in
groupoids, say, consists of
collection of objects or ``colours'', and operations or ``multimaps''
which compose.
In an $n$-theory, only the multimaps of dimension $n$ are required to
compose, so only these are really considered as operations, while the
collections of lower dimensional multimaps are then considered as
forming \emph{strata of colours} whose role is to specify the types of
the operations in the top dimension.

As we could consider uncoloured operad, we sometimes want to consider
uncoloured, and only partially coloured, higher theories.
Specifically, we would like to consider situations in which the data
below some dimension are all fixed to be `trivial'.
We actually do this by simulating such a situation, instead of
defining what we mean by the ``trivial'' data.

\begin{definition}\label{def:uncoloured}
Let $n\ge 2$ be an integer.
Then a (symmetric) {\textbf}{uncoloured $n$-theory} ${\mathcal}{U}$ enriched in
a symmetric monoidal category ${\mathcal}{A}$, consists of
data of the forms specified below as ($n$), ($n+1$) and ($\infty$).
\end{definition}

\begin{itemize}
\item[($n$)](The object ``formed by \emph{objects}''.)
  Suppose given the arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$ of an $n$-multimap in a
  symmetric higher theory, namely, ($n-1'$) through ($0'$) of ($n$) in
  Section \ref{sec:n}.
  Then an object ${\operatorname{Ob}}^\pi{\mathcal}{U}$ of ${\mathcal}{A}$, to be called the
  object of {\textbf}{objects} of ${\mathcal}{U}$ of the specified arity.
\end{itemize}

This extends for a non-elemental input datum just as the datum ($n$)
of Section \ref{sec:n} did, and we use the resulting extended datum in
the specification of the next datum form.

\begin{itemize}
\item[($n+1$)](\emph{Composition} of objects.)
  Suppose given the arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$ of an ($n+1$)-multimap in a
  symmetric higher theory.
  Then a map
  $m^{\mathcal}{U}_1(\pi)\colon{\operatorname{Ob}}^{\phi^{n-1}}{\mathcal}{U}\to{\operatorname{Ob}}^{\pi_!\phi^{n-1}}{\mathcal}{U}$
  in ${\mathcal}{A}$, where the source here is the object ${\bigotimes}_{i\in
    I^n_0}{\operatorname{Ob}}^{\phi^{n-1}_i}{\mathcal}{U}$.
  The map $m_1(\pi)$ will be called the {\textbf}{composition}
  operation for objects of ${\mathcal}{U}$.
\item[($\infty$)] A datum of coherent associativity for the
  composition
  operations, corresponding to that for an $n$-theory described in
  Sections \ref{sec:associative-n+2} and \ref{sec:coherence-n+ell}.
\end{itemize}

This completes Definition \ref{def:uncoloured}.

\begin{definition}\label{def:tuply-coloured}
Let $n\ge 2$ be an integer.
We say that an $n$-theory as defined in Definition \ref{def:theory},
as {\textbf}{$n$-tuply coloured}.

Let $m$ be an integer such that $1\le m\le n-1$.
Then a (symmetric) {\textbf}{$m$-tuply coloured $n$-theory} ${\mathcal}{U}$
enriched in a symmetric monoidal category ${\mathcal}{A}$,
consists of data of the forms specified below as ($n-m$), ``($k$)''
for every integer $k$ such that $n-m+1\le k\le n-1$, ($n$),
($n+1$) and ($\infty$).
\end{definition}

\begin{itemize}
\item[($n-m$)](\emph{Object}.)
  Suppose given the arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$ of an ($n-m$)-multimap in a
  symmetric higher theory (or a finite set $S$ with unique map
  $\pi\colon S\to{*}$, if $n-m=1$).
  Then a collection ${\operatorname{Ob}}^\pi{\mathcal}{U}$, whose member will be called an
  {\textbf}{object} of ${\mathcal}{U}$ of the specified arity.
\end{itemize}

This extends for a non-elemental input datum just as the datum ($k$)
of
Section \ref{sec:k} did for $k=n-m$, and we use the resulting extended
datum in the specification of the next datum form.

\begin{itemize}
\item[($k$)](\emph{($k-n+m$)-multimap}, inductively for $n-m+1\le k\le
  n-1$.)
  Suppose given
  \begin{itemize}
  \item the arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$ of a $k$-multimap in a symmetric
    higher theory,
  \item if $k-3\ge n-m$, then ($n-m''$) through ($k-3''$) of ($k-1$)
    here,
  \end{itemize}
  and
  \begin{itemize}
  \item[($k-2''$)] if $k-2\ge n-m$, then an $I^{k-2}$-family
    $u^{k-2-n+m}=(u^{k-n+m-2}_i)_{i\in[I^{k-1}_0]}$ of
    ($k-n+m-2$)-multimaps (or objects if $k-n+m-2=0$) in ${\mathcal}{U}$,
    where, if $k-n+m-2\ge 1$, then the $I^{k-2}_i$-family
    $u^{k-n+m-2}_i$ is in fact a
    ${{\phi^{k-2}}_{\rightarrow{{i}}}}_!\phi^{k-3}$-nerve (see
    ($k-1''$) below) of ($k-n+m-2$)-multimaps in ${\mathcal}{U}$,
    connecting ${{\phi^{k-2}}_{\rightarrow{{i}}}}_!u^{k-n-m-3}$, 
  \item[($k-1''$)] if $k-1=n-m$, then
    \begin{itemize}
    \item a \emph{$\phi^{k-2}$-nerve}
      $u^0_0$ of objects in ${\mathcal}{U}$,
      which \emph{by definition} means that $u^0_0=(u^0_{0i})_{i\in
        I^{k-1}_0}$, where $u^0_{0i}\in{\operatorname{Ob}}^{\phi^{k-2}_i}{\mathcal}{U}$,
    \item an object $u^0_1\in{\operatorname{Ob}}^{\pi_!\phi^{k-2}}{\mathcal}{U}$;
    \end{itemize}
    if $k-1\ge n-m+1$, then
    \begin{itemize}
    \item a \emph{$\phi^{k-2}$-nerve} $u^{k-1-n+m}_0$ of
      ($k-n+m-1$)-multimaps in ${\mathcal}{U}$ \emph{connecting}
      $u^{k-n+m-2}$, which \emph{by definition} means that
      $u^{k-n+m-1}_0=(u^{k-n+m-1}_{0i})_{i\in I^{k-1}_0}$, where
      $u^{k-n+m-1}_{0i}\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\phi^{k-2}_i}[u^{\le
        k-n+m-2}{\mathclose{|}_{{i}}}]$ (see below),
    \item $u^{k-n+m-1}_1\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\pi_!\phi^{k-2}}[\pi_!u^{\le
        k-n+m-2}]$.
    \end{itemize}
  \end{itemize}
  Then a collection
  ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u^{\le k-n+m-2}](u^{k-n+m-1}_0;u^{k-n+m-1}_1)$ or
  ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$ for short, whose member will be called a
  {\textbf}{($k-n+m$)-multimap} $u^{k-n+m-1}_0\to u^{k-n+m-1}_1$ in
  ${\mathcal}{U}$.
\end{itemize}

This extends for a non-elemental input datum just as the datum ($k$)
of Section \ref{sec:k} did, and we use the resulting extended datum in
the specification of the next datum form.

\begin{itemize}
\item[($n$)](The object ``formed by \emph{$m$-multimaps}''.)
  Suppose given the arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$ of an $n$-multimap in a
  symmetric higher theory, and a set of data similar to ($0''$)
  through ($k-1''$) of ``($k$)'' above, but with $k$ substituted by
  $n$, so these will be ($0''$) through ($n-1''$) here.
  Then an object ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u^{\le m-2}](u^{m-1}_0;u^{m-1}_1)$
  of ${\mathcal}{A}$, or ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$ for short, to be called the
  object of {\textbf}{$m$-multimaps} $u^{m-1}_0\to u^{m-1}_1$ in
  ${\mathcal}{U}$.
\end{itemize}

This extends for a non-elemental input datum just as the datum ($n$)
of Section \ref{sec:n} did, and we use the resulting extended datum in
the specification of the next datum form.

\begin{itemize}
\item[($n+1$)](\emph{Composition} of $m$-multimaps.)
  Suppose given
  \begin{itemize}
  \item the arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$ of an ($n+1$)-multimap in a symmetric
    higher theory,
  \item ($n-m''$) through ($n-2''$) of ($n$) above,
  \item ($k-2''$) of ($k$) above, but with $k$ substituted by
    $n+1$, so this will be ($n-1''$) here.
  \end{itemize}
  Then a map
  $m^{\mathcal}{U}_1(\pi)\colon{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\phi^{n-1}}_{\mathcal}{U}[u]\to{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\pi_!\phi^{n-1}}_{\mathcal}{U}[\pi_!u]$
  in ${\mathcal}{A}$, where the source here is the object ${\bigotimes}_{i\in
    I^n_0}{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\phi^{n-1}_i}[u{\mathclose{|}_{{i}}}]$ (of $\phi^{n-1}$-nerves of
  $m$-multimaps connecting $u^{m-1}$ in ${\mathcal}{U}$).
  The map $m_1(\pi)$ will be called the {\textbf}{composition} operation
  for $m$-multimaps in ${\mathcal}{U}$.

\item[($\infty$)] A datum of (coherent) associativity for the
  composition
  operations, corresponding to that for an $n$-theory described
  in Sections \ref{sec:associative-n+2} and \ref{sec:coherence-n+ell}.
\end{itemize}

This completes Definition \ref{def:tuply-coloured}.


\subsubsection{}

Any notion which makes sense for a general $n$-theory also makes sense
for an $n$-theory with restricted strata of colours as above.
Indeed, given the definition of a notion concerning an $n$-theory, one
obtains the definition of the corresponding notion for a less coloured
$n$-theory just by suppressing from the definition, every
specification involving colours in the lower dimensions in the
$n$-theory.
For example, at a place where one needs to choose an object of an
$n$-theory, one just does not need to make any choice with an
$m$-tuply coloured $n$-theory if $m\le n-1$.
Similarly, at a place where one needs to make some choice for every
object of the $n$-theory, one just make one choice with a not fully
coloured $n$-theory.



{\oldsubsection{{Forgetting categorifications to theorizations}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}
\label{sec:forget-to-theorization}

\subsubsection{}

For an integer $m\ge 0$, let us denote by ${\ccat{Cat}}_m$ the Cartesian
symmetric monoidal category of $m$-categories with a fix limit for the
size, where we let a {\textbf}{$0$-category} mean a groupoid by
convention.

While an $n$-theory enriched in ${\ccat{Cat}}_m$ is an instance of an enriched
$n$-theory, it is also \emph{unenriched} in the sense that we can more
generally consider $m$-categories enriched in a symmetric monoidal
category.
Thus it can be considered both as an ``unenriched'' instance of an
\emph{$m$-categorified} $n$-theory, and as an enriched
``uncategorified'' $n$-theory.
Interpolating these two views, it can also be considered as an
$\ell$-categorified $n$-theory enriched in ($m-\ell$)-categories, for
every integer $\ell$ such that $1\le\ell\le m-1$.


\subsubsection{}

Since ($n+1$)-theory is a theorization of $n$-theory, there are in
particular, $n$-theories enriched in ${\ccat{Cat}}_{m+1}$ among
($n+1$)-theories enriched in ${\ccat{Cat}}_m$.
Indeed, a \emph{op-lax} $n$-theory enriched in ${\ccat{Cat}}_{m+1}$ can be
characterized among ($n+1$)-theories enriched in ${\ccat{Cat}}_m$, as one in
which every
profunctor/distributor/bimodule (enriched in ${\ccat{Cat}}_m$) virtually
giving the composition of
\emph{$n$-multimaps}, is corepresentable, and an $n$-theory can be
characterized among op-lax $n$-theories as
one in which every associativity map is an isomorphism.

Given an $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{U}$ enriched in ($m+1$)-categories, let us
denote by ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$, ($n+1$)-theory enriched in
$m$-categories obtained by replacing each functor of composition
operation for $n$-multimaps in ${\mathcal}{U}$, by the bimodule
corepresented by it.
We shall say that ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ is {\textbf}{represented} by
${\mathcal}{U}$.

\begin{definition}\label{def:forget-to-theorization}
Let $n\ge 0$, $m\ge 2$ be integers, and let ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory
enriched in $m$-categories.
Given an integer $\ell$ such that $0\le\ell\le m$, we define an
($n+\ell$)-theory ${\Theta}^{n+\ell}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ enriched in
($m-\ell$)-categories, by the inductive relations
prevtext:
of $I^{n+\ell-1}_1$-nerves of ($\ell-1$)-isomorphisms in ${\mathcal}{A}$, as
given by
the family indexed by $i\in I^{n+\ell-1}_1$ of the isomorphisms
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex25.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="m_{\ell}(\pi_{i})\colon{\pi_{i}}_{!}m_{\ell-1}\bigl{(}\phi^{n+\ell-2}{%
\mathclose{|}_{{i}}}\bigr{)}{\xlongrightarrow{{\sim}}}m_{\ell-1}\bigl{(}(\psi_%
{!}\phi^{n+\ell-2})_{i}\bigr{)}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">ℓ</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>π</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>:</mo><mrow><mrow><mmultiscripts><mi>π</mi><mi>i</mi><none/><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">!</mo><none/></mmultiscripts><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>m</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">ℓ</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">(</mo><msub><mrow><msup><mi>ϕ</mi><mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">ℓ</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mi>i</mi></msub><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\xlongrightarrow</mtext></merror></mrow><mo>∼</mo><mrow><msub><mi>m</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">ℓ</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">(</mo><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>ψ</mi><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">!</mo></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>ϕ</mi><mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">ℓ</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mi>i</mi></msub><mo maxsize="120%" minsize="120%">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\end{definition}

For example, we obtain from a symmetric monoidal $n$-category
${\mathcal}{A}$ an uncategorified $n$-theory ${\Theta}^n_0{\mathcal}{A}$.
Even though this is an $n$-theory, it is true that this is not really
a new mathematical object since it is essentially just a symmetric
monoidal $n$-category ${\mathcal}{A}$.
An $n$-theory which \emph{fails} to be represented by an
($n-1$)-theory arises, for example, through the ``delooping'', as well
as the ``convolution'', constructions, which we shall discuss in
Sections \ref{sec:delooping} and \ref{sec:convolution} respectively.

However, considering symmetric monoidal $n$-categories as $n$-theories
means considering very different \emph{morphisms} between symmetric
monoidal $n$-categories, since a functor of these $n$-theories turns
out to be an \emph{$n$-lax} version of a symmetric monoidal functor of
the original symmetric monoidal $n$-categories.
Here and everywhere, by ``\emph{$n$-lax}'' we mean ``relaxed $n$
times''.
The way in which the structure is relaxed each time is actually quite
interesting here, and the author also finds the structure resulting
from iteration of these processes of relaxation fascinating.

Even though $n$-lax symmetric monoidal functor may still not be a
\emph{very} new notion, the construction above is certainly giving a
new meaning to this notion, in a richer environment where many new
and natural mathematical structures interact, as we shall show through
this work.

In general, for $m$-categorified $n$-theories ${\mathcal}{U},{\mathcal}{V}$, a
functor ${\Theta}^{m+n}_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\Theta}^{m+n}_n{\mathcal}{V}$ of
uncategorified ($n+m$)-theories is equivalent as a datum to an $m$-lax
functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$, as follows similarly to Therem
\ref{thm:functor-of-theorization} below.


\subsubsection{}

There are of course, less coloured versions of all the above.
In particular, in the situation of Definition
\ref{def:forget-to-theorization}, if ${\mathcal}{U}$ is $k$-tuply coloured,
where $0\le k\le n-1$, then ${\Theta}^{n+\ell}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ is
obtained as ($k+\ell$)-tuply coloured.



{\oldsubsection{{Theorization and lax functors}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}
\label{sec:functor}

\subsubsection{}

The obvious notion of functor of $n$-theories has a reasonable lax
version.
Let us start with recording the definition of a functor.

\begin{definition}\label{def:functor}
Let $n\ge 2$ be an integer, and let ${\mathcal}{U}$ and ${\mathcal}{V}$ be
$n$-theories enriched in a symmetric monoidal category ${\mathcal}{A}$.
Then a {\textbf}{functor} $F\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$ of $n$-theories
consists of data
of the forms specified below as ($0$), ``($k$)'' for every integer $k$
such that $1\le k\le n-1$, ($n$), ($n+1$), $(n+2)$, and ``($n+\ell$)''
for every integer $\ell\ge 3$.
\end{definition}

Similarly to the data for an $n$-theory, data for a functor will be
associated to input data satisfying the same elementality requirements
as before.
As before, each datum form specified needs to be extended for a
non-elemental input datum before the next datum form is specified.
The way how we do this is more or less the same as before, and we
shall do this implicitly.

The forms of data are as follows.

\begin{itemize}
\item[($0$)](\emph{Action} on objects.)
  For every object $u$ of ${\mathcal}{U}$, an object $Fu$ of ${\mathcal}{V}$.
\item[($k$)](\emph{Action} on $k$-mutimaps, inductively for $1\le k\le
  n-1$.)
  Suppose given the type $u$ of a $k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{U}$ of arity

\subsubsection{}

We can thus proceed to the next inductive step, and this completes

{\oldsection{{Simple variants and basic constructions}}\setcounter{subsection}{-1}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}\setcounter{equation}{-1}}
\label{sec:variant-construction}

{\oldsubsection{{Introduction}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}

In this section, we shall first discuss a planar variant of higher
theories, which iteratevely theorize associative algebra.
In particular, we shall find the structure of a planar ($n-1$)-theory
formed by endomorphisms in a symmetric $n$-theory.
This will lead to a discussion of other theorized structures similarly
residing in a symmetric higher theory.
We shall further discuss less coloured variants of higher theory,
relation of higher theory to higher categorified structure, and a
construction for a higher theory which generalizes the ``delooping''
construction for a symmetric monoidal category.



{\oldsubsection{{Planar theories}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}
\label{sec:planar-theory}

\subsubsection{}

The notion of symmetric multicategory had variants such as planar and
braided.
While a generalization of these will appear in Section
\ref{sec:grading}, the notion of \emph{planar} $n$-theory is
particularly simple to describe, and turns out to be also fundamental,
so we shall discuss it here.

The definition of a {\textbf}{planar $n$-theory} is the same as the
definition of a symmetric $n$-theory except that one uses the
category ${\mathrm}{Ord}$ instead of ${\mathrm}{Fin}$.
Namely, $I^0$ (and $S$) appearing in the definition \ref{def:theory}
of an $n$-theory should now be in ${\mathrm}{Ord}$, and everything else is as it
makes sense under this modification.

In particular, one obtains a planar $n$-theory from a symmetric
$n$-theory ${\mathcal}{U}$ by restricting the data defining ${\mathcal}{U}$,
through the forgetful functor ${\mathrm}{Ord}\to{\mathrm}{Fin}$.


\subsubsection{}

The notion of planar $n$-theory is fundamental for the following
reason.
Given a symmetric $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{U}$, and its object $x$, the
structure of a planar ($n-1$)-theory underlies the
structure formed by endomorphisms (i.e., unary endomultimaps) of $x$.

The idea is that if one intends to take as the part ($0'$) of an
input datum for ${\mathcal}{U}$, the constant elemental $I^1_0$-nerve
${*}\to\cdots\to{*}$, and as the part ($0''$), the constant family
at $x$,
then the rest of the required input data is of the same form as the
form for an input datum for a \emph{planar} ($n-1$)-theory.

Thus, a planar ($n-1$)-theory ${\mathcal}{V}={\mathcal}{M}ap_{\mathcal}{U}(x,x)$ is
obtained as follows.
Suppose inductively in $k$, that an input for the datum ($k$) for the
planar ($n-1$)-theory ${\mathcal}{V}$ is given by $J^\nu$,
$\psi^\nu$, $v^\nu$ for all integers $\nu$ in the suitable range.
Then one obtains an input for the datum ($k+1$) for ${\mathcal}{U}$ by
letting
\begin{itemize}
\item $I^\nu:=J^{\nu-1}$, $\phi^\nu:=\psi^{\nu-1}$ for $\nu\ge 1$,
\item $I^0$ and $\phi^0$ constant as above, as well as $u^0$ constant
  at $x$,
\item $u^\nu:=v^{\nu-1}$ for $\nu\ge 1$,
\end{itemize}
so we use the output for this by ${\mathcal}{U}$ as the datum ($k$) for
${\mathcal}{V}$ for the original input.

For example, the collection of the objects of ${\mathcal}{V}$ is
${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}(x;x)$, where $\pi$ is the identity map of
$I^0_1=\{1\}$.



{\oldsubsection{{More related higher theorizations.}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}

In Section \ref{sec:planar-theory}, we have found the structure of a
planar ($n-1$)-theory within the structure of every $n$-theory.
The case $n=1$ of this is the associative algebra of endomorphisms
within a multicategory, and by no accident, a planar $n$-theory is an
$n$-th theorization of an associative algebra.

Since we can also find other structures within the structure of a
multicategory, we can find higher theorized forms of them within the
structure of an $n$-theory.

For example, if we focus on, instead of endormophisms on a selected
object, all unary multimaps between arbitrary objects within an
$n$-theory, then we find that they naturally form a structure which is
an ($n-1$)-th theorization of the structure of a category.
We have seen examples of theorized categories in Section
\ref{sec:theorize-category}.
We have also noted there that theorized category was a `more coloured'
version of planar multicategory.
Higher theorizations of category relates to planar higher theories in
a similar manner.

For another example, if we fix one object of an $n$-theory to look at,
but allow all endomultimaps of arbitrary arities (and arbitrary higher
multimaps between them), then we find the
structure of an ($n-1$)-th theorization of an uncoloured operad.
The theorizations can have colours at `shallower' levels, and these
will be precisely defined as \emph{($n-1$)-tuply coloured}
$n$-theories in Section \ref{sec:stratum-for-colour}.



{\oldsubsection{{Restricting strata for colours}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}
\label{sec:stratum-for-colour}

\subsubsection{}

The datum of a multicategory, or a coloured operad, enriched in
groupoids, say, consists of
collection of objects or ``colours'', and operations or ``multimaps''
which compose.
In an $n$-theory, only the multimaps of dimension $n$ are required to
compose, so only these are really considered as operations, while the
collections of lower dimensional multimaps are then considered as
forming \emph{strata of colours} whose role is to specify the types of
the operations in the top dimension.

As we could consider uncoloured operad, we sometimes want to consider
uncoloured, and only partially coloured, higher theories.
Specifically, we would like to consider situations in which the data
below some dimension are all fixed to be `trivial'.
We actually do this by simulating such a situation, instead of
defining what we mean by the ``trivial'' data.

\begin{definition}\label{def:uncoloured}
Let $n\ge 2$ be an integer.
Then a (symmetric) {\textbf}{uncoloured $n$-theory} ${\mathcal}{U}$ enriched in
a symmetric monoidal category ${\mathcal}{A}$, consists of
data of the forms specified below as ($n$), ($n+1$) and ($\infty$).
\end{definition}

\begin{itemize}
\item[($n$)](The object ``formed by \emph{objects}''.)
  Suppose given the arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$ of an $n$-multimap in a
  symmetric higher theory, namely, ($n-1'$) through ($0'$) of ($n$) in
  Section \ref{sec:n}.
  Then an object ${\operatorname{Ob}}^\pi{\mathcal}{U}$ of ${\mathcal}{A}$, to be called the
  object of {\textbf}{objects} of ${\mathcal}{U}$ of the specified arity.
\end{itemize}

This extends for a non-elemental input datum just as the datum ($n$)
of Section \ref{sec:n} did, and we use the resulting extended datum in
the specification of the next datum form.

\begin{itemize}
\item[($n+1$)](\emph{Composition} of objects.)
  Suppose given the arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$ of an ($n+1$)-multimap in a
  symmetric higher theory.
  Then a map
  $m^{\mathcal}{U}_1(\pi)\colon{\operatorname{Ob}}^{\phi^{n-1}}{\mathcal}{U}\to{\operatorname{Ob}}^{\pi_!\phi^{n-1}}{\mathcal}{U}$
  in ${\mathcal}{A}$, where the source here is the object ${\bigotimes}_{i\in
    I^n_0}{\operatorname{Ob}}^{\phi^{n-1}_i}{\mathcal}{U}$.
  The map $m_1(\pi)$ will be called the {\textbf}{composition}
  operation for objects of ${\mathcal}{U}$.
\item[($\infty$)] A datum of coherent associativity for the
  composition
  operations, corresponding to that for an $n$-theory described in
  Sections \ref{sec:associative-n+2} and \ref{sec:coherence-n+ell}.
\end{itemize}

This completes Definition \ref{def:uncoloured}.

\begin{definition}\label{def:tuply-coloured}
Let $n\ge 2$ be an integer.
We say that an $n$-theory as defined in Definition \ref{def:theory},
as {\textbf}{$n$-tuply coloured}.

Let $m$ be an integer such that $1\le m\le n-1$.
Then a (symmetric) {\textbf}{$m$-tuply coloured $n$-theory} ${\mathcal}{U}$
enriched in a symmetric monoidal category ${\mathcal}{A}$,
consists of data of the forms specified below as ($n-m$), ``($k$)''
for every integer $k$ such that $n-m+1\le k\le n-1$, ($n$),
($n+1$) and ($\infty$).
\end{definition}

\begin{itemize}
\item[($n-m$)](\emph{Object}.)
  Suppose given the arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$ of an ($n-m$)-multimap in a
  symmetric higher theory (or a finite set $S$ with unique map
  $\pi\colon S\to{*}$, if $n-m=1$).
  Then a collection ${\operatorname{Ob}}^\pi{\mathcal}{U}$, whose member will be called an
  {\textbf}{object} of ${\mathcal}{U}$ of the specified arity.
\end{itemize}

This extends for a non-elemental input datum just as the datum ($k$)
of
Section \ref{sec:k} did for $k=n-m$, and we use the resulting extended
datum in the specification of the next datum form.

\begin{itemize}
\item[($k$)](\emph{($k-n+m$)-multimap}, inductively for $n-m+1\le k\le
  n-1$.)
  Suppose given
  \begin{itemize}
  \item the arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$ of a $k$-multimap in a symmetric
    higher theory,
  \item if $k-3\ge n-m$, then ($n-m''$) through ($k-3''$) of ($k-1$)
    here,
  \end{itemize}
  and
  \begin{itemize}
  \item[($k-2''$)] if $k-2\ge n-m$, then an $I^{k-2}$-family
    $u^{k-2-n+m}=(u^{k-n+m-2}_i)_{i\in[I^{k-1}_0]}$ of
    ($k-n+m-2$)-multimaps (or objects if $k-n+m-2=0$) in ${\mathcal}{U}$,
    where, if $k-n+m-2\ge 1$, then the $I^{k-2}_i$-family
    $u^{k-n+m-2}_i$ is in fact a
    ${{\phi^{k-2}}_{\rightarrow{{i}}}}_!\phi^{k-3}$-nerve (see
    ($k-1''$) below) of ($k-n+m-2$)-multimaps in ${\mathcal}{U}$,
    connecting ${{\phi^{k-2}}_{\rightarrow{{i}}}}_!u^{k-n-m-3}$, 
  \item[($k-1''$)] if $k-1=n-m$, then
    \begin{itemize}
    \item a \emph{$\phi^{k-2}$-nerve}
      $u^0_0$ of objects in ${\mathcal}{U}$,
      which \emph{by definition} means that $u^0_0=(u^0_{0i})_{i\in
        I^{k-1}_0}$, where $u^0_{0i}\in{\operatorname{Ob}}^{\phi^{k-2}_i}{\mathcal}{U}$,
    \item an object $u^0_1\in{\operatorname{Ob}}^{\pi_!\phi^{k-2}}{\mathcal}{U}$;
    \end{itemize}
    if $k-1\ge n-m+1$, then
    \begin{itemize}
    \item a \emph{$\phi^{k-2}$-nerve} $u^{k-1-n+m}_0$ of
      ($k-n+m-1$)-multimaps in ${\mathcal}{U}$ \emph{connecting}
      $u^{k-n+m-2}$, which \emph{by definition} means that
      $u^{k-n+m-1}_0=(u^{k-n+m-1}_{0i})_{i\in I^{k-1}_0}$, where
      $u^{k-n+m-1}_{0i}\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\phi^{k-2}_i}[u^{\le
        k-n+m-2}{\mathclose{|}_{{i}}}]$ (see below),
    \item $u^{k-n+m-1}_1\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\pi_!\phi^{k-2}}[\pi_!u^{\le
        k-n+m-2}]$.
    \end{itemize}
  \end{itemize}
  Then a collection
  ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u^{\le k-n+m-2}](u^{k-n+m-1}_0;u^{k-n+m-1}_1)$ or
  ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$ for short, whose member will be called a
  {\textbf}{($k-n+m$)-multimap} $u^{k-n+m-1}_0\to u^{k-n+m-1}_1$ in
  ${\mathcal}{U}$.
\end{itemize}

This extends for a non-elemental input datum just as the datum ($k$)
of Section \ref{sec:k} did, and we use the resulting extended datum in
the specification of the next datum form.

\begin{itemize}
\item[($n$)](The object ``formed by \emph{$m$-multimaps}''.)
  Suppose given the arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$ of an $n$-multimap in a
  symmetric higher theory, and a set of data similar to ($0''$)
  through ($k-1''$) of ``($k$)'' above, but with $k$ substituted by
  $n$, so these will be ($0''$) through ($n-1''$) here.
  Then an object ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u^{\le m-2}](u^{m-1}_0;u^{m-1}_1)$
  of ${\mathcal}{A}$, or ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$ for short, to be called the
  object of {\textbf}{$m$-multimaps} $u^{m-1}_0\to u^{m-1}_1$ in
  ${\mathcal}{U}$.
\end{itemize}

This extends for a non-elemental input datum just as the datum ($n$)
of Section \ref{sec:n} did, and we use the resulting extended datum in
the specification of the next datum form.

\begin{itemize}
\item[($n+1$)](\emph{Composition} of $m$-multimaps.)
  Suppose given
  \begin{itemize}
  \item the arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$ of an ($n+1$)-multimap in a symmetric
    higher theory,
  \item ($n-m''$) through ($n-2''$) of ($n$) above,
  \item ($k-2''$) of ($k$) above, but with $k$ substituted by
    $n+1$, so this will be ($n-1''$) here.
  \end{itemize}
  Then a map
  $m^{\mathcal}{U}_1(\pi)\colon{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\phi^{n-1}}_{\mathcal}{U}[u]\to{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\pi_!\phi^{n-1}}_{\mathcal}{U}[\pi_!u]$
  in ${\mathcal}{A}$, where the source here is the object ${\bigotimes}_{i\in
    I^n_0}{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\phi^{n-1}_i}[u{\mathclose{|}_{{i}}}]$ (of $\phi^{n-1}$-nerves of
  $m$-multimaps connecting $u^{m-1}$ in ${\mathcal}{U}$).
  The map $m_1(\pi)$ will be called the {\textbf}{composition} operation
  for $m$-multimaps in ${\mathcal}{U}$.

\item[($\infty$)] A datum of (coherent) associativity for the
  composition
  operations, corresponding to that for an $n$-theory described
  in Sections \ref{sec:associative-n+2} and \ref{sec:coherence-n+ell}.
\end{itemize}

This completes Definition \ref{def:tuply-coloured}.


\subsubsection{}

Any notion which makes sense for a general $n$-theory also makes sense
for an $n$-theory with restricted strata of colours as above.
Indeed, given the definition of a notion concerning an $n$-theory, one
obtains the definition of the corresponding notion for a less coloured
$n$-theory just by suppressing from the definition, every
specification involving colours in the lower dimensions in the
$n$-theory.
For example, at a place where one needs to choose an object of an
$n$-theory, one just does not need to make any choice with an
$m$-tuply coloured $n$-theory if $m\le n-1$.
Similarly, at a place where one needs to make some choice for every
object of the $n$-theory, one just make one choice with a not fully
coloured $n$-theory.



{\oldsubsection{{Forgetting categorifications to theorizations}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}
\label{sec:forget-to-theorization}

\subsubsection{}

For an integer $m\ge 0$, let us denote by ${\ccat{Cat}}_m$ the Cartesian
symmetric monoidal category of $m$-categories with a fix limit for the
size, where we let a {\textbf}{$0$-category} mean a groupoid by
convention.

While an $n$-theory enriched in ${\ccat{Cat}}_m$ is an instance of an enriched
$n$-theory, it is also \emph{unenriched} in the sense that we can more
generally consider $m$-categories enriched in a symmetric monoidal
category.
Thus it can be considered both as an ``unenriched'' instance of an
\emph{$m$-categorified} $n$-theory, and as an enriched
``uncategorified'' $n$-theory.
Interpolating these two views, it can also be considered as an
$\ell$-categorified $n$-theory enriched in ($m-\ell$)-categories, for
every integer $\ell$ such that $1\le\ell\le m-1$.


\subsubsection{}

Since ($n+1$)-theory is a theorization of $n$-theory, there are in
particular, $n$-theories enriched in ${\ccat{Cat}}_{m+1}$ among
($n+1$)-theories enriched in ${\ccat{Cat}}_m$.
Indeed, a \emph{op-lax} $n$-theory enriched in ${\ccat{Cat}}_{m+1}$ can be
characterized among ($n+1$)-theories enriched in ${\ccat{Cat}}_m$, as one in
which every
profunctor/distributor/bimodule (enriched in ${\ccat{Cat}}_m$) virtually
giving the composition of
\emph{$n$-multimaps}, is corepresentable, and an $n$-theory can be
characterized among op-lax $n$-theories as
one in which every associativity map is an isomorphism.

Given an $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{U}$ enriched in ($m+1$)-categories, let us
denote by ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$, ($n+1$)-theory enriched in
$m$-categories obtained by replacing each functor of composition
operation for $n$-multimaps in ${\mathcal}{U}$, by the bimodule
corepresented by it.
We shall say that ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ is {\textbf}{represented} by
${\mathcal}{U}$.

\begin{definition}\label{def:forget-to-theorization}
Let $n\ge 0$, $m\ge 2$ be integers, and let ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory
enriched in $m$-categories.
Given an integer $\ell$ such that $0\le\ell\le m$, we define an
($n+\ell$)-theory ${\Theta}^{n+\ell}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ enriched in
($m-\ell$)-categories, by the inductive relations

\ell=0$},\\
{\Theta}_{n+\ell-1}{\Theta}^{n+\ell-1}_{n}{\mathcal{}}{U}&\text{if $\ell\geq 1%
$}.\end{cases}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Θ</mi><mi>n</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">ℓ</mi></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>U</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mi>U</mi></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mtext>if </mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">ℓ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Θ</mi><mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">ℓ</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Θ</mi><mi>n</mi><mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">ℓ</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>U</mi></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mtext>if </mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">ℓ</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext:
\end{definition}

For example, we obtain from a symmetric monoidal $n$-category
${\mathcal}{A}$ an uncategorified $n$-theory ${\Theta}^n_0{\mathcal}{A}$.
Even though this is an $n$-theory, it is true that this is not really
a new mathematical object since it is essentially just a symmetric
monoidal $n$-category ${\mathcal}{A}$.
An $n$-theory which \emph{fails} to be represented by an
($n-1$)-theory arises, for example, through the ``delooping'', as well
as the ``convolution'', constructions, which we shall discuss in
Sections \ref{sec:delooping} and \ref{sec:convolution} respectively.

However, considering symmetric monoidal $n$-categories as $n$-theories
means considering very different \emph{morphisms} between symmetric
monoidal $n$-categories, since a functor of these $n$-theories turns
out to be an \emph{$n$-lax} version of a symmetric monoidal functor of
the original symmetric monoidal $n$-categories.
Here and everywhere, by ``\emph{$n$-lax}'' we mean ``relaxed $n$
times''.
The way in which the structure is relaxed each time is actually quite
interesting here, and the author also finds the structure resulting
from iteration of these processes of relaxation fascinating.

Even though $n$-lax symmetric monoidal functor may still not be a
\emph{very} new notion, the construction above is certainly giving a
new meaning to this notion, in a richer environment where many new
and natural mathematical structures interact, as we shall show through
this work.

In general, for $m$-categorified $n$-theories ${\mathcal}{U},{\mathcal}{V}$, a
functor ${\Theta}^{m+n}_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\Theta}^{m+n}_n{\mathcal}{V}$ of
uncategorified ($n+m$)-theories is equivalent as a datum to an $m$-lax
functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$, as follows similarly to Therem
\ref{thm:functor-of-theorization} below.


\subsubsection{}

There are of course, less coloured versions of all the above.
In particular, in the situation of Definition
\ref{def:forget-to-theorization}, if ${\mathcal}{U}$ is $k$-tuply coloured,
where $0\le k\le n-1$, then ${\Theta}^{n+\ell}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ is
obtained as ($k+\ell$)-tuply coloured.



{\oldsubsection{{Theorization and lax functors}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}
\label{sec:functor}

\subsubsection{}

The obvious notion of functor of $n$-theories has a reasonable lax
version.
Let us start with recording the definition of a functor.

\begin{definition}\label{def:functor}
Let $n\ge 2$ be an integer, and let ${\mathcal}{U}$ and ${\mathcal}{V}$ be
$n$-theories enriched in a symmetric monoidal category ${\mathcal}{A}$.
Then a {\textbf}{functor} $F\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$ of $n$-theories
consists of data
of the forms specified below as ($0$), ``($k$)'' for every integer $k$
such that $1\le k\le n-1$, ($n$), ($n+1$), $(n+2)$, and ``($n+\ell$)''
for every integer $\ell\ge 3$.
\end{definition}

Similarly to the data for an $n$-theory, data for a functor will be
associated to input data satisfying the same elementality requirements
as before.
As before, each datum form specified needs to be extended for a
non-elemental input datum before the next datum form is specified.
The way how we do this is more or less the same as before, and we
shall do this implicitly.

The forms of data are as follows.

\begin{itemize}
\item[($0$)](\emph{Action} on objects.)
  For every object $u$ of ${\mathcal}{U}$, an object $Fu$ of ${\mathcal}{V}$.
\item[($k$)](\emph{Action} on $k$-mutimaps, inductively for $1\le k\le
  n-1$.)
  Suppose given the type $u$ of a $k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{U}$ of arity
  given as $(I;\pi,\phi)$.
  Then for every $k$-multimap $x\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$, a
  $k$-multimap $Fx\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{V}[Fu]$.
\item[($n$)](\emph{Action} on $n$-multimaps.)
  Suppose given the type $u$ of an $n$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{U}$ of arity
  given as $(I;\pi,\phi)$.
  Then a map
  ${\check}{m}^F_1(\pi)\colon{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]\to{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{V}[Fu]$
  in ${\mathcal}{A}$.
\item[($n+1$)](The isomorphism of \emph{compatibility} with the
  composition.)
  Suppose given
  \begin{itemize}
  \item the arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$ of an ($n+1$)-multimap in a symmetric
    higher theory,
  \item the type $u$ of a $\phi^{n-1}$-nerve of $n$-multimaps in
    ${\mathcal}{U}$.
  \end{itemize}
  Then a $2$-isomorphism

This completes Definition \ref{def:lax-functor}.


\subsubsection{}
\label{sec:colour-system}

The notion of lax functor can be used to define the notion of
``\emph{($n+1$)-tuply}'' \emph{coloured lax $n$-theory}, which will
allow us to describe an ($n+1$)-theory along the line discussed in
Section \ref{sec:coloured-lax-structure}, as to be done in Proposition
\ref{prop:theory-as-theorization}.
In order to do this, let us first understand an $n$-theory as a
functor of higher theories.

In order to describe the source of the functor, we need the following
definitions.
Recall that an $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{U}$ consists by definition, of data
($k$) for all integers $k\ge 0$, of the forms specified in Section
\ref{sec:symmetric-theory}.
Of these, the part $k\le n-1$ does not involve the information of
where the theory is enriched.

\begin{definition}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer.
Then we refer to data of the forms ($0$) through ($n-1$) as specified
for Definition \ref{def:theory} of an $n$-theory, as a
system of {\textbf}{colours up to dimension $n-1$} for a higher theory, or
a system of colours {\textbf}{for an $n$-theory}.
\end{definition}

In particular, for every $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{U}$ and every integer $m$
such that $0\le m\le n-1$, we have a system of colours up to dimension
$m$ {\textbf}{underlying} ${\mathcal}{U}$, consisting of the data ($0$) through
($m$) for ${\mathcal}{U}$, so ${\mathcal}{U}$ consists of this system of
colours and a structure on it.

\begin{definition}
Let $m\ge 0$ and $n\ge m+1$ be integers.
Then for the system of colours up to dimension $m$ consisting of data
of the forms ($0$) through ($m$) as specified for Definition
\ref{def:theory} of an $n$-theory, we refer to the rest of data for an
$n$-theory, consisting of data of the forms ($k$) for $k\ge m+1$, as
the {\textbf}{structure of an $n$-theory} on the system of colours.
\end{definition}

In order to describe the target of the functor, we need to recall the
\emph{categorical delooping}, which associates to a monoid $A$ (or
more generally, a monoidal $n$-category), a category (or
($n+1$)-category in the general case) ${B} A$ with a
chosen ``base'' object, in which
\begin{itemize}
\item all objects are equivalent,
\item the endomorphism monoid (or monoidal $n$-category) of the base
  object is given an equivalence with $A$.
\end{itemize}

Note that, if ${\mathcal}{A}$ is a \emph{symmetric monoidal} $n$-category,
then ${B}{\mathcal}{A}$ is canonically a symmetric monoidal
($n+1$)-category (with unit the base object) since the functor
${B}$ preserves direct products.

Now the following gives an interpretation of a higher theory as a
functor of higher theories.

\begin{example}\label{ex:theory-as-functor}
Choose and fixed a system of colours up to dimension $n-1$, and denote
by ${\mathcal}{T}$ the terminal object among unenriched ($n+1$)-theories
extending this system of lower colours.
Explicitly, ${\mathcal}{T}$ is such that every collection of
$n$-multimaps in it is non-empty, and every groupoid of
($n+1$)-multimaps in it is contractible.

Then the structure on the chosen system of colours, of an $n$-theory
enriched in a symmetric monoidal category ${\mathcal}{A}$, is equivalent as
a datum to a functor ${\mathcal}{T}\to{\Theta}^{n+1}_0{B}^n{\mathcal}{A}$
(where ${B}^n$ indicates $n$-fold application of the delooping
construction ${B}$) of ($n+1$)-theories which is
{\textbf}{$n$-trapped} in the sense that it sends any object of ${\mathcal}{T}$
to the base object of ${B}^n{\mathcal}{A}$, and any $k$-multimap of
${\mathcal}{T}$ for $1\le k\le n-1$, to the identity $k$-morphism or the
base object of ${B}^{n-k}{\mathcal}{A}$.
\end{example}

Let us say that an ($n+1$)-theory ${\mathcal}{T}$ as in Example
\ref{ex:theory-as-functor} is terminal {\textbf}{on}
the chosen system of colours up to dimension $n-1$.
Considering ${\mathcal}{T}$ as a coloured variant of the terminal unenriched
uncoloured ($n+1$)-theory ${\boldsymbol{1}}^{n+1}_{\mathrm}{Com}$ (where ${\mathrm}{Com}=E_\infty$
denotes the commutative operad), one might say that an $n$-theory
enriched in ${\mathcal}{A}$ is an $n$-trapped functor
${\boldsymbol{1}}^{n+1}_{\mathrm}{Com}\to{\Theta}^{n+1}_0{B}^n{\mathcal}{A}$ \emph{with
  strata of colours} for an $n$-theory.

\begin{definition}\label{def:coloured-lax-theory}
For an integer $n\ge 0$, an {\textbf}{($n+1$)-tuply coloured lax
  $n$-theory} enriched in a symmetric monoidal $2$-category ${\mathcal}{A}$,
is an $n$-trapped lax functor
${\boldsymbol{1}}^{n+1}_{\mathrm}{Com}\to{\Theta}^{n+1}_0{B}^n{\mathcal}{A}$ with strata
of colours up to dimension $n$, namely, an $n$-trapped lax functor
$F\colon{\mathcal}{T}\to{\Theta}^{n+1}_0{B}^n{\mathcal}{A}$, where
${\mathcal}{T}$ is an unenriched ($n+1$)-theory, which is terminal on a
system of colours for an ($n+1$)-theory.

An ($n+1$)-tuply coloured lax $n$-theory enriched in ${\mathcal}{A}$,
defined by a lax functor $F$ as above, is said to be {\textbf}{trapped} if
$F$ sends $n$-multimaps of ${\mathcal}{T}$ to the unit object of ${\mathcal}{A}$.
\end{definition}

\begin{proposition}\label{prop:theory-as-theorization}
Let ${\mathcal}{A}$ be a symmetric monoidal category.
Then, for an integer $n\ge 1$, an $n$-theory enriched in ${\mathcal}{A}$ is
equivalent as a datum to a trapped $n$-tuply coloured lax
($n-1$)-theory enriched in ${B}{\mathcal}{A}$.
\end{proposition}

This is a consequence of Theorem \ref{thm:functor-of-theorization}
below, as will be seen in Section \ref{sec:delooping-comparison}.


\subsubsection{}
\label{sec:functor-of-theorization}

The following is a key fact on the relation between theorization and
categorification.

\begin{theorem}\label{thm:functor-of-theorization}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ and ${\mathcal}{V}$ be
categorified $n$-theories.
Then a functor ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$ of
uncategorified ($n+1$)-theories, is
equivalent as a datum to a lax functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$.
\end{theorem}

\begin{proof}
{\refstepcounter{proofsec}\noindent\textbf{\theproofsec.}~}
We first note that the form of datum for the action of a functor
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$ on the colours up to
dimension $n-1$, is identical to the form of datum for the action of a
lax functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$ on the colours up to the same
dimension.
Then for any fixed datum of this form, we would like to prove that the
categories (or $2$-categories) naturally formed respectively by the
structures on these same data, of functors (of ($n+1$)-theories), and
of lax functors (of categorified $n$-theories), are equivalent.

{\refstepcounter{proofsec}\noindent\textbf{\theproofsec.}~}
The structure of a categorified $n$-theory is given on the categories
of $n$-multimaps, by the (cohrently) associative composition
functors.
A lax functor $F\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$ extending the chosen action,
is then seen to be given by
\begin{enumerate}
\setcounter{enumi}{-1}
\item\label{item:action-on-n}
  the action of $F$ on the categories of $n$-multimaps through
  functors specified by the datum ${\check}{m}^F_1$, and
\item\label{item:compatibility-n-action-composition}
  the (lax) compatibility specified by the data $m^F_2$ and
  ${\check}{m}^F_k$ for $k\ge 3$, of the mentioned action with the
  associative composition functors for $n$-multimaps in ${\mathcal}{U}$ and
  in ${\mathcal}{V}$.
\end{enumerate}

{\refstepcounter{proofsec}\noindent\textbf{\theproofsec.}~}\label{step:lax-functor-to-functor}
Recall that we have obtained ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ by replacing the
composition functors of ${\mathcal}{U}$ by the
bimodules/distributors/profunctors represented by them, and similarly
for ${\mathcal}{V}$.

Given a datum as (\ref{item:action-on-n}) above for a lax functor $F$,
of an action on $n$-multimaps, a datum of compatibility as
(\ref{item:compatibility-n-action-composition}) above, of this action
with the composition functors for $n$-multimaps, can equivalently be
described as an action on the (associative) composition bimodules for
$n$-multimaps (which were represented by the composition functors) in
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ and in ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$.
Note that these bimodules (in ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ or in
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$) are formed by ($n+1$)-multimaps, and the
(coherent) associativity of the composition (for $n$-multimaps) can
equivalently be described as the (coherently associative) composition
operations for ($n+1$)-multimaps.

In this manner, we consider $F$ as a structure between
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ and ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$.

The difference of this structure between ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ and
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$, from a functor
$G\colon{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$ of
($n+1$)-theories, is that
\begin{itemize}
\item the action of $G$ on $n$-multimaps does not (explicitly) include
  the datum of functoriality included in ${\check}{m}^F_1$, and
\item the action of $G$ on ($n+1$)-multimaps (given by ${\check}{m}^G_1$)
  and its compatibility (given by ${\check}{m}^G_k$, $k\ge 2$) with the
  composition operations for ($n+1$)-multimaps in
  ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ and in ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$, do not
  explicitly include the data of compatibility with the bimodules
  structures, included in $m^F_2$ and ${\check}{m}^F_{\ge 3}$.
\end{itemize}

Never the less, we obtain a functor
${\Theta}_nF\colon{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$ by
forgetting these extra data (which will turn out in the next step to
have been actually redundant).

{\refstepcounter{proofsec}\noindent\textbf{\theproofsec.}~}\label{step:functor-to-lax-functor}
Conversely, suppose given a functor
$G\colon{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$ which extends the
chosen actions up to dimension $n-1$.
Then, from the discussions above, a lax functor
$H\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$ extending the same lower
actions, such that ${\Theta}_nH=G$, is constructed if we equip the
higher data for $G$ with the following.
\begin{itemize}
\item A functoriality in the $n$-multimap $x\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$,
  on the $n$-multimap $Gx\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{V}[Hu]$.
\item A compatibility of this functoriality with the data
  ${\check}{m}^G_i$, $i\ge 1$, of the action of $G$ (in a manner
  compatible with the (associative) composition operations for
  ($n+1$)-multimaps in ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ and in
  ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$) on ($n+1$)-multimaps.
\end{itemize}

In order to obtain a functoriality of the $n$-multimap $Gx$, one notes
that a map in the category ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$
is suitably `unary' ($n+1$)-multimaps in ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$.
The desired functoriality is given by the restriction of the
associative action of $G$ to unary ($n+1$)-multimaps in
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$.

A compatibility of this functoriality with the action of $G$ means
\begin{itemize}
\item a naturality of every instance of the map

\phi^{n-1}){\longrightarrow}{\check{}}{m}^{F}_{1}(\pi_{!}\phi^{n-1}){\circ}m^{%

in $u^n$, and
\item a compatibility of this naturality with the compatibility, given
  by ${\check}{m}^G_i$, $i\ge 2$, of these maps ${\check}{m}^G_1(\pi)$ with
  the composition operations in ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ and in
  ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$.
\end{itemize}
We note that the functoriality in $u^n$ of the target of
${\check}{m}^G_1(\pi)$ is the composite of the functoriality of
${\mathrm{Map}}_{{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\pi_!\phi^{n-1}}_{\mathcal}{V}[\pi_!Hu^{\le
    n-1}]}\bigl(m^{\mathcal}{V}_1(\pi)(-),-\bigr)$ in its variables, with the
functoriality of $G$.
Moreover, the compatibility of this functoriality with the composition
structures of ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ and of ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$,
is also induced by the same functoriality of $G$, from the
compatibility of the functoriality of
${\mathrm{Map}}_{{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\pi_!\phi^{n-1}}_{\mathcal}{V}[\pi_!v]}\bigl(m^{\mathcal}{V}_1(\pi)(-),-\bigr)$
with the composition operations.

Now, the functoriality, together with its compatibility with the
composition structure of ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$, of
${\mathrm{Map}}_{{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\pi_!\phi^{n-1}}_{\mathcal}{U}[\pi_!u^{\le
    n-1}]}\bigl(m^{\mathcal}{U}_1(\pi)(-),-\bigr)={\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}}\bigl[u^{\le
  n-1}\bigr]\bigl(-;-\bigr)$ can alternatively be considered as obtained
by suitably restricting the composition structure of
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$, and similarly for
${\mathrm{Map}}_{{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\pi_!\phi^{n-1}}_{\mathcal}{V}[\pi_!v]}\bigl(m^{\mathcal}{V}_1(\pi)(-),-\bigr)$.
Since the functoriality of $G$ on the category of $n$-multimaps is as
constructed above, we see that the compatibility of the action of $G$
on ($n+1$)-multimaps with the composition structures of
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ and of
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$, also induces a desired datum.

{\refstepcounter{proofsec}\noindent\textbf{\theproofsec.}~}
We have thus constructed a desired lax functor
$H\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$ naturally from $G$.
In order to complete the proof, we would like to verify in the case
$G={\Theta}_nF$ for a lax functor $F\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$, that
the lax functor ``$H$'' constructed from $G$ will be naturally
equivalent to $F$.
For this, it suffices to observe that the set of data which we have
added to the datum of $G$ to construct $H$ in the step
\ref{step:functor-to-lax-functor}, is naturally equivalent to the
set of data which was ``forgotten'' in the construction
$F\mapsto{\Theta}_nF$ in the step
\ref{step:lax-functor-to-functor}, but this is clear.
\end{proof}

\begin{remark}\label{rem:lax-functor-general}
We have thus described for the ($n+1$)-theory
${\mathcal}{W}={\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$, a functor
$G\colon{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{W}$ as a lax functor
${\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$.
Similar arguments lead to a description of $G$ for an arbitrary
($n+1$)-theory ${\mathcal}{W}$, as a structure generalizing a lax functor
${\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$.
One might call this structure between ${\mathcal}{U}$ and ${\mathcal}{W}$ a
{\textbf}{functor} ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{W}$.
Thus, a functor ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{W}$ will be equivalent as
a datum to a functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{W}$.
\end{remark}


\subsubsection{}

Note that $n$-theories enriched in groupoids are also among
$n$-theories enriched in categories since a groupoid can be considered
as a category in which every morphism is invertible.
This kind of unenriched categorified $n$-theories is special as a
target of a
functor in that there is no difference between an ordinary functor and
a lax functor from an unenriched categorified $n$-theory to such a
target.

\begin{corollary}\label{cor:forget-to-theorization}
The functor ${\Theta}_n$ is fully faithful on $n$-theories enriched
in groupoids.
\end{corollary}



{\oldsubsection{{Delooping a higher theory}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}
\label{sec:delooping}

\subsubsection{}

There is a construction, which we shall call the \emph{delooping}, of
a symmetric $n$-tuply coloured ($n+1$)-theory from a symmetric
$n$-theory.
We shall describe this construction, and then discuss its relation to
the ``categorical'' delooping.

An ($n+1$)-theory which is obtained through this construction normally
fails to be representable by an $n$-theory.
Delooped theories will be conveniently used throughout this work as
the targets of (possibly ``coloured'') functors of higher theories.


\subsubsection{}

The delooping construction relies on the following construction.

Suppose first that the arity of a $2$-multimap is specified as in
($1'$) and ($0'$) of ($2$) in Section \ref{sec:2}.
Then since our notation \ref{notation:skip-0} chooses an embedding
$I^1_0{\hookrightarrow}[I^1_0]$, it makes sense to take the coproduct
$\coprod_{I^1_0}I^0$.
Then note that a $\phi^0$-nerve $u^0_0$ as in ($2$) of Definition
\ref{def:tuply-coloured} in the case $m-n=1$, of objects of an
($n-1$)-tuply coloured $n$-theory, can be considered as a
($\coprod_{I^1_0}I^0$)-family, while an ($I^0_0$-ary) object $u^0_1$
is a ($\coprod_{I^1_1}\pi_!I^0$)-family, where $I^1_1:=\{1\}$.

Suppose next given the arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$ of a $3$-multimap in a
symmetric higher theory.
Then for every $i\in I^2_0$ and $j\in I^1_i$, we have a map
$\coprod_{(\phi^1_i)^{-1}j}{({\phi^1}_{\rightarrow{{i-1}}})}_!I^0\to
I^0_{[{\phi^1}_{\rightarrow{{i}}}](j)}$ whose component for
$k\in(\phi^1_i)^{-1}j$ is the composite
prevtext:
in ${\mathcal}{A}$.
  See ($n+1$) for Definition \ref{def:functor} above.
\item[($\infty$)] A datum of coherence, similar to that for a
  functor.
\end{itemize}

This completes Definition \ref{def:lax-functor}.


\subsubsection{}
\label{sec:colour-system}

The notion of lax functor can be used to define the notion of
``\emph{($n+1$)-tuply}'' \emph{coloured lax $n$-theory}, which will
allow us to describe an ($n+1$)-theory along the line discussed in
Section \ref{sec:coloured-lax-structure}, as to be done in Proposition
\ref{prop:theory-as-theorization}.
In order to do this, let us first understand an $n$-theory as a
functor of higher theories.

In order to describe the source of the functor, we need the following
definitions.
Recall that an $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{U}$ consists by definition, of data
($k$) for all integers $k\ge 0$, of the forms specified in Section
\ref{sec:symmetric-theory}.
Of these, the part $k\le n-1$ does not involve the information of
where the theory is enriched.

\begin{definition}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer.
Then we refer to data of the forms ($0$) through ($n-1$) as specified
for Definition \ref{def:theory} of an $n$-theory, as a
system of {\textbf}{colours up to dimension $n-1$} for a higher theory, or
a system of colours {\textbf}{for an $n$-theory}.
\end{definition}

In particular, for every $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{U}$ and every integer $m$
such that $0\le m\le n-1$, we have a system of colours up to dimension
$m$ {\textbf}{underlying} ${\mathcal}{U}$, consisting of the data ($0$) through
($m$) for ${\mathcal}{U}$, so ${\mathcal}{U}$ consists of this system of
colours and a structure on it.

\begin{definition}
Let $m\ge 0$ and $n\ge m+1$ be integers.
Then for the system of colours up to dimension $m$ consisting of data
of the forms ($0$) through ($m$) as specified for Definition
\ref{def:theory} of an $n$-theory, we refer to the rest of data for an
$n$-theory, consisting of data of the forms ($k$) for $k\ge m+1$, as
the {\textbf}{structure of an $n$-theory} on the system of colours.
\end{definition}

In order to describe the target of the functor, we need to recall the
\emph{categorical delooping}, which associates to a monoid $A$ (or
more generally, a monoidal $n$-category), a category (or
($n+1$)-category in the general case) ${B} A$ with a
chosen ``base'' object, in which
\begin{itemize}
\item all objects are equivalent,
\item the endomorphism monoid (or monoidal $n$-category) of the base
  object is given an equivalence with $A$.
\end{itemize}

Note that, if ${\mathcal}{A}$ is a \emph{symmetric monoidal} $n$-category,
then ${B}{\mathcal}{A}$ is canonically a symmetric monoidal
($n+1$)-category (with unit the base object) since the functor
${B}$ preserves direct products.

Now the following gives an interpretation of a higher theory as a
functor of higher theories.

\begin{example}\label{ex:theory-as-functor}
Choose and fixed a system of colours up to dimension $n-1$, and denote
by ${\mathcal}{T}$ the terminal object among unenriched ($n+1$)-theories
extending this system of lower colours.
Explicitly, ${\mathcal}{T}$ is such that every collection of
$n$-multimaps in it is non-empty, and every groupoid of
($n+1$)-multimaps in it is contractible.

Then the structure on the chosen system of colours, of an $n$-theory
enriched in a symmetric monoidal category ${\mathcal}{A}$, is equivalent as
a datum to a functor ${\mathcal}{T}\to{\Theta}^{n+1}_0{B}^n{\mathcal}{A}$
(where ${B}^n$ indicates $n$-fold application of the delooping
construction ${B}$) of ($n+1$)-theories which is
{\textbf}{$n$-trapped} in the sense that it sends any object of ${\mathcal}{T}$
to the base object of ${B}^n{\mathcal}{A}$, and any $k$-multimap of
${\mathcal}{T}$ for $1\le k\le n-1$, to the identity $k$-morphism or the
base object of ${B}^{n-k}{\mathcal}{A}$.
\end{example}

Let us say that an ($n+1$)-theory ${\mathcal}{T}$ as in Example
\ref{ex:theory-as-functor} is terminal {\textbf}{on}
the chosen system of colours up to dimension $n-1$.
Considering ${\mathcal}{T}$ as a coloured variant of the terminal unenriched
uncoloured ($n+1$)-theory ${\boldsymbol{1}}^{n+1}_{\mathrm}{Com}$ (where ${\mathrm}{Com}=E_\infty$
denotes the commutative operad), one might say that an $n$-theory
enriched in ${\mathcal}{A}$ is an $n$-trapped functor
${\boldsymbol{1}}^{n+1}_{\mathrm}{Com}\to{\Theta}^{n+1}_0{B}^n{\mathcal}{A}$ \emph{with
  strata of colours} for an $n$-theory.

\begin{definition}\label{def:coloured-lax-theory}
For an integer $n\ge 0$, an {\textbf}{($n+1$)-tuply coloured lax
  $n$-theory} enriched in a symmetric monoidal $2$-category ${\mathcal}{A}$,
is an $n$-trapped lax functor
${\boldsymbol{1}}^{n+1}_{\mathrm}{Com}\to{\Theta}^{n+1}_0{B}^n{\mathcal}{A}$ with strata
of colours up to dimension $n$, namely, an $n$-trapped lax functor
$F\colon{\mathcal}{T}\to{\Theta}^{n+1}_0{B}^n{\mathcal}{A}$, where
${\mathcal}{T}$ is an unenriched ($n+1$)-theory, which is terminal on a
system of colours for an ($n+1$)-theory.

An ($n+1$)-tuply coloured lax $n$-theory enriched in ${\mathcal}{A}$,
defined by a lax functor $F$ as above, is said to be {\textbf}{trapped} if
$F$ sends $n$-multimaps of ${\mathcal}{T}$ to the unit object of ${\mathcal}{A}$.
\end{definition}

\begin{proposition}\label{prop:theory-as-theorization}
Let ${\mathcal}{A}$ be a symmetric monoidal category.
Then, for an integer $n\ge 1$, an $n$-theory enriched in ${\mathcal}{A}$ is
equivalent as a datum to a trapped $n$-tuply coloured lax
($n-1$)-theory enriched in ${B}{\mathcal}{A}$.
\end{proposition}

This is a consequence of Theorem \ref{thm:functor-of-theorization}
below, as will be seen in Section \ref{sec:delooping-comparison}.


\subsubsection{}
\label{sec:functor-of-theorization}

The following is a key fact on the relation between theorization and
categorification.

\begin{theorem}\label{thm:functor-of-theorization}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ and ${\mathcal}{V}$ be
categorified $n$-theories.
Then a functor ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$ of
uncategorified ($n+1$)-theories, is
equivalent as a datum to a lax functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$.
\end{theorem}

\begin{proof}
{\refstepcounter{proofsec}\noindent\textbf{\theproofsec.}~}
We first note that the form of datum for the action of a functor
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$ on the colours up to
dimension $n-1$, is identical to the form of datum for the action of a
lax functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$ on the colours up to the same
dimension.
Then for any fixed datum of this form, we would like to prove that the
categories (or $2$-categories) naturally formed respectively by the
structures on these same data, of functors (of ($n+1$)-theories), and
of lax functors (of categorified $n$-theories), are equivalent.

{\refstepcounter{proofsec}\noindent\textbf{\theproofsec.}~}
The structure of a categorified $n$-theory is given on the categories
of $n$-multimaps, by the (cohrently) associative composition
functors.
A lax functor $F\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$ extending the chosen action,
is then seen to be given by
\begin{enumerate}
\setcounter{enumi}{-1}
\item\label{item:action-on-n}
  the action of $F$ on the categories of $n$-multimaps through
  functors specified by the datum ${\check}{m}^F_1$, and
\item\label{item:compatibility-n-action-composition}
  the (lax) compatibility specified by the data $m^F_2$ and
  ${\check}{m}^F_k$ for $k\ge 3$, of the mentioned action with the
  associative composition functors for $n$-multimaps in ${\mathcal}{U}$ and
  in ${\mathcal}{V}$.
\end{enumerate}

{\refstepcounter{proofsec}\noindent\textbf{\theproofsec.}~}\label{step:lax-functor-to-functor}
Recall that we have obtained ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ by replacing the
composition functors of ${\mathcal}{U}$ by the
bimodules/distributors/profunctors represented by them, and similarly
for ${\mathcal}{V}$.

Given a datum as (\ref{item:action-on-n}) above for a lax functor $F$,
of an action on $n$-multimaps, a datum of compatibility as
(\ref{item:compatibility-n-action-composition}) above, of this action
with the composition functors for $n$-multimaps, can equivalently be
described as an action on the (associative) composition bimodules for
$n$-multimaps (which were represented by the composition functors) in
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ and in ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$.
Note that these bimodules (in ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ or in
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$) are formed by ($n+1$)-multimaps, and the
(coherent) associativity of the composition (for $n$-multimaps) can
equivalently be described as the (coherently associative) composition
operations for ($n+1$)-multimaps.

In this manner, we consider $F$ as a structure between
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ and ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$.

The difference of this structure between ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ and
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$, from a functor
$G\colon{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$ of
($n+1$)-theories, is that
\begin{itemize}
\item the action of $G$ on $n$-multimaps does not (explicitly) include
  the datum of functoriality included in ${\check}{m}^F_1$, and
\item the action of $G$ on ($n+1$)-multimaps (given by ${\check}{m}^G_1$)
  and its compatibility (given by ${\check}{m}^G_k$, $k\ge 2$) with the
  composition operations for ($n+1$)-multimaps in
  ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ and in ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$, do not
  explicitly include the data of compatibility with the bimodules
  structures, included in $m^F_2$ and ${\check}{m}^F_{\ge 3}$.
\end{itemize}

Never the less, we obtain a functor
${\Theta}_nF\colon{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$ by
forgetting these extra data (which will turn out in the next step to
have been actually redundant).

{\refstepcounter{proofsec}\noindent\textbf{\theproofsec.}~}\label{step:functor-to-lax-functor}
Conversely, suppose given a functor
$G\colon{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$ which extends the
chosen actions up to dimension $n-1$.
Then, from the discussions above, a lax functor
$H\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$ extending the same lower
actions, such that ${\Theta}_nH=G$, is constructed if we equip the
higher data for $G$ with the following.
\begin{itemize}
\item A functoriality in the $n$-multimap $x\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$,
  on the $n$-multimap $Gx\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{V}[Hu]$.
\item A compatibility of this functoriality with the data
  ${\check}{m}^G_i$, $i\ge 1$, of the action of $G$ (in a manner
  compatible with the (associative) composition operations for
  ($n+1$)-multimaps in ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ and in
  ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$) on ($n+1$)-multimaps.
\end{itemize}

In order to obtain a functoriality of the $n$-multimap $Gx$, one notes
that a map in the category ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$
is suitably `unary' ($n+1$)-multimaps in ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$.
The desired functoriality is given by the restriction of the
associative action of $G$ to unary ($n+1$)-multimaps in
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$.

A compatibility of this functoriality with the action of $G$ means
\begin{itemize}
\item a naturality of every instance of the map

$\coprod_{I^1_{i-1}}{({\phi^1}_{\rightarrow{{i-1}}})}_!I^0\to\coprod_{I^1_i}{({\phi^1}_{\rightarrow{{i}}})}_!I^0$,
which together form an $I^2_0$-nerve in ${\mathrm}{Fin}$.

Let us denote this nerve by $\int_{I^1}\phi^0$, and the
$[I^2_0]$-family of finite sets connected by it by $\int_{I^1}I^0$.
Then the datum $u^0_i$ of ($1''$) of ($3$) for Definition
\ref{def:tuply-coloured} in the case $m=n-1$, can be considered as a

\subsubsection{}

Suppose now given an $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{V}$.
Then we wish to construct a new $n$-tuply coloured ($n+1$)-theory
${\mathcal}{U}={\field{\deloop}}{\mathcal}{V}$ by precomposing the above constructions
to the data for ${\mathcal}{V}$.

The construction of ${\mathcal}{U}$ is as follows.
\begin{itemize}
\item[($1$)] Given a finite set $S$, we let
  ${\operatorname{Ob}}^\pi{\mathcal}{U}={\operatorname{Ob}}{\mathcal}{V}$, where $\pi$ denotes the unique
  map $S\to{*}$.
\item[($2$)] Given the arity of a $2$-multimap as in the preliminary
  construction above, if $n=0$, then we let
  $m^{\mathcal}{U}_1(\pi)\colon{\operatorname{Ob}}^{\phi^0}{\mathcal}{U}\to{\operatorname{Ob}}^{\pi_!\phi^0}{\mathcal}{U}$
  be the multiplication map
  $({\operatorname{Ob}}{\mathcal}{V})^{{\otimes}(\coprod_{I^1_0}I^0)}\to{\operatorname{Ob}}{\mathcal}{V}$.
  If $n\ge 1$, and further given a $\phi^0$-nerve $u^0_0$ of objects
  of ${\mathcal}{U}$ and an $I^0_0$-ary object $u^0_1$ as in ($2$) of
  Definition \ref{def:tuply-coloured} in the case $m=n-1$, then we let
  ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u^0]={\operatorname{Mul}}^{\pi'}_{\mathcal}{V}[u^0]$, where $\pi'$
  denotes the unique map $\coprod_{I^1_0}I^0\to{*}$, and $u^0$
  is considered as a ($\int_{I^1}I^0$)-family of objects in ${\mathcal}{V}$,
  by the preliminary construction above.
\end{itemize}

Next, if $n\ge 2$, suppose given an input datum for ($3$) for
Definition \ref{def:tuply-coloured} in the case $m=n-1$.
Then we can construct a set of data of the form required of an input
to ($2$) in Section \ref{sec:2} for ${\mathcal}{V}$, as follows.
If we define

in $u^n$, and
\item a compatibility of this naturality with the compatibility, given
  by ${\check}{m}^G_i$, $i\ge 2$, of these maps ${\check}{m}^G_1(\pi)$ with
  the composition operations in ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ and in
  ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$.
\end{itemize}
We note that the functoriality in $u^n$ of the target of
${\check}{m}^G_1(\pi)$ is the composite of the functoriality of
${\mathrm{Map}}_{{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\pi_!\phi^{n-1}}_{\mathcal}{V}[\pi_!Hu^{\le
    n-1}]}\bigl(m^{\mathcal}{V}_1(\pi)(-),-\bigr)$ in its variables, with the
functoriality of $G$.
Moreover, the compatibility of this functoriality with the composition
structures of ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ and of ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$,
is also induced by the same functoriality of $G$, from the
compatibility of the functoriality of
${\mathrm{Map}}_{{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\pi_!\phi^{n-1}}_{\mathcal}{V}[\pi_!v]}\bigl(m^{\mathcal}{V}_1(\pi)(-),-\bigr)$
with the composition operations.

Now, the functoriality, together with its compatibility with the
composition structure of ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$, of
${\mathrm{Map}}_{{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\pi_!\phi^{n-1}}_{\mathcal}{U}[\pi_!u^{\le
    n-1}]}\bigl(m^{\mathcal}{U}_1(\pi)(-),-\bigr)={\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}}\bigl[u^{\le
  n-1}\bigr]\bigl(-;-\bigr)$ can alternatively be considered as obtained
by suitably restricting the composition structure of
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$, and similarly for
${\mathrm{Map}}_{{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\pi_!\phi^{n-1}}_{\mathcal}{V}[\pi_!v]}\bigl(m^{\mathcal}{V}_1(\pi)(-),-\bigr)$.
Since the functoriality of $G$ on the category of $n$-multimaps is as
constructed above, we see that the compatibility of the action of $G$
on ($n+1$)-multimaps with the composition structures of
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$ and of
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$, also induces a desired datum.

{\refstepcounter{proofsec}\noindent\textbf{\theproofsec.}~}
We have thus constructed a desired lax functor
$H\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$ naturally from $G$.
In order to complete the proof, we would like to verify in the case
$G={\Theta}_nF$ for a lax functor $F\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$, that
the lax functor ``$H$'' constructed from $G$ will be naturally
equivalent to $F$.
For this, it suffices to observe that the set of data which we have
added to the datum of $G$ to construct $H$ in the step
\ref{step:functor-to-lax-functor}, is naturally equivalent to the
set of data which was ``forgotten'' in the construction
$F\mapsto{\Theta}_nF$ in the step
\ref{step:lax-functor-to-functor}, but this is clear.
\end{proof}

\begin{remark}\label{rem:lax-functor-general}
We have thus described for the ($n+1$)-theory
${\mathcal}{W}={\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{V}$, a functor
$G\colon{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{W}$ as a lax functor
${\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$.
Similar arguments lead to a description of $G$ for an arbitrary
($n+1$)-theory ${\mathcal}{W}$, as a structure generalizing a lax functor
${\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$.
One might call this structure between ${\mathcal}{U}$ and ${\mathcal}{W}$ a
{\textbf}{functor} ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{W}$.
Thus, a functor ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{W}$ will be equivalent as
a datum to a functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{W}$.
\end{remark}


\subsubsection{}

Note that $n$-theories enriched in groupoids are also among
$n$-theories enriched in categories since a groupoid can be considered
as a category in which every morphism is invertible.
This kind of unenriched categorified $n$-theories is special as a
target of a
functor in that there is no difference between an ordinary functor and
a lax functor from an unenriched categorified $n$-theory to such a
target.

\begin{corollary}\label{cor:forget-to-theorization}
The functor ${\Theta}_n$ is fully faithful on $n$-theories enriched
in groupoids.
\end{corollary}



{\oldsubsection{{Delooping a higher theory}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}
\label{sec:delooping}

\subsubsection{}

There is a construction, which we shall call the \emph{delooping}, of
a symmetric $n$-tuply coloured ($n+1$)-theory from a symmetric
$n$-theory.
We shall describe this construction, and then discuss its relation to
the ``categorical'' delooping.

An ($n+1$)-theory which is obtained through this construction normally
fails to be representable by an $n$-theory.
Delooped theories will be conveniently used throughout this work as
the targets of (possibly ``coloured'') functors of higher theories.


\subsubsection{}

The delooping construction relies on the following construction.

Suppose first that the arity of a $2$-multimap is specified as in
($1'$) and ($0'$) of ($2$) in Section \ref{sec:2}.
Then since our notation \ref{notation:skip-0} chooses an embedding
$I^1_0{\hookrightarrow}[I^1_0]$, it makes sense to take the coproduct
$\coprod_{I^1_0}I^0$.
Then note that a $\phi^0$-nerve $u^0_0$ as in ($2$) of Definition
\ref{def:tuply-coloured} in the case $m-n=1$, of objects of an
($n-1$)-tuply coloured $n$-theory, can be considered as a
($\coprod_{I^1_0}I^0$)-family, while an ($I^0_0$-ary) object $u^0_1$
is a ($\coprod_{I^1_1}\pi_!I^0$)-family, where $I^1_1:=\{1\}$.

Suppose next given the arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$ of a $3$-multimap in a
symmetric higher theory.
Then for every $i\in I^2_0$ and $j\in I^1_i$, we have a map
$\coprod_{(\phi^1_i)^{-1}j}{({\phi^1}_{\rightarrow{{i-1}}})}_!I^0\to
I^0_{[{\phi^1}_{\rightarrow{{i}}}](j)}$ whose component for
$k\in(\phi^1_i)^{-1}j$ is the composite
