Using this, we let ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]={\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{V}[u]$.

If $n\ge 1$, we let $m^{\mathcal}{U}_\nu(\pi)=m^{\mathcal}{V}_\nu(\pi)$ for
$\nu=1$ or $2$, in the similar manner, where the form of $u$ is
different in the
case $n=1$, and we are not given $u$ in the case $n=0$.

For every $k\ge 4$, the datum ($k$) for ${\mathcal}{U}$ is constructed in
the similar manner from the datum ($k-1$) for ${\mathcal}{V}$.


\subsubsection{}

It is clear that if ${\mathcal}{U}$ is an $m$-tuply coloured $n$-theory,
then its deloop ${\field{\deloop}}{\mathcal}{U}$ is obtained as an $m$-tuply coloured
($n+1$)-theory.


\subsubsection{}
\label{sec:delooping-comparison}

Our delooping construction for higher theories relates to the
categorical delooping recalled in Section \ref{sec:functor} for the
formulation of Example \ref{ex:theory-as-functor}.
Let us describe one relation which will be convenient for us.

Specifically, let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{A}$ be a symmetric
monoidal $n$-category.
Then for an integer $m$ such that $0\le m\le n$, we would like to
relate the ($m+1$)-theory ${\field{\deloop}}{\Theta}^m_0{\mathcal}{A}$ to the
($m+1$)-theory ${\Theta}^{m+1}_0{B}{\mathcal}{A}$, both enriched in
($n-m$)-categories.

An obvious issue for this is that ${\Theta}^{m+1}_0{B}{\mathcal}{A}$
is fully coloured whereas ${\field{\deloop}}{\Theta}^m_0{\mathcal}{A}$ is only
$m$-tuply coloured.
However, if we restrict the data for
${\Theta}^{m+1}_0{B}{\mathcal}{A}$ so the only object we consider is
the base object of ${B}{\mathcal}{A}$, then the rest of the data for
${\Theta}^{m+1}_0{B}{\mathcal}{A}$ is of the form of datum for an
$m$-tuply coloured ($m+1$)-theory enriched in ($n-m$)-categories.

\begin{proposition}\label{prop:deloop-comparison}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{A}$ be a symmetric monoidal
$n$-category.
Then for every integer $m$ such that $0\le m\le n$,
${\field{\deloop}}{\Theta}^m_0{\mathcal}{A}$ is equivalent to the
($n-m$)-categorified $m$-tuply coloured ($m+1$)-theory obtained as
above from ${\Theta}^{m+1}_0{B}{\mathcal}{A}$ by restricting objects
to just the base object of ${B}{\mathcal}{A}$.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
The case $m=0$ is immediate from the constructions, and the general
case follows by induction, from Lemma
\ref{lem:deloop-forget-commutation} below.
\end{proof}

The lemma is as follows, and follows immediately from the
definitions.

\begin{lemma}\label{lem:deloop-forget-commutation}
For an arbitrary times categorified $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{U}$, we have

\begin{proof}[Proof of Proposition \ref{prop:theory-as-theorization}]
Definition \ref{def:coloured-lax-theory} and Proposition
\ref{prop:deloop-comparison} implies that a trapped $n$-tuply coloured
lax ($n-1$)-theory enriched in ${B}{\mathcal}{A}$ is equivalent as a
datum
to a lax functor ${\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}\to{\field{\deloop}}^n{\mathcal}{A}$ with strata of
colours up to dimension $n-1$.
Example \ref{ex:theory-as-functor} and Proposition
\ref{prop:deloop-comparison} implies that an $n$-theory enriched in
${\mathcal}{A}$ is equivalent as a datum to a functor
${\boldsymbol{1}}^{n+1}_{\mathrm}{Com}\to{\Theta}_n{\field{\deloop}}^n{\mathcal}{A}$ with
strata of colours up to dimension $n-1$.

Let ${\mathcal}{T}$ be an unenriched $n$-theory which is terminal on a
system of colours up to dimension $n-1$.
Then the ($n+1$)-theory ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{T}$ (where we have
considered ${\mathcal}{T}$ as trivially categorified) is terminal on the
same system of colours, so the result follows immediately from the
equivalence of Theorem \ref{thm:functor-of-theorization}.
\end{proof}

We also obtain the following from Proposition
\ref{prop:deloop-comparison}.

\begin{corollary}\label{cor:deloop-comparison-functor}
Let ${\mathcal}{A}$ be a symmetric monoidal category.
Then for an unenriched ($n+1$)-theory ${\mathcal}{U}$, an $n$-trapped
functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\Theta}^{n+1}_0{B}^n{\mathcal}{A}$ is equivalent
as a datum to a functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\field{\deloop}}^n{\Theta}_0{\mathcal}{A}$.
\end{corollary}

\begin{definition}\label{def:theory-enriched-in-multicategory}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer.
Then an {\textbf}{$n$-theory enriched in a multicategory ${\mathcal}{M}$}, is a
functor ${\boldsymbol{1}}^{n+1}_{\mathrm}{Com}\to{\field{\deloop}}^n{\mathcal}{M}$ with strata of colours for an
$n$-theory.
\end{definition}

Generalizing Proposition \ref{prop:theory-as-theorization}, this is
equivalent as a datum to a functor ${\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}\to{\field{\deloop}}^n{\mathcal}{M}$
(Remark \ref{rem:lax-functor-general}) with strata of colours up to
dimension $n-1$ for a higher theory.



{\oldsection{{Graded higher theories}}\setcounter{subsection}{-1}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}\setcounter{equation}{-1}}
\label{sec:grading}

{\oldsubsection{{Introduction}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}

The purpose of this section is to discuss grading of higher theory by
a higher theory (enriched in groupoids).
It turns out that this notion naturally arises by considering
theorization of algebra over a higher theory.
We shall also see interrelations between the notions, of ``graded''
lower theory over a higher theory, and of \emph{iterated monoid},
i.e., monoid (i.e., algebra in the 
category of groupoids) over a monoid over ...~over a monoid, over a
higher theory enriched in groupoids.
Some results obtained along the way will be basic.



{\oldsubsection{{Algebras over a higher theory}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}
\label{sec:monoid-theorization}

\subsubsection{}

We have sought for the notion of $n$-theory as an interesting $n$-th
theorization of the notion of commutative algebra.
As have been discussed in Section \ref{sec:introduction}, what we
wished to get from this was for each $n$-theory to govern
\emph{algebras} over it, which naturally generalize ($n-1$)-theories.

\begin{definition}\label{def:algebra}
Let $n\ge 2$ be an integer, and let ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an unenriched
$n$-theory.
Then a {\textbf}{${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra} ${\mathcal}{X}$ enriched in a multicategory
${\mathcal}{M}$ consists of data of the forms specified below as ($0$) and
($1$) (or just ($0$) if $n=2$), ``($k$)'' for every integer $k$ such
that $2\le k\le n-2$, ($n-1$), ($n$) and ($\infty$).
\end{definition}

Let us specify the forms of data for Definition.

\begin{remark}\label{rem:extend-to-non-elemental}
As before, we implicitly extend each datum form specified below for a
non-elemental input datum before proceeding to specifying the next datum
form, in a more or less similar manner as before.
\end{remark}

\begin{itemize}
\item[($0$)](\emph{Object}.)
  For every object $u$ of ${\mathcal}{U}$, a collection ${\operatorname{Ob}}_u{\mathcal}{X}$,
  whose member
  will be called an {\textbf}{object} of ${\mathcal}{X}$ of {\textbf}{degree} $u$.
\item[($1$)](\emph{Multimap}, in the case $n\ge 3$.)
  Suppose given ($0'$) and ($0''$) of ($1$) in Section \ref{sec:1},
  and
  \begin{itemize}
  \item[($0^\circ$)] an $S$-family $x_0$ of objects of ${\mathcal}{X}$ of
    degree $u_0$ (namely, $x_{0s}\in{\operatorname{Ob}}_{u_{0s}}{\mathcal}{X}$ for every
    $s\in S$), and an object $x_1$ of degree $u_1$.
  \end{itemize}
  Then for every multimap $v\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$, a collection
  ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}(x_0;x_1)$ or ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}[x]$
  for short, whose member will be called an ($S$-ary)
  ({\textbf}{$1$-}){\textbf}{multimap} $x_0\to x_1$ in ${\mathcal}{X}$ of
  {\textbf}{degree} $v$.
\item[($k$)](\emph{$k$-multimap}, inductively for $2\le k\le n-2$.)
  Suppose given (\ref{item:monoid-k-1}), ($0^\circ$),
  (\ref{item:monoid-k-5}), ($k-2^\circ$) (or just
  (\ref{item:monoid-k-1}), ``($0^\circ$)'' if $k=2$), and
  ($k-1^\circ$) below:
  \begin{enumerate}
  \item\label{item:monoid-k-1}
    the type $u$ of a $k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{U}$ of arity given as
    $(I;\pi,\phi)$.
  \item[($0^\circ$)] an $I^0$-family $x^0$ of objects of ${\mathcal}{X}$, of
    degree $u^0$, namely, $x^0=(x^0_i)_{i\in[I^1_0]}$, where
    $x^0_i$ is an $I^0_i$-family of objects of ${\mathcal}{X}$, of degree
    $u^0_i$,
  \item\label{item:monoid-k-5} if $k\ge 4$, then ($1^\circ$) through
    ($k-3^\circ$) of ($k-1$) here,
  \item[($k-2^\circ$)](in the case $k\ge 3$)
    an $I^{k-2}$-family $x^{k-2}=(x^{k-2}_i)_{i\in[I^{k-1}_0]}$ of
    ($k-2$)-multimaps in ${\mathcal}{X}$, where $x^{k-2}_i$ is an
    ${{\phi^{k-2}}_{\rightarrow{{i}}}}_!\phi^{k-3}$-nerve of ($k-2$)-multimaps
    in ${\mathcal}{X}$, connecting ${{\phi^{k-2}}_{\rightarrow{{i}}}}_!x^{k-3}$ of
    degree $u^{k-2}_i$,
  \item[($k-1^\circ$)]
    \begin{itemize}
    \item a $\phi^{k-2}$-nerve $x^{k-1}_0$ of ($k-1$)-multimaps
      connecting $x^{k-2}$, of degree $u^{k-1}_0$ in ${\mathcal}{X}$,
      namely,
      $x^{k-1}_{0i}\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\phi^{k-2}_i}_{u^{k-1}_{0i}}[x^{\le
        k-2}{\mathclose{|}_{{i}}}]$ for every $i\in I^{k-1}_0$,
    \item $x^{k-1}_1\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\pi_!\phi^{k-2}}_{u^{k-1}_1}[\pi_!x^{\le k-2}]$.
    \end{itemize}
  \end{enumerate}
  Then for every $k$-multimap $v\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$, a collection
  ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}[x^{\le k-2}](x^{k-1}_0;x^{k-1}_1)$ or
  ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}[x]$ for
  short, whose member will be called a {\textbf}{$k$-multimap}
  $x^{k-1}_0\to x^{k-1}_1$ in ${\mathcal}{X}$ of {\textbf}{degree} $v$.
\end{itemize}

\begin{definition}
We refer to a datum of the form $x=(x^\nu)_{0\le\nu\le k-1}$ specified
by
($0^\circ$) through ($k-1^\circ$) above (by induction in $k$), as the
{\textbf}{type of a $k$-multimap} in ${\mathcal}{X}$ of {\textbf}{arity}
$(I;\pi,\phi)$ and of {\textbf}{degree} $u$.
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}
Even though we have not yet specified the form of the rest of data
for ${\mathcal}{X}$, note that the notion of the type of a
$k$-multimap ``in ${\mathcal}{X}$'' makes sense as soon as data of the forms
($0$) through ($k-1$) are given ``for ${\mathcal}{X}$''.
\end{remark}

\begin{itemize}
\item[($n-1$)](The object ``formed by \emph{($n-1$)-multimaps}''.)
  Suppose given the type $u$ of an ($n-1$)-multimap in ${\mathcal}{U}$ of
  arity given as $(I;\pi,\phi)$, and the type $x$ of an
  ($n-1$)-multimap in ${\mathcal}{X}$ of the same arity of degree $u$,
  namely, a set of data similar to ($0^\circ$) through ($k-1^\circ$),
  of ``($k$)'' above, but with $k$ substituted by $n-1$, so these will
  be ($0^\circ$) through ($n-2^\circ$) here.
  Then for every ($n-1$)-multimap $v\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$, an object
  ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}[x^{\le n-3}](x^{n-2}_0;x^{n-2}_1)$ of
  ${\mathcal}{M}$, or ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}[x]$ for short.
  In the case where ${\mathcal}{M}$ is ${\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$ or some other
  multicategory so that
  ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}[x]$ can have its objects, then those objects
  will be called {\textbf}{($n-1$)-multimaps} $x^{n-2}_0\to x^{n-2}_1$ in
  ${\mathcal}{X}$ of {\textbf}{degree} $v$.
  For a general ${\mathcal}{M}$, we shall call ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}[x]$ the
  object ``of \emph{($n-1$)-multimaps} in ${\mathcal}{X}$ of \emph{degree}
  $v$''.

\item[($n$)](\emph{Action} of the $n$-multimaps of ${\mathcal}{U}$.)
  Suppose given
  \begin{itemize}
  \item the type $u$ of an $n$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{U}$ of arity given as
    $(I;\pi,\phi)$,
  \item ($0^\circ$) through ($n-3^\circ$) of ($n-1$) above,
  \item ($k-2^\circ$) of ``($k$)'' above, but with $k$ substituted by
    $n$, so this will be  ($n-2^\circ$) here.
  \end{itemize}

\subsubsection{}

It is clear that if ${\mathcal}{U}$ is an $m$-tuply coloured $n$-theory,
then its deloop ${\field{\deloop}}{\mathcal}{U}$ is obtained as an $m$-tuply coloured
($n+1$)-theory.


\subsubsection{}
\label{sec:delooping-comparison}

Our delooping construction for higher theories relates to the
categorical delooping recalled in Section \ref{sec:functor} for the
formulation of Example \ref{ex:theory-as-functor}.
Let us describe one relation which will be convenient for us.

Specifically, let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{A}$ be a symmetric
monoidal $n$-category.
Then for an integer $m$ such that $0\le m\le n$, we would like to
relate the ($m+1$)-theory ${\field{\deloop}}{\Theta}^m_0{\mathcal}{A}$ to the
($m+1$)-theory ${\Theta}^{m+1}_0{B}{\mathcal}{A}$, both enriched in
($n-m$)-categories.

An obvious issue for this is that ${\Theta}^{m+1}_0{B}{\mathcal}{A}$
is fully coloured whereas ${\field{\deloop}}{\Theta}^m_0{\mathcal}{A}$ is only
$m$-tuply coloured.
However, if we restrict the data for
${\Theta}^{m+1}_0{B}{\mathcal}{A}$ so the only object we consider is
the base object of ${B}{\mathcal}{A}$, then the rest of the data for
${\Theta}^{m+1}_0{B}{\mathcal}{A}$ is of the form of datum for an
$m$-tuply coloured ($m+1$)-theory enriched in ($n-m$)-categories.

\begin{proposition}\label{prop:deloop-comparison}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{A}$ be a symmetric monoidal
$n$-category.
Then for every integer $m$ such that $0\le m\le n$,
${\field{\deloop}}{\Theta}^m_0{\mathcal}{A}$ is equivalent to the
($n-m$)-categorified $m$-tuply coloured ($m+1$)-theory obtained as
above from ${\Theta}^{m+1}_0{B}{\mathcal}{A}$ by restricting objects
to just the base object of ${B}{\mathcal}{A}$.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
The case $m=0$ is immediate from the constructions, and the general
case follows by induction, from Lemma
\ref{lem:deloop-forget-commutation} below.
\end{proof}

The lemma is as follows, and follows immediately from the
definitions.

\begin{lemma}\label{lem:deloop-forget-commutation}
For an arbitrary times categorified $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{U}$, we have

\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}[Proof of Proposition \ref{prop:theory-as-theorization}]
Definition \ref{def:coloured-lax-theory} and Proposition
\ref{prop:deloop-comparison} implies that a trapped $n$-tuply coloured
lax ($n-1$)-theory enriched in ${B}{\mathcal}{A}$ is equivalent as a
datum
to a lax functor ${\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}\to{\field{\deloop}}^n{\mathcal}{A}$ with strata of
colours up to dimension $n-1$.
Example \ref{ex:theory-as-functor} and Proposition
\ref{prop:deloop-comparison} implies that an $n$-theory enriched in
${\mathcal}{A}$ is equivalent as a datum to a functor
${\boldsymbol{1}}^{n+1}_{\mathrm}{Com}\to{\Theta}_n{\field{\deloop}}^n{\mathcal}{A}$ with
strata of colours up to dimension $n-1$.

Let ${\mathcal}{T}$ be an unenriched $n$-theory which is terminal on a
system of colours up to dimension $n-1$.
Then the ($n+1$)-theory ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{T}$ (where we have
considered ${\mathcal}{T}$ as trivially categorified) is terminal on the
same system of colours, so the result follows immediately from the
equivalence of Theorem \ref{thm:functor-of-theorization}.
\end{proof}

We also obtain the following from Proposition
\ref{prop:deloop-comparison}.

\begin{corollary}\label{cor:deloop-comparison-functor}
Let ${\mathcal}{A}$ be a symmetric monoidal category.
Then for an unenriched ($n+1$)-theory ${\mathcal}{U}$, an $n$-trapped
functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\Theta}^{n+1}_0{B}^n{\mathcal}{A}$ is equivalent
as a datum to a functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\field{\deloop}}^n{\Theta}_0{\mathcal}{A}$.
\end{corollary}

\begin{definition}\label{def:theory-enriched-in-multicategory}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer.
Then an {\textbf}{$n$-theory enriched in a multicategory ${\mathcal}{M}$}, is a
functor ${\boldsymbol{1}}^{n+1}_{\mathrm}{Com}\to{\field{\deloop}}^n{\mathcal}{M}$ with strata of colours for an
$n$-theory.
\end{definition}

Generalizing Proposition \ref{prop:theory-as-theorization}, this is
equivalent as a datum to a functor ${\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}\to{\field{\deloop}}^n{\mathcal}{M}$
(Remark \ref{rem:lax-functor-general}) with strata of colours up to
dimension $n-1$ for a higher theory.



{\oldsection{{Graded higher theories}}\setcounter{subsection}{-1}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}\setcounter{equation}{-1}}
\label{sec:grading}

{\oldsubsection{{Introduction}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}

The purpose of this section is to discuss grading of higher theory by
a higher theory (enriched in groupoids).
It turns out that this notion naturally arises by considering
theorization of algebra over a higher theory.
We shall also see interrelations between the notions, of ``graded''
lower theory over a higher theory, and of \emph{iterated monoid},
i.e., monoid (i.e., algebra in the 
category of groupoids) over a monoid over ...~over a monoid, over a
higher theory enriched in groupoids.
Some results obtained along the way will be basic.



{\oldsubsection{{Algebras over a higher theory}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}
\label{sec:monoid-theorization}

\subsubsection{}

We have sought for the notion of $n$-theory as an interesting $n$-th
theorization of the notion of commutative algebra.
As have been discussed in Section \ref{sec:introduction}, what we
wished to get from this was for each $n$-theory to govern
\emph{algebras} over it, which naturally generalize ($n-1$)-theories.

\begin{definition}\label{def:algebra}
Let $n\ge 2$ be an integer, and let ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an unenriched
$n$-theory.
Then a {\textbf}{${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra} ${\mathcal}{X}$ enriched in a multicategory
${\mathcal}{M}$ consists of data of the forms specified below as ($0$) and
($1$) (or just ($0$) if $n=2$), ``($k$)'' for every integer $k$ such
that $2\le k\le n-2$, ($n-1$), ($n$) and ($\infty$).
\end{definition}

Let us specify the forms of data for Definition.

\begin{remark}\label{rem:extend-to-non-elemental}
As before, we implicitly extend each datum form specified below for a
non-elemental input datum before proceeding to specifying the next datum
form, in a more or less similar manner as before.
\end{remark}

\begin{itemize}
\item[($0$)](\emph{Object}.)
  For every object $u$ of ${\mathcal}{U}$, a collection ${\operatorname{Ob}}_u{\mathcal}{X}$,
  whose member
  will be called an {\textbf}{object} of ${\mathcal}{X}$ of {\textbf}{degree} $u$.
\item[($1$)](\emph{Multimap}, in the case $n\ge 3$.)
  Suppose given ($0'$) and ($0''$) of ($1$) in Section \ref{sec:1},

  \begin{itemize}
  \item[($0^\circ$)] an $S$-family $x_0$ of objects of ${\mathcal}{X}$ of
    degree $u_0$ (namely, $x_{0s}\in{\operatorname{Ob}}_{u_{0s}}{\mathcal}{X}$ for every
    $s\in S$), and an object $x_1$ of degree $u_1$.
  \end{itemize}
  Then for every multimap $v\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$, a collection

  for short, whose member will be called an ($S$-ary)
  ({\textbf}{$1$-}){\textbf}{multimap} $x_0\to x_1$ in ${\mathcal}{X}$ of

\item[($k$)](\emph{$k$-multimap}, inductively for $2\le k\le n-2$.)
  Suppose given (\ref{item:monoid-k-1}), ($0^\circ$),
  (\ref{item:monoid-k-5}), ($k-2^\circ$) (or just
  (\ref{item:monoid-k-1}), ``($0^\circ$)'' if $k=2$), and
  ($k-1^\circ$) below:
  \begin{enumerate}
  \item\label{item:monoid-k-1}

  \item[($0^\circ$)] an $I^0$-family $x^0$ of objects of ${\mathcal}{X}$, of

    in ${\mathcal}{X}$, connecting ${{\phi^{k-2}}_{\rightarrow{{i}}}}_!x^{k-3}$ of

    \item a $\phi^{k-2}$-nerve $x^{k-1}_0$ of ($k-1$)-multimaps
      connecting $x^{k-2}$, of degree $u^{k-1}_0$ in ${\mathcal}{X}$,

      $x^{k-1}_{0i}\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\phi^{k-2}_i}_{u^{k-1}_{0i}}[x^{\le

  \end{enumerate}
  Then for every $k$-multimap $v\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$, a collection
  ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}[x^{\le k-2}](x^{k-1}_0;x^{k-1}_1)$ or

  short, whose member will be called a {\textbf}{$k$-multimap}
  $x^{k-1}_0\to x^{k-1}_1$ in ${\mathcal}{X}$ of {\textbf}{degree} $v$.
\end{itemize}

\begin{definition}
We refer to a datum of the form $x=(x^\nu)_{0\le\nu\le k-1}$ specified
by
($0^\circ$) through ($k-1^\circ$) above (by induction in $k$), as the
{\textbf}{type of a $k$-multimap} in ${\mathcal}{X}$ of {\textbf}{arity}

\end{definition}

\begin{remark}
Even though we have not yet specified the form of the rest of data
for ${\mathcal}{X}$, note that the notion of the type of a
$k$-multimap ``in ${\mathcal}{X}$'' makes sense as soon as data of the forms

\begin{definition}
We refer to a datum of the form $x=(x^\nu)_{0\le\nu\le n-2}$ specified
by ($0^\circ$) through ($n-2^\circ$) above, as the {\textbf}{type of a

of {\textbf}{degree} $u^{\le n-2}$.
\end{definition}

\begin{itemize}
\item[($\infty$)] A datum of (coherent) associativity for the action
  of $n$-multimaps, similar to that for a functor (Definition
  \ref{def:functor}).
\end{itemize}

This completes Definition \ref{def:algebra}.


\subsubsection{}

Similarly, one can define the notion of algebra over a less coloured
$n$-theory.
See Section \ref{sec:stratum-for-colour}.

\begin{example}
A ${\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$-algebra enriched in a symmetric monoidal category
${\mathcal}{A}$, i.e., in the multicategory ${\Theta}_0{\mathcal}{A}$, is
equivalent as a datum to an ($n-1$)-theory enriched in ${\mathcal}{A}$.
\end{example}

It follows from Example \ref{ex:theory-as-functor} and Corollary
\ref{cor:deloop-comparison-functor}, that a ${\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$-algebra
enriched in the multicategory ${\mathcal}{M}={\Theta}_0{\mathcal}{A}$, is a
coloured functor ${\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}\to{\field{\deloop}}^{n-1}{\mathcal}{M}$, and this is
true in fact, for every multicategory ${\mathcal}{M}$.
This can further be generalized over an arbitrary $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{U}$
after we theorize the notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra, which we shall do
next.



{\oldsubsection{{Iterated theorizations of algebra}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}
\label{sec:iterate-theorize-algebra}

\subsubsection{}

We would like to theorize the notion of algebra.
Let us first relax the notion.

\begin{definition}\label{def:lax-monoid}
Let $n\ge 2$ be an integer, and let ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an unenriched
$n$-theory.
Then a {\textbf}{lax ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra} ${\mathcal}{X}$ enriched in a
categorified multicategory ${\mathcal}{M}$ consists of data of the forms
($0$) through ($n$), specified above for Definition \ref{def:algebra}
for the same value of ``$n$'', and a datum of coherent lax
associativity
for the action of $n$-multimaps, similar to that for a lax functor
(Definition \ref{def:lax-functor}).
\end{definition}

This essentially contains at least the unenriched version of a
virtualization of the notion of op-lax categorified ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra,
namely, a \emph{theorization} of the notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra.
We shall write down an enriched version of the definition explicitly,
in a form which will be convenient shortly.
(The notion will be generalized in Section \ref{sec:enrichment}.)
A natural name for the kind of thing will turn out to be ``graded
$n$-theory''.

\begin{definition}\label{def:graded}
Let $n\ge 1$ be an integer, and let ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory
enriched in groupoids.
Then a {\textbf}{${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory} ${\mathcal}{X}$ enriched in a
multicategory ${\mathcal}{M}$
consists of data of the forms specified below as ($0$) and ($1$)
(or just ($0$) if $n=2$), ``($k$)'' for every integer $k$ such that
$2\le k\le n-2$, ($n-1$), ($n$), ($n+1$), and ($\infty$).
\end{definition}

The forms of data are as follows.
Remark \ref{rem:extend-to-non-elemental} applies here again.

\begin{itemize}
\item[($0$)](Object.)
  For every object $u$ of ${\mathcal}{U}$, a collection ${\operatorname{Ob}}_u{\mathcal}{X}$,
  whose member
  will be called an {\textbf}{object} of ${\mathcal}{X}$ of {\textbf}{degree} $u$.
\item[($1$)](Multimap, in the case $n\ge 2$.)
  Suppose given ($0'$) and ($0''$) of ($1$) in Section \ref{sec:1},
  and
  \begin{itemize}
  \item[($0^\circ$)] an $S$-family $x_0$ of objects of ${\mathcal}{X}$ of
    degree $u_0$, and an object $x_1$ of degree $u_1$.
  \end{itemize}
  Then for every multimap $v\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$, a collection
  ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}(x_0;x_1)$ or ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}[x]$
  for short, whose member will be called an ($S$-ary)
  ({\textbf}{$1$-}){\textbf}{multimap} $x_0\to x_1$ in ${\mathcal}{X}$ of
  {\textbf}{degree} $v$.
\item[($k$)]($k$-multimap, inductively for $2\le k\le n-1$.)
  Suppose given the type $u$ of a $k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{U}$ of arity
  given as $(I;\pi,\phi)$, and the type $x$ of a $k$-multimap
  in ${\mathcal}{X}$ of the same arity of degree $u$, namely, ($0^\circ$),
  (\ref{item:graded-k-5}), ($k-2^\circ$) (or just ``($0^\circ$)'' if
  $k=2$), and ($k-1^\circ$) below:
  \begin{enumerate}
  \addtocounter{enumi}{1}
  \item[($0^\circ$)] an $I^0$-family $x^0$ of objects of
    ${\mathcal}{X}$, of degree $u^0$, namely, $x^0_i\in{\operatorname{Ob}}_{u^0_i}{\mathcal}{X}$
    for every $i\in[I^1_0]$,
  \item\label{item:graded-k-5} if $k\ge 4$, then ($1^\circ$) through
    ($k-3^\circ$) of ($k-1$) here,
  \item[($k-2^\circ$)](in the case $k\ge 3$)
    an $I^{k-2}$-family $x^{k-2}=(x^{k-2}_i)_{i\in[I^{k-1}_0]}$, where
    $x^{k-2}_i$ is an ${{\phi^{k-2}}_{\rightarrow{{i}}}}_!\phi^{k-3}$-nerve of
    ($k-2$)-multimaps connecting ${{\phi^{k-2}}_{\rightarrow{{i}}}}_!x^{k-3}$
    in ${\mathcal}{X}$, of degree $u^{k-2}_i$,
  \item[($k-1^\circ$)] a $\phi^{k-2}$-nerve $x^{k-1}_0$ of
    ($k-1$)-multimaps connecting $x^{k-2}$, of degree $u^{k-1}_0$ in
    ${\mathcal}{X}$, and
    $x^{k-1}_1\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\pi_!\phi^{k-2}}_{u^{k-1}_1}[\pi_!x^{\le
      k-2}]$.
  \end{enumerate}
  Then for every $k$-multimap $v\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$, a collection
  ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}[x^{\le k-2}](x^{k-1}_0;x^{k-1}_1)$ or
  ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}[x]$ for
  short, whose member will be called a {\textbf}{$k$-multimap}
  $x^{k-1}_0\to x^{k-1}_1$ in ${\mathcal}{X}$ of {\textbf}{degree} $v$.
\item[($n$)](Action of the $n$-multimaps of ${\mathcal}{U}$.)
  Suppose given the type $x$ of an $n$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{X}$ of
  arity and degree given respectively as $(I;\pi,\phi)$ and $u$.
  Then a functor (to the underlying category of ${\mathcal}{M}$)

See Section \ref{sec:stratum-for-colour}.

\begin{example}
A ${\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$-algebra enriched in a symmetric monoidal category
${\mathcal}{A}$, i.e., in the multicategory ${\Theta}_0{\mathcal}{A}$, is
equivalent as a datum to an ($n-1$)-theory enriched in ${\mathcal}{A}$.

This can further be generalized over an arbitrary $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{U}$

\label{sec:iterate-theorize-algebra}

\begin{definition}\label{def:graded}
Let $n\ge 1$ be an integer, and let ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory

Then a {\textbf}{${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory} ${\mathcal}{X}$ enriched in a

(or just ($0$) if $n=2$), ``($k$)'' for every integer $k$ such that
$2\le k\le n-2$, ($n-1$), ($n$), ($n+1$), and ($\infty$).
\end{definition}

The forms of data are as follows.
Remark \ref{rem:extend-to-non-elemental} applies here again.

\begin{itemize}
\item[($0$)](Object.)
  For every object $u$ of ${\mathcal}{U}$, a collection ${\operatorname{Ob}}_u{\mathcal}{X}$,
  whose member
  will be called an {\textbf}{object} of ${\mathcal}{X}$ of {\textbf}{degree} $u$.
\item[($1$)](Multimap, in the case $n\ge 2$.)
  Suppose given ($0'$) and ($0''$) of ($1$) in Section \ref{sec:1},

  \item[($0^\circ$)] an $S$-family $x_0$ of objects of ${\mathcal}{X}$ of

  Then for every multimap $v\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$, a collection
  ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}(x_0;x_1)$ or ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}[x]$

  ({\textbf}{$1$-}){\textbf}{multimap} $x_0\to x_1$ in ${\mathcal}{X}$ of

\item[($k$)]($k$-multimap, inductively for $2\le k\le n-1$.)
  Suppose given the type $u$ of a $k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{U}$ of arity
  given as $(I;\pi,\phi)$, and the type $x$ of a $k$-multimap
  in ${\mathcal}{X}$ of the same arity of degree $u$, namely, ($0^\circ$),

  \begin{enumerate}

  \item[($0^\circ$)] an $I^0$-family $x^0$ of objects of
    ${\mathcal}{X}$, of degree $u^0$, namely, $x^0_i\in{\operatorname{Ob}}_{u^0_i}{\mathcal}{X}$

  \item\label{item:graded-k-5} if $k\ge 4$, then ($1^\circ$) through

  \item[($k-2^\circ$)](in the case $k\ge 3$)
    an $I^{k-2}$-family $x^{k-2}=(x^{k-2}_i)_{i\in[I^{k-1}_0]}$, where

  For a general ${\mathcal}{M}$, we shall call ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}[x]$ the

\item[($n+1$)](Associativity map.)

    ($k-2^\circ$) of ``($k$)'' above, but with $k$ substituted by
    $n+1$, so this will be ($0^\circ$) through ($n-1^\circ$) here.
  \end{itemize}
  Then a multimap

\subsubsection{}

Let us consider the unenriched case where
${\mathcal}{M}={\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$.

Note that in this case, $M_1(\pi)[x]$ above can be identified with the

nexttext:
of groupoids.
The groupoid ${\operatorname{colim}}_v{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}[x]$ of $n$-multimaps of
arbitrary degrees, will further be the groupoid of $n$-multimaps in a
symmetric $n$-theory.

Indeed, the datum $M_2$ induces ``composition'' operations
${\operatorname{colim}}_vm^{\mathcal}{X}_1(\pi)(v)$ on these groupoids, covering the
composition operations $m^{\mathcal}{U}_1(\pi)$ in ${\mathcal}{U}$.
Writing down the form of datum for the coherence for the associativity
in ${\mathcal}{X}$
(which is straightforward), we obtain the case $m=0$ of Proposition
\ref{prop:graded-is-overlying} below (hence our term for the notion).

The construction simply remains valid in the unenriched (higher)
categorified case ${\mathcal}{M}={\Theta}_0{\ccat{Cat}}_m$.

\begin{proposition}\label{prop:graded-is-overlying}
Let $n\ge 1$ be an integer, and let ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory
enriched in groupoids.
Then for every integer $m\ge 0$, an unenriched $m$-categorified
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory (i.e., ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory
enriched in ${\Theta}_0{\ccat{Cat}}_m$) is equivalent as a datum to an
unenriched $m$-categorified \textbf{symmetric} $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{Y}$
equipped with a functor ${\mathcal}{Y}\to{\mathcal}{U}$.
\end{proposition}

In order to see this more precisely, let us introduce the following
terminology, which will be justified shortly.

\begin{definition}
Let $n\ge 1$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an (unenriched)
$n$-theory.
Then, for an integer $m$ such that $0\le m\le n$, we refer to data of
the forms ($0$) through ($m-1$) specified for Definition
\ref{def:graded}, as a system of {\textbf}{colours} up to dimension $m-1$
{\textbf}{for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded higher theory}, or a system of colours
{\textbf}{for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory}.
\end{definition}

Suppose given a system ${\mathcal}{X}$ of colours up to dimension $n-2$ for
a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded higher theory.
Then we obtain a system ${\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{X}$ (where
${\Delta}\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$) of colours up to dimension $n-2$
for a symmetric higher theory, by inductively defining as follows.

We first define ${\operatorname{Ob}}{\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{X}$ as the collection whose member is
a pair $(u,x)$, where $u\in{\operatorname{Ob}}{\mathcal}{U}$ and $x\in{\operatorname{Ob}}_u{\mathcal}{X}$.
If $n\ge 3$, then inductively for an integer $k$ such that $1\le k\le
n-2$, the type of a $k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{Y}$ will be an identical
form of datum as a pair $(u,x)$, where $u$ is the type of a
$k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{U}$, and $x$ is the type of a
$k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{X}$ of degree $u$.
We then inductively define ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{X}}[(u,x)]$ as the
collection whose member is a pair $(v,y)$ consisting of
$v\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$ and $y\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}[x]$.
Moreover, one can associate to every member
$(v,y)\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{X}}[x]$ the member
$v\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$.

Proposition \ref{prop:graded-is-overlying} now follows since the
category (or ($m+2$)-category) of extensions of the datum
${\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{X}$ to an unenriched $m$-categorified symmetric
$n$-theory equipped with a functor to ${\mathcal}{U}$, gets equated by the
described construction, to the category (or ($m+2$)-category) of
extensions of the datum ${\mathcal}{X}$ to an unenriched $m$-categorified
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory.

\begin{example}\label{ex:graded-multicategory}
Let ${\mathrm}{Init}$ denote the initial uncoloured operad in groupoids.
\begin{itemize}
\item A category is equivalent as a datum to an ${\mathrm}{Init}$-graded
  $1$-theory.
\item A planar multicategory is equivalent as a datum to an
  $E_1$-graded $1$-theory.
\item A braided multicategory (see Fiedorowicz \cite{fiedoro})
  is equivalent as a datum to an $E_2$-graded $1$-theory.
\end{itemize}
\end{example}

\begin{example}
Since ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory is a theorization of
${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra, one obtains from a ${\mathcal}{U}$-monoidal category
${\mathcal}{X}$, a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory by replacing the functors
giving the composition operations by the
bimodules/distributors/profunctors corepresented by them.
We shall say that this $n$-theory is {\textbf}{represented} by ${\mathcal}{X}$,
and shall denote it by ${\Theta}_{n-1}{\mathcal}{X}$, where the subscript
comes from the fact that ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra is a generalization of
($n-1$)-theory from the case ${\mathcal}{U}={\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$.
\end{example}

\begin{example}
Recall that we called a plain $n$-theory, i.e., an $n$-theory which is
not considered with any grading, also a \emph{symmetric} $n$-theory.
Every symmetric $n$-theory is canonically graded by the terminal
unenriched uncoloured $n$-theory ${\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$, and there is no
difference between a
symmetric $n$-theory and a ${\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$-graded $n$-theory.
\end{example}


\subsubsection{}

For an unenriched ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{X}$, let us denote the
symmetric $n$-theory underlying ${\mathcal}{X}$ (which maps to ${\mathcal}{U}$;
see Proposition \ref{prop:graded-is-overlying}) by ${\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{X}$,
where ${\Delta}$ denotes the unique functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$.
For example, for the terminal unenriched uncoloured ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$n$-theory ${\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathcal}{U}$, we have that the canonical projection
functor ${\Delta}_!{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{U}$ is an equivalence.

Using this, we can obtain a compact reformulation of the notion of
algebra, as will be given now.

Suppose given a system of colours up to dimension $n-2$ for
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded higher theory, and let ${\mathcal}{T}$ denote the terminal
unenriched ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory on this system of colours.
Note that one can consider the structure of a ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra on
this system of colours.
Indeed, the structure of a ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra enriched in a
multicategory ${\mathcal}{M}$, is equivalent as a datum to a functor
${\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{T}\to{\field{\deloop}}^{n-1}{\mathcal}{M}$ of $n$-theories (and
equivalently therefore, an uncoloured ${\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{T}$-algebra
enriched in ${\mathcal}{M}$).
It is convenient to say that a ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra enriched in ${\mathcal}{M}$
is a functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\field{\deloop}}^{n-1}{\mathcal}{M}$ \emph{with strata of
  colours} up to dimension $n-2$, or colours for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra.

For example, a \emph{${\mathcal}{U}$-monoid}, i.e., a ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra
enriched in groupoids, is naturally equivalent as a datum to a
coloured functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\field{\deloop}}^{n-1}{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$.
In this sense, the symmetric ($n+1$)-theory
${\field{\deloop}}^{n-1}{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$ classifies (uncoloured) monoids over
unenriched symmetric $n$-theories, where the universal monoid is the
uncoloured ${\field{\deloop}}^{n-1}{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$-monoid ${\mathbb{U}}^{n-1}$
``classified'' by the identity functor of
${\field{\deloop}}^{n-1}{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$.

\begin{proposition}\label{prop:universal-theorization}
For the universal monoid ${\mathbb{U}}^{n-1}$, the projection functor of
the ${\field{\deloop}}^{n-1}{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$-graded $n$-theory
${\Theta}_{n-1}{\mathbb{U}}^{n-1}$ is equivalent to
prevtext:

  {\textbf}{composition} operation {\textbf}{along} $v$ for $n$-multimaps.
\item[($\infty$)] A datum of coherence for the associativity,
  corresponding to that for a lax ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra (Definition
  \ref{def:lax-monoid}).
\end{itemize}

This completes Definition \ref{def:graded}.


\subsubsection{}

Let us consider the unenriched case where
${\mathcal}{M}={\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$.

Note that in this case, $M_1(\pi)[x]$ above can be identified with the
datum of the canonical projection map

induced from the forgetful functor ${\mathrm}{Gpd}_*\to{\mathrm}{Gpd}$, where ${\mathrm}{Gpd}_*$
denotes the Cartesian symmetric monoidal category
of pointed groupoids.
\end{proposition}

The proof is straightforward from the definitions.


\subsubsection{}
\label{sec:theorem}

Now the notion of algebra generalizes immediately as follows.

\begin{definition}
Let $n\ge 2$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an unenriched
$n$-theory.
Then a {\textbf}{${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra in a symmetric $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{V}$} is
a \emph{functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$ with strata of colours}
for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra, namely, a functor ${\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{T}\to{\mathcal}{V}$,
where ${\mathcal}{T}$ is the terminal unenriched ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory
on a system of colours
up to dimension $n-2$ for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded higher theory.
\end{definition}

We generalize this as follows.

\begin{definition}\label{def:coloured-lax-algebra-over-theory}
Let $n\ge 1$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an unenriched
$n$-theory.
Then an {\textbf}{$n$-tuply coloured lax ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra} in a
categorified symmetric $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{V}$, is a lax functor
${\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$ with strata of colours up
to dimension $n-1$, namely, a lax functor ${\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{T}\to{\mathcal}{V}$,
where ${\mathcal}{T}$ is the terminal unenriched ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory
on a system of
colours up to dimension $n-1$ for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded higher theory.
\end{definition}

We obtain from Definition \ref{def:graded} that a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$n$-theory enriched in a symmetric monoidal category ${\mathcal}{A}$, i.e.,
in ${\Theta}_0{\mathcal}{A}$, is (circularly) an $n$-tuply coloured lax
${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra in ${\field{\deloop}}^n{\mathcal}{A}$.

\begin{remark}\label{rem:coloured-lax-algebra}
Using the definition mentioned in Remark
\ref{rem:lax-functor-general}, of a ``functor'', one can define an
$n$-tuply coloured ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra in a symmetric
\emph{($n+1$)-theory} ${\mathcal}{W}$ as a functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{W}$ with
strata of colours up to dimension $n-1$.
In particular, a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory enriched in a
multicategory ${\mathcal}{M}$ will be equivalent as a datum to an $n$-tuply
coloured ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra in ${\field{\deloop}}^n{\mathcal}{M}$.
Note the equivalence
${\Theta}_n{\field{\deloop}}^n{\mathcal}{A}={\field{\deloop}}^n{\Theta}_0{\mathcal}{A}$ for a
symmetric monoidal category ${\mathcal}{A}$, which follows from Lemma
\ref{lem:deloop-forget-commutation}.
\end{remark}

We obtain the following fundamental result.

\begin{theorem}\label{thm:graded-theory-is-monoid}
Let $n\ge 1$ be an integer, and let ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory
enriched in groupoids.
Then a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory enriched in a multicategory
${\mathcal}{M}$ is equivalent as a datum to a ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$-algebra
enriched in ${\mathcal}{M}$.
\end{theorem}

\begin{proof}
We shall prove the case where ${\mathcal}{M}$ is represented by a symmetric
monoidal category ${\mathcal}{A}$.
The general case follows from essentially the same (and simpler)
argument, but one needs to use Remark \ref{rem:coloured-lax-algebra}
and the remark after Definition
\ref{def:theory-enriched-in-multicategory}, of which we have omitted
the details.

Let us first note that systems of colours for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$n$-theory and for
a ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$-algebra are identical forms of datum.
Choose and fix a datum of this form.
Then we would like to show that the categories of the structures on
this same system of colours, of a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory and of
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$-algebras, are equivalent.
Let us prove this.

Let ${\mathcal}{T}$ denote the terminal unenriched ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$n$-theory on the chosen system of colours.
Then the structure of a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory on those strata of
colours could be described as a lax functor
${\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{T}\to{\field{\deloop}}^n{\mathcal}{A}$, which Theorem
\ref{thm:functor-of-theorization} and Lemma
\ref{lem:deloop-forget-commutation} equates with the datum of a
functor
${\Theta}_n{\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{T}\to{\field{\deloop}}^n{\Theta}_0{\mathcal}{A}$.

Let next ${\mathcal}{J}$ denote the terminal unenriched
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($n+1$)-theory on the same system of
colours.
Then the structure of a ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$-algebra on those strata
of colours can be described as a functor
${{\Delta}'}_!{\mathcal}{J}\to{\field{\deloop}}^n{\Theta}_0{\mathcal}{A}$, where
${\Delta}'\colon{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^{n+1}_{\mathrm}{Com}$.

However, it is immediate that the strata of colours up to dimension
$n-1$, of ${\Theta}_n{\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{T}$, and of ${{\Delta}'}_!{\mathcal}{J}$,
are identical, and these two ($n+1$)-theories on the same strata of
colours are in fact equivalent.
The result follows.
\end{proof}

\begin{definition}\label{def:graded-by-0-theory}
Let $A$ be a $0$-theory in groupoids, i.e., a commutative monoid.
Then an {\textbf}{$A$-graded} $0$-theory is a ${\Theta}_0A$-algebra.
\end{definition}

In particular, an unenriched $A$-graded $0$-theory is equivalent as
a datum to a commutative monoid $X$ equipped with a morphism $X\to
A$.


\subsubsection{}

The notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory can be theorized in almost
the same way as how we
have theorized the notion of algebra over an $n$-theory.
We might call the resulting object a {\textbf}{${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
($n+1$)-theory}.

However, this is not really a new notion as should be expected from
Theorem \ref{thm:graded-theory-is-monoid}.

\begin{theorem}\label{thm:grade-theorized-theory}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and let ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory
enriched in groupoids.
Then a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($n+1$)-theory is equivalent as a datum to a
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($n+1$)-theory.
\end{theorem}

The proof is also similar to the proof of Theorem
\ref{thm:graded-theory-is-monoid}.
We leave the details to the interested reader.

\begin{definition}\label{def:higher-graded}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and let ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory
enriched in groupoids.
For an integer $m\ge n+2$, a {\textbf}{${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory} is a
${\Theta}^m_n{\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory, or equivalently, a
${\Theta}^{m+1}_n{\mathcal}{U}$-algebra.
\end{definition}

Thus, for every ${\mathcal}{U}$, ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theories are iterated
theorizations of ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra for $m\ge n$.

\begin{example}
An $E_1$-graded $n$-theory is equivalent as a datum to a planar
$n$-theory defined in Section \ref{sec:planar-theory}.
\end{example}

More generally, for every multicategory ${\mathcal}{U}$ enriched in
groupoids, there is a similar description of a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$n$-theory.
Recall that the notion of planar $n$-theory was defined by replacing
the category ${\mathrm}{Fin}$ in the definition of a symmetric $n$-theory, with
the category ${\mathrm}{Ord}$.
For a similar description of the notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$n$-theory, we would like to replace ${\mathrm}{Fin}$ by a category which is an
analogue for ${\mathcal}{U}$, of ${\mathrm}{Ord}$.

In order to construct this category, note that the forgetful functor
${\Theta}_0$ from ${\mathcal}{U}$-monoidal categories to ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
multicategories, has a left adjoint $L_{\mathcal}{U}$, and that the unique
functor ${\Delta}\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathrm}{Com}$ of symmetric multicategories,
where ${\mathrm}{Com}=E_\infty$ denotes the commutative operad (i.e., the
terminal unenriched symmetric operad), induces a functor
${\Delta}_*\colon
L_{\mathcal}{U}{\boldsymbol{1}}^1_{\mathcal}{U}\to{\Delta}^*L_{\mathrm}{Com}{\boldsymbol{1}}^1_{\mathrm}{Com}={\Delta}^*{\mathrm}{Fin}$ of
${\mathcal}{U}$-monoidal categories, where ${\boldsymbol{1}}^1_{\mathcal}{U}$ denotes the
terminal unenriched ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded multicategory.

For simplicity, suppose first that ${\mathcal}{U}$ is uncoloured.
Then we obtain a description of a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory by
replacing the category ${\mathrm}{Fin}$ in the definition \ref{def:theory} of a
symmetric $n$-theory, with ${\mathcal}{L}:=L_{\mathcal}{U}{\boldsymbol{1}}^1_{\mathcal}{U}$, where
\begin{itemize}
\item by a family \emph{indexed by $J\in{\mathcal}{L}$}, we mean a family
  indexed by ${\Delta}_*J\in{\mathrm}{Fin}$, and
\item for $I\in{\mathrm}{Ord}$, we say that a $[I]$-family $J$ of objects of
  ${\mathcal}{L}$ is \emph{elemental} if ${\Delta}_*J$ is an elemental
  $[I]$-family in ${\mathrm}{Fin}$.
\end{itemize}

If ${\mathcal}{U}$ is instead a coloured multicategory, then the description
is similar except that we would need to have objects of the ``theory''
to have ``degrees'' in ${\mathcal}{U}$.
We leave the details to the reader.



{\oldsubsection{{Iterated monoids}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}
\label{sec:iterated-monoid}

\subsubsection{}

Let ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in groupoids, and ${\mathcal}{X}$ be
a ${\mathcal}{U}$-monoid.
Then since the structure of ${\mathcal}{X}$ is a generalization of the
structure of an ($n-1$)-theory, it is natural to consider the notion
of ${\mathcal}{X}$-algebra if $n\ge 2$.

The notion can actually be reduced to the same notion in the special
case where ${\mathcal}{X}$ is the unit (or terminal uncoloured)
${\mathcal}{U}$-monoid.
Indeed, if we denote by ${\Delta}$ the unique functor
${\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$, then an ${\mathcal}{X}$-algebra will simply be an
algebra over the unit ${\Delta}_!{\Theta}_{n-1}{\mathcal}{X}$-monoid.
(In particular, the dependence of the notion on ${\mathcal}{U}$ will be only
through the presentation of the symmetric $n$-theory
${\mathcal}{Y}={\Delta}_!{\Theta}_{n-1}{\mathcal}{X}$ as underlying
${\Theta}_{n-1}{\mathcal}{X}$.)


\subsubsection{}
\label{sec:detheorize}

Let now ${\mathcal}{X}$ be the unit ${\mathcal}{U}$-monoid (so
${\mathcal}{U}={\Delta}_!{\Theta}_{n-1}{\mathcal}{X}$).
Then the notion of ${\mathcal}{X}$-algebra will be such that the notion of
${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra theorizes it.
In fact, the notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra `detheorizes' more times, and
the most detheorized notion will at the end be equivalent to the
notion of algebra over the unit monoid over~...~over the unit monoid
over ${\mathcal}{U}$, where we should have $n-1$ unit monoids in the
expression.

We can directly define all iteratively detheorized notions as
follows.

\begin{definition}
Let $n\ge 1$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in
groupoids.
Then for an integer $m$ such that $0\le m\le n-1$, a
{\textbf}{${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory} enriched in a multicategory
${\mathcal}{M}$, is a functor
${\mathcal}{U}\to{\Theta}^n_{m+1}{\field{\deloop}}^m{\mathcal}{M}$ with strata of
colours for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory.
\end{definition}

To be explicit, in the case $m=0$, there is no colours added.
In the case $m\ge 1$, given a system of colours for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$m$-theory ${\mathcal}{X}$, the structure on it, of a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$m$-theory, is a functor
${\mathcal}{T}\to{\Theta}^n_{m+1}{\field{\deloop}}^m{\mathcal}{M}$,
where ${\mathcal}{T}$ is the symmetric $n$-theory described as follows.
\begin{itemize}
\item[($0$)] ${\operatorname{Ob}}{\mathcal}{T}$ is the collection whose member is a pair
  $(u,x)$, where $u\in{\operatorname{Ob}}{\mathcal}{U}$ and $x\in{\operatorname{Ob}}_u{\mathcal}{X}$.
\end{itemize}
By induction, for $k$ such that $1\le k\le m$, the type of a
$k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{T}$ of a given arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$, is
specified by
\begin{itemize}
\item the type $u$ of a $k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{U}$ of arity
  $(I;\pi,\phi)$,
\item the type $x$ of a $k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{X}$ of the same arity of
  degree $u$.
\end{itemize}
\begin{itemize}
\item[($k$)](Inductively for $k$ such that $1\le k\le m-1$.)
  Suppose given the arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$ of a $k$-multimap, and the
  type $(u,x)$ of a $k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{T}$ of arity
  $(I;\pi,\phi)$.
  Then ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{T}[(u,x)]$ is the collection whose member is a
  pair $(v,y)$, where $v\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$ and
  $y\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}[x]$.
\item[($m$)] Suppose given a datum similar to an input datum for
  ``($k$)'' above, but with $k$ substituted by $m$.
  Then ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{T}[(u,x)]={\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$.
\item[($\ell$)](Inductively for $\ell$ such that $m+1\le\ell\le n$.)
  Suppose given the arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$ of a $\ell$-multimap, and the
  type of an $\ell$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{T}$ of arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$,
  which by induction, will be specified by
  \begin{itemize}
  \item the type $u$ of a $\ell$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{U}$ of arity
    $(I;\pi,\phi)$,
  \item the type $x$ of a $\phi^{m-1}$-nerve of $m$-multimaps in
    ${\mathcal}{X}$ of degree $u^{\le m-1}$.
  \end{itemize}
  Then ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{T}[(u,x)]={\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$.
\end{itemize}
The composition is given by the composition in ${\mathcal}{U}$.

Thus, the notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($n-1$)-theory coincides with the
notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra, and for all $m\ge 0$ (which may be $\ge
n$), the notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory is iteratively an
$m$-th theorization of the notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $0$-theory.

\begin{lemma}
A ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory is equivalent as a datum to a
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory.
\end{lemma}

The proof of this is direct from Corollary
\ref{cor:forget-to-theorization}.

\begin{definition}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in
groupoids.
Then we refer to a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $1$-theory also as a
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded {\textbf}{multicategory}.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}
Let $n\ge 1$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in
groupoids.
Let $m\ge 0$ and $\ell\ge 1$ be integers.
Then, for an $\ell$-categorified ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory
${\mathcal}{X}$, we denote by ${\Theta}_m{\mathcal}{X}$, the
($\ell-1$)-categorified ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($m+1$)-theory
\emph{represented} by ${\mathcal}{X}$, namely, obtained by
replacing the structure functors of ${\mathcal}{X}$ by the
bimodules/distributors/profunctors corepresented by them.
\end{definition}

If ${\mathcal}{X}$ is enriched in $\ell$-categories, then it can be regarded
as $k$-categorified for any $k\ge\ell$.
However, resulting ${\Theta}_m{\mathcal}{X}$ is independent of $k$.
In particular, ${\Theta}_m{\mathcal}{X}$ is also defined for an
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory ${\mathcal}{X}$ enriched in groupoids, and it is
an uncategorified ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($m+1$)-theory, which can be
considered as as highly categorified (trivially) as one wishes to.

\begin{definition}
Let $n\ge 1$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in
groupoids.
Let $m\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{X}$ be a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$m$-theory which is possibly higher categorified.
Then, for an integer $\ell\ge 0$, we define a (less or un-
categorified) ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($m+\ell$)-theory
${\Theta}^{m+\ell}_m{\mathcal}{X}$ by the inductive relations
prevtext:
of groupoids.
The groupoid ${\operatorname{colim}}_v{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}[x]$ of $n$-multimaps of
arbitrary degrees, will further be the groupoid of $n$-multimaps in a
symmetric $n$-theory.

Indeed, the datum $M_2$ induces ``composition'' operations
${\operatorname{colim}}_vm^{\mathcal}{X}_1(\pi)(v)$ on these groupoids, covering the
composition operations $m^{\mathcal}{U}_1(\pi)$ in ${\mathcal}{U}$.
Writing down the form of datum for the coherence for the associativity
in ${\mathcal}{X}$
(which is straightforward), we obtain the case $m=0$ of Proposition
\ref{prop:graded-is-overlying} below (hence our term for the notion).

The construction simply remains valid in the unenriched (higher)
categorified case ${\mathcal}{M}={\Theta}_0{\ccat{Cat}}_m$.

\begin{proposition}\label{prop:graded-is-overlying}
Let $n\ge 1$ be an integer, and let ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory
enriched in groupoids.
Then for every integer $m\ge 0$, an unenriched $m$-categorified
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory (i.e., ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory
enriched in ${\Theta}_0{\ccat{Cat}}_m$) is equivalent as a datum to an
unenriched $m$-categorified \textbf{symmetric} $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{Y}$
equipped with a functor ${\mathcal}{Y}\to{\mathcal}{U}$.
\end{proposition}

In order to see this more precisely, let us introduce the following
terminology, which will be justified shortly.

\begin{definition}
Let $n\ge 1$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an (unenriched)
$n$-theory.
Then, for an integer $m$ such that $0\le m\le n$, we refer to data of
the forms ($0$) through ($m-1$) specified for Definition
\ref{def:graded}, as a system of {\textbf}{colours} up to dimension $m-1$
{\textbf}{for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded higher theory}, or a system of colours
{\textbf}{for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory}.
\end{definition}

Suppose given a system ${\mathcal}{X}$ of colours up to dimension $n-2$ for
a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded higher theory.
Then we obtain a system ${\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{X}$ (where
${\Delta}\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$) of colours up to dimension $n-2$
for a symmetric higher theory, by inductively defining as follows.

We first define ${\operatorname{Ob}}{\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{X}$ as the collection whose member is
a pair $(u,x)$, where $u\in{\operatorname{Ob}}{\mathcal}{U}$ and $x\in{\operatorname{Ob}}_u{\mathcal}{X}$.
If $n\ge 3$, then inductively for an integer $k$ such that $1\le k\le
n-2$, the type of a $k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{Y}$ will be an identical
form of datum as a pair $(u,x)$, where $u$ is the type of a
$k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{U}$, and $x$ is the type of a
$k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{X}$ of degree $u$.
We then inductively define ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{X}}[(u,x)]$ as the
collection whose member is a pair $(v,y)$ consisting of
$v\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$ and $y\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}[x]$.
Moreover, one can associate to every member
$(v,y)\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{X}}[x]$ the member
$v\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$.

Proposition \ref{prop:graded-is-overlying} now follows since the
category (or ($m+2$)-category) of extensions of the datum
${\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{X}$ to an unenriched $m$-categorified symmetric
$n$-theory equipped with a functor to ${\mathcal}{U}$, gets equated by the
described construction, to the category (or ($m+2$)-category) of
extensions of the datum ${\mathcal}{X}$ to an unenriched $m$-categorified
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory.

\begin{example}\label{ex:graded-multicategory}
Let ${\mathrm}{Init}$ denote the initial uncoloured operad in groupoids.
\begin{itemize}
\item A category is equivalent as a datum to an ${\mathrm}{Init}$-graded
  $1$-theory.
\item A planar multicategory is equivalent as a datum to an
  $E_1$-graded $1$-theory.
\item A braided multicategory (see Fiedorowicz \cite{fiedoro})
  is equivalent as a datum to an $E_2$-graded $1$-theory.
\end{itemize}
\end{example}

\begin{example}
Since ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory is a theorization of
${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra, one obtains from a ${\mathcal}{U}$-monoidal category
${\mathcal}{X}$, a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory by replacing the functors
giving the composition operations by the
bimodules/distributors/profunctors corepresented by them.
We shall say that this $n$-theory is {\textbf}{represented} by ${\mathcal}{X}$,
and shall denote it by ${\Theta}_{n-1}{\mathcal}{X}$, where the subscript
comes from the fact that ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra is a generalization of
($n-1$)-theory from the case ${\mathcal}{U}={\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$.
\end{example}

\begin{example}
Recall that we called a plain $n$-theory, i.e., an $n$-theory which is
not considered with any grading, also a \emph{symmetric} $n$-theory.
Every symmetric $n$-theory is canonically graded by the terminal
unenriched uncoloured $n$-theory ${\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$, and there is no
difference between a
symmetric $n$-theory and a ${\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$-graded $n$-theory.
\end{example}


\subsubsection{}

For an unenriched ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{X}$, let us denote the
symmetric $n$-theory underlying ${\mathcal}{X}$ (which maps to ${\mathcal}{U}$;
see Proposition \ref{prop:graded-is-overlying}) by ${\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{X}$,
where ${\Delta}$ denotes the unique functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$.
For example, for the terminal unenriched uncoloured ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$n$-theory ${\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathcal}{U}$, we have that the canonical projection
functor ${\Delta}_!{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{U}$ is an equivalence.

Using this, we can obtain a compact reformulation of the notion of
algebra, as will be given now.

Suppose given a system of colours up to dimension $n-2$ for
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded higher theory, and let ${\mathcal}{T}$ denote the terminal
unenriched ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory on this system of colours.
Note that one can consider the structure of a ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra on
this system of colours.
Indeed, the structure of a ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra enriched in a
multicategory ${\mathcal}{M}$, is equivalent as a datum to a functor
${\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{T}\to{\field{\deloop}}^{n-1}{\mathcal}{M}$ of $n$-theories (and
equivalently therefore, an uncoloured ${\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{T}$-algebra
enriched in ${\mathcal}{M}$).
It is convenient to say that a ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra enriched in ${\mathcal}{M}$
is a functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\field{\deloop}}^{n-1}{\mathcal}{M}$ \emph{with strata of
  colours} up to dimension $n-2$, or colours for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra.

For example, a \emph{${\mathcal}{U}$-monoid}, i.e., a ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra
enriched in groupoids, is naturally equivalent as a datum to a
coloured functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\field{\deloop}}^{n-1}{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$.
In this sense, the symmetric ($n+1$)-theory
${\field{\deloop}}^{n-1}{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$ classifies (uncoloured) monoids over
unenriched symmetric $n$-theories, where the universal monoid is the
uncoloured ${\field{\deloop}}^{n-1}{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$-monoid ${\mathbb{U}}^{n-1}$
``classified'' by the identity functor of
${\field{\deloop}}^{n-1}{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$.

\begin{proposition}\label{prop:universal-theorization}
For the universal monoid ${\mathbb{U}}^{n-1}$, the projection functor of
the ${\field{\deloop}}^{n-1}{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$-graded $n$-theory
${\Theta}_{n-1}{\mathbb{U}}^{n-1}$ is equivalent to
