\end{definition}


\subsubsection{}

The following definition essentially achieves (more than) our initial
goal of the discussions here.

\begin{definition}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in
groupoids.
Let $m\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{X}$ be a
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory enriched in groupoids.
Then for an integer $\ell\ge 0$, an {\textbf}{${\mathcal}{X}$-graded}
$\ell$-theory is a ${\Delta}_!{\Theta}^N_m{\mathcal}{X}$-graded
$\ell$-theory, where $N:=\max\{m,n\}$, and
${\Delta}\colon{\Theta}^N_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^N_{\mathrm}{Com}$.
\end{definition}

\begin{example}\label{ex:terminally-graded}
Let ${\mathcal}{X}$ be the terminal uncoloured ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory
enriched in groupoids.
Then we have ${\Delta}_!{\Theta}^N_m{\mathcal}{X}={\Theta}^N_n{\mathcal}{U}$,
so an ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded
$\ell$-theory is equivalent as a datum to a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$\ell$-theory, as had been predicted.
\end{example}


\subsubsection{}

In order to analyse the notions further, we shall next consider how
gradings can be altered.

Given a functor $F\colon{\mathcal}{V}\to{\mathcal}{U}$ of $n$-theories enriched in
groupoids, it
is clear that a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory ${\mathcal}{X}$ gets pulled back
by $F$.
Let us denote the resulting ${\mathcal}{V}$-graded $m$-theory by
$F^*{\mathcal}{X}$.
In the case where $m=n$, and ${\mathcal}{X}$ is unenriched, the projection
$({\Delta}_{\mathcal}{V})_!F^*{\mathcal}{X}\to{\mathcal}{V}$ (where
${\Delta}_{\mathcal}{V}\colon{\mathcal}{V}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$) is the base
change of the projection $({\Delta}_{\mathcal}{U})_!{\mathcal}{X}\to{\mathcal}{U}$ by $F$
in a suitable sense.
In the case where $m\le n-1$, one has
${\vphantom{{{\Theta}}}{^{\mathcal}{V}}\!{{{\Theta}}}}^n_m(F^*{\mathcal}{X})=F^*({\vphantom{{{\Theta}}}{^{\mathcal}{U}}\!{{{\Theta}}}}^n_m{\mathcal}{X})$,
where the superscripts to ${\Theta}^n_m$ indicate the gradings
considered.
If $m\ge n+1$, then $F^*$ is the pull-back by
${\Theta}^m_nF\colon{\Theta}^m_n{\mathcal}{V}\to{\Theta}^m_n{\mathcal}{U}$.

\begin{example}
For an $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{V}$ enriched in groupoids, and an uncoloured
${\mathcal}{V}$-monoid ${\mathcal}{X}$ defined by a functor
$F\colon{\mathcal}{V}\to{\field{\deloop}}^{n-1}{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$,
we have an equivalence
${\Theta}_{n-1}{\mathcal}{X}=F^*({\Theta}_{n-1}{\mathbb{U}}^{n-1})$ of
(simply coloured) ${\mathcal}{V}$-graded $n$-theories, where
${\Theta}_{n-1}{\mathbb{U}}^{n-1}$ has been described in Proposition
\ref{prop:universal-theorization}.
\end{example}

Let again ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in groupoids.
For an integer $m\ge 0$, suppose that ${\mathcal}{V}$ is a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$m$-theory enriched in groupoids, and denote by $P$, the projection
${\Delta}_!{\Theta}^N_m{\mathcal}{V}\to{\Theta}^N_n{\mathcal}{U}$, where $N\ge
m,n$, and ${\Delta}\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$.
Then also clearly, one obtains from an unenriched (possibly higher
categorified) ${\mathcal}{V}$-graded $m$-theory
${\mathcal}{Y}$, its push forward $P_!{\mathcal}{Y}$ as a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$m$-theory, generalizing the construction ${\Delta}_!$.

In the case $m=n$, $P_!{\mathcal}{Y}$ has the same underlying symmetric
$n$-theory as that of ${\mathcal}{Y}$, with projection to ${\mathcal}{U}$ given by
the projection to ${\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{V}$ composed with
$P\colon{\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{V}\to{\mathcal}{U}$.

In the case $m\le n-1$, the description of $P_!{\mathcal}{Y}$ is as
follows.
\begin{itemize}
\item[($0$)] For an object $u\in{\operatorname{Ob}}{\mathcal}{U}$, ${\operatorname{Ob}}_uP_!{\mathcal}{Y}$ is the
  collection whose member is a pair $(v,y)$, where $v\in{\operatorname{Ob}}_u{\mathcal}{V}$
  and $y\in{\operatorname{Ob}}_v{\mathcal}{Y}$.
\end{itemize}
Let $k$ be an integer such that $1\le k\le m$, and suppose given the
type $u$ of a $k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{U}$ whose arity is given as
$(I;\pi,\phi)$.
Then by induction, the type of a $k$-multimap in $P_!{\mathcal}{X}$ of the
same arity of degree $u$, is specified by
\begin{itemize}
\item the type $v$ of a $k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{V}$ of the same arity of
  degree $u$,
\item the type $y$ of a $k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{Y}$ of the same arity of
  degree $v$.
\end{itemize}
\begin{itemize}
\item[($k$)](Inductively for $1\le k\le m-1$.)
  Suppose given
  \begin{itemize}
  \item a $k$-multimap $u^k$ in ${\mathcal}{U}$ whose arity and type
    are given respectively as $(I;\pi,\phi)$ and $u^{\le
      k-1}=(u^\nu)_{0\le\nu\le k-1}$,
  \item the type $(v,y)$ of a $k$-multimap in $P_!{\mathcal}{X}$ of the same
    arity of degree $u^{\le k-1}$.
  \end{itemize}
  Then ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{P_!{\mathcal}{Y},u^k}[(v,y)]$ is the collection whose
  member is a pair $(w,z)$, where $w\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{V},u^k}[v]$ and
  $z\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{Y},w}[y]$.
\item[($m$)] Suppose given a datum similar to an input datum for
  ``($k$)'' above, but with $k$ substituted by $m$.
  Then
prevtext:
induced from the forgetful functor ${\mathrm}{Gpd}_*\to{\mathrm}{Gpd}$, where ${\mathrm}{Gpd}_*$
denotes the Cartesian symmetric monoidal category
of pointed groupoids.
\end{proposition}

The proof is straightforward from the definitions.


\subsubsection{}
\label{sec:theorem}

Now the notion of algebra generalizes immediately as follows.

\begin{definition}
Let $n\ge 2$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an unenriched
$n$-theory.
Then a {\textbf}{${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra in a symmetric $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{V}$} is
a \emph{functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$ with strata of colours}
for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra, namely, a functor ${\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{T}\to{\mathcal}{V}$,
where ${\mathcal}{T}$ is the terminal unenriched ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory
on a system of colours
up to dimension $n-2$ for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded higher theory.
\end{definition}

We generalize this as follows.

\begin{definition}\label{def:coloured-lax-algebra-over-theory}
Let $n\ge 1$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an unenriched
$n$-theory.
Then an {\textbf}{$n$-tuply coloured lax ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra} in a
categorified symmetric $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{V}$, is a lax functor
${\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$ with strata of colours up
to dimension $n-1$, namely, a lax functor ${\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{T}\to{\mathcal}{V}$,
where ${\mathcal}{T}$ is the terminal unenriched ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory
on a system of
colours up to dimension $n-1$ for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded higher theory.
\end{definition}

We obtain from Definition \ref{def:graded} that a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$n$-theory enriched in a symmetric monoidal category ${\mathcal}{A}$, i.e.,
in ${\Theta}_0{\mathcal}{A}$, is (circularly) an $n$-tuply coloured lax
${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra in ${\field{\deloop}}^n{\mathcal}{A}$.

\begin{remark}\label{rem:coloured-lax-algebra}
Using the definition mentioned in Remark
\ref{rem:lax-functor-general}, of a ``functor'', one can define an
$n$-tuply coloured ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra in a symmetric
\emph{($n+1$)-theory} ${\mathcal}{W}$ as a functor ${\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{W}$ with
strata of colours up to dimension $n-1$.
In particular, a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory enriched in a
multicategory ${\mathcal}{M}$ will be equivalent as a datum to an $n$-tuply
coloured ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra in ${\field{\deloop}}^n{\mathcal}{M}$.
Note the equivalence
${\Theta}_n{\field{\deloop}}^n{\mathcal}{A}={\field{\deloop}}^n{\Theta}_0{\mathcal}{A}$ for a
symmetric monoidal category ${\mathcal}{A}$, which follows from Lemma
\ref{lem:deloop-forget-commutation}.
\end{remark}

We obtain the following fundamental result.

\begin{theorem}\label{thm:graded-theory-is-monoid}
Let $n\ge 1$ be an integer, and let ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory
enriched in groupoids.
Then a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory enriched in a multicategory
${\mathcal}{M}$ is equivalent as a datum to a ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$-algebra
enriched in ${\mathcal}{M}$.
\end{theorem}

\begin{proof}
We shall prove the case where ${\mathcal}{M}$ is represented by a symmetric
monoidal category ${\mathcal}{A}$.
The general case follows from essentially the same (and simpler)
argument, but one needs to use Remark \ref{rem:coloured-lax-algebra}
and the remark after Definition
\ref{def:theory-enriched-in-multicategory}, of which we have omitted
the details.

Let us first note that systems of colours for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$n$-theory and for
a ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$-algebra are identical forms of datum.
Choose and fix a datum of this form.
Then we would like to show that the categories of the structures on
this same system of colours, of a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory and of
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$-algebras, are equivalent.
Let us prove this.

Let ${\mathcal}{T}$ denote the terminal unenriched ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$n$-theory on the chosen system of colours.
Then the structure of a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory on those strata of
colours could be described as a lax functor
${\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{T}\to{\field{\deloop}}^n{\mathcal}{A}$, which Theorem
\ref{thm:functor-of-theorization} and Lemma
\ref{lem:deloop-forget-commutation} equates with the datum of a
functor
${\Theta}_n{\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{T}\to{\field{\deloop}}^n{\Theta}_0{\mathcal}{A}$.

Let next ${\mathcal}{J}$ denote the terminal unenriched
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($n+1$)-theory on the same system of
colours.
Then the structure of a ${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$-algebra on those strata
of colours can be described as a functor
${{\Delta}'}_!{\mathcal}{J}\to{\field{\deloop}}^n{\Theta}_0{\mathcal}{A}$, where
${\Delta}'\colon{\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^{n+1}_{\mathrm}{Com}$.

However, it is immediate that the strata of colours up to dimension
$n-1$, of ${\Theta}_n{\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{T}$, and of ${{\Delta}'}_!{\mathcal}{J}$,
are identical, and these two ($n+1$)-theories on the same strata of
colours are in fact equivalent.
The result follows.
\end{proof}

\begin{definition}\label{def:graded-by-0-theory}
Let $A$ be a $0$-theory in groupoids, i.e., a commutative monoid.
Then an {\textbf}{$A$-graded} $0$-theory is a ${\Theta}_0A$-algebra.
\end{definition}

In particular, an unenriched $A$-graded $0$-theory is equivalent as
a datum to a commutative monoid $X$ equipped with a morphism $X\to
A$.


\subsubsection{}

The notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory can be theorized in almost
the same way as how we
have theorized the notion of algebra over an $n$-theory.
We might call the resulting object a {\textbf}{${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
($n+1$)-theory}.

However, this is not really a new notion as should be expected from
Theorem \ref{thm:graded-theory-is-monoid}.

\begin{theorem}\label{thm:grade-theorized-theory}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and let ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory
enriched in groupoids.
Then a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($n+1$)-theory is equivalent as a datum to a
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($n+1$)-theory.
\end{theorem}

The proof is also similar to the proof of Theorem
\ref{thm:graded-theory-is-monoid}.
We leave the details to the interested reader.

\begin{definition}\label{def:higher-graded}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and let ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory
enriched in groupoids.
For an integer $m\ge n+2$, a {\textbf}{${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory} is a
${\Theta}^m_n{\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory, or equivalently, a
${\Theta}^{m+1}_n{\mathcal}{U}$-algebra.
\end{definition}

Thus, for every ${\mathcal}{U}$, ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theories are iterated
theorizations of ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra for $m\ge n$.

\begin{example}
An $E_1$-graded $n$-theory is equivalent as a datum to a planar
$n$-theory defined in Section \ref{sec:planar-theory}.
\end{example}

More generally, for every multicategory ${\mathcal}{U}$ enriched in
groupoids, there is a similar description of a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$n$-theory.
Recall that the notion of planar $n$-theory was defined by replacing
the category ${\mathrm}{Fin}$ in the definition of a symmetric $n$-theory, with
the category ${\mathrm}{Ord}$.
For a similar description of the notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$n$-theory, we would like to replace ${\mathrm}{Fin}$ by a category which is an
analogue for ${\mathcal}{U}$, of ${\mathrm}{Ord}$.

In order to construct this category, note that the forgetful functor
${\Theta}_0$ from ${\mathcal}{U}$-monoidal categories to ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
multicategories, has a left adjoint $L_{\mathcal}{U}$, and that the unique
functor ${\Delta}\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathrm}{Com}$ of symmetric multicategories,
where ${\mathrm}{Com}=E_\infty$ denotes the commutative operad (i.e., the
terminal unenriched symmetric operad), induces a functor
${\Delta}_*\colon
L_{\mathcal}{U}{\boldsymbol{1}}^1_{\mathcal}{U}\to{\Delta}^*L_{\mathrm}{Com}{\boldsymbol{1}}^1_{\mathrm}{Com}={\Delta}^*{\mathrm}{Fin}$ of
${\mathcal}{U}$-monoidal categories, where ${\boldsymbol{1}}^1_{\mathcal}{U}$ denotes the
terminal unenriched ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded multicategory.

For simplicity, suppose first that ${\mathcal}{U}$ is uncoloured.
Then we obtain a description of a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory by
replacing the category ${\mathrm}{Fin}$ in the definition \ref{def:theory} of a
symmetric $n$-theory, with ${\mathcal}{L}:=L_{\mathcal}{U}{\boldsymbol{1}}^1_{\mathcal}{U}$, where
\begin{itemize}
\item by a family \emph{indexed by $J\in{\mathcal}{L}$}, we mean a family
  indexed by ${\Delta}_*J\in{\mathrm}{Fin}$, and
\item for $I\in{\mathrm}{Ord}$, we say that a $[I]$-family $J$ of objects of
  ${\mathcal}{L}$ is \emph{elemental} if ${\Delta}_*J$ is an elemental
  $[I]$-family in ${\mathrm}{Fin}$.
\end{itemize}

If ${\mathcal}{U}$ is instead a coloured multicategory, then the description
is similar except that we would need to have objects of the ``theory''
to have ``degrees'' in ${\mathcal}{U}$.
We leave the details to the reader.



{\oldsubsection{{Iterated monoids}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}
\label{sec:iterated-monoid}

\subsubsection{}

Let ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in groupoids, and ${\mathcal}{X}$ be
a ${\mathcal}{U}$-monoid.
Then since the structure of ${\mathcal}{X}$ is a generalization of the
structure of an ($n-1$)-theory, it is natural to consider the notion
of ${\mathcal}{X}$-algebra if $n\ge 2$.

The notion can actually be reduced to the same notion in the special
case where ${\mathcal}{X}$ is the unit (or terminal uncoloured)
${\mathcal}{U}$-monoid.
Indeed, if we denote by ${\Delta}$ the unique functor
${\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$, then an ${\mathcal}{X}$-algebra will simply be an
algebra over the unit ${\Delta}_!{\Theta}_{n-1}{\mathcal}{X}$-monoid.
(In particular, the dependence of the notion on ${\mathcal}{U}$ will be only
through the presentation of the symmetric $n$-theory
${\mathcal}{Y}={\Delta}_!{\Theta}_{n-1}{\mathcal}{X}$ as underlying
${\Theta}_{n-1}{\mathcal}{X}$.)


\subsubsection{}
\label{sec:detheorize}

Let now ${\mathcal}{X}$ be the unit ${\mathcal}{U}$-monoid (so
${\mathcal}{U}={\Delta}_!{\Theta}_{n-1}{\mathcal}{X}$).
Then the notion of ${\mathcal}{X}$-algebra will be such that the notion of
${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra theorizes it.
In fact, the notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra `detheorizes' more times, and
the most detheorized notion will at the end be equivalent to the
notion of algebra over the unit monoid over~...~over the unit monoid
over ${\mathcal}{U}$, where we should have $n-1$ unit monoids in the
expression.

We can directly define all iteratively detheorized notions as
follows.

\begin{definition}
Let $n\ge 1$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in
groupoids.
Then for an integer $m$ such that $0\le m\le n-1$, a
{\textbf}{${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory} enriched in a multicategory
${\mathcal}{M}$, is a functor
${\mathcal}{U}\to{\Theta}^n_{m+1}{\field{\deloop}}^m{\mathcal}{M}$ with strata of
colours for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory.
\end{definition}

To be explicit, in the case $m=0$, there is no colours added.
In the case $m\ge 1$, given a system of colours for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$m$-theory ${\mathcal}{X}$, the structure on it, of a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$m$-theory, is a functor
${\mathcal}{T}\to{\Theta}^n_{m+1}{\field{\deloop}}^m{\mathcal}{M}$,
where ${\mathcal}{T}$ is the symmetric $n$-theory described as follows.
\begin{itemize}
\item[($0$)] ${\operatorname{Ob}}{\mathcal}{T}$ is the collection whose member is a pair
  $(u,x)$, where $u\in{\operatorname{Ob}}{\mathcal}{U}$ and $x\in{\operatorname{Ob}}_u{\mathcal}{X}$.
\end{itemize}
By induction, for $k$ such that $1\le k\le m$, the type of a
$k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{T}$ of a given arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$, is
specified by
\begin{itemize}
\item the type $u$ of a $k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{U}$ of arity
  $(I;\pi,\phi)$,
\item the type $x$ of a $k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{X}$ of the same arity of
  degree $u$.
\end{itemize}
\begin{itemize}
\item[($k$)](Inductively for $k$ such that $1\le k\le m-1$.)
  Suppose given the arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$ of a $k$-multimap, and the
  type $(u,x)$ of a $k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{T}$ of arity
  $(I;\pi,\phi)$.
  Then ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{T}[(u,x)]$ is the collection whose member is a
  pair $(v,y)$, where $v\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$ and
  $y\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{X},v}[x]$.
\item[($m$)] Suppose given a datum similar to an input datum for
  ``($k$)'' above, but with $k$ substituted by $m$.
  Then ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{T}[(u,x)]={\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$.
\item[($\ell$)](Inductively for $\ell$ such that $m+1\le\ell\le n$.)
  Suppose given the arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$ of a $\ell$-multimap, and the
  type of an $\ell$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{T}$ of arity $(I;\pi,\phi)$,
  which by induction, will be specified by
  \begin{itemize}
  \item the type $u$ of a $\ell$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{U}$ of arity
    $(I;\pi,\phi)$,
  \item the type $x$ of a $\phi^{m-1}$-nerve of $m$-multimaps in
    ${\mathcal}{X}$ of degree $u^{\le m-1}$.
  \end{itemize}
  Then ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{T}[(u,x)]={\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{\mathcal}{U}[u]$.
\end{itemize}
The composition is given by the composition in ${\mathcal}{U}$.

Thus, the notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($n-1$)-theory coincides with the
notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra, and for all $m\ge 0$ (which may be $\ge
n$), the notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory is iteratively an
$m$-th theorization of the notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $0$-theory.

\begin{lemma}
A ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory is equivalent as a datum to a
${\Theta}_n{\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory.
\end{lemma}

The proof of this is direct from Corollary
\ref{cor:forget-to-theorization}.

\begin{definition}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in
groupoids.
Then we refer to a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $1$-theory also as a
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded {\textbf}{multicategory}.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}
Let $n\ge 1$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in
groupoids.
Let $m\ge 0$ and $\ell\ge 1$ be integers.
Then, for an $\ell$-categorified ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory
${\mathcal}{X}$, we denote by ${\Theta}_m{\mathcal}{X}$, the
($\ell-1$)-categorified ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($m+1$)-theory
\emph{represented} by ${\mathcal}{X}$, namely, obtained by
replacing the structure functors of ${\mathcal}{X}$ by the
bimodules/distributors/profunctors corepresented by them.
\end{definition}

If ${\mathcal}{X}$ is enriched in $\ell$-categories, then it can be regarded
as $k$-categorified for any $k\ge\ell$.
However, resulting ${\Theta}_m{\mathcal}{X}$ is independent of $k$.
In particular, ${\Theta}_m{\mathcal}{X}$ is also defined for an
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory ${\mathcal}{X}$ enriched in groupoids, and it is
an uncategorified ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($m+1$)-theory, which can be
considered as as highly categorified (trivially) as one wishes to.

\begin{definition}
Let $n\ge 1$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in
groupoids.
Let $m\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{X}$ be a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$m$-theory which is possibly higher categorified.
Then, for an integer $\ell\ge 0$, we define a (less or un-
categorified) ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($m+\ell$)-theory
${\Theta}^{m+\ell}_m{\mathcal}{X}$ by the inductive relations

nexttext:
\end{itemize}
The composition is given by the composition in ${\mathcal}{Y}$.

It is immediate to verify that we have an equivalence
${\vphantom{{{\Theta}}}{^{\mathcal}{U}}\!{{{\Theta}}}}^n_m(P_!{\mathcal}{Y}){\simeq}
P_!{\vphantom{{{\Theta}}}{^{\mathcal}{V}}\!{{{\Theta}}}}^n_m{\mathcal}{Y}$.

In the case $m\ge n+1$, the description above applies after ${\mathcal}{U}$
is replaced by ${\Theta}^m_n{\mathcal}{U}$.

In general, between suitable categories, the construction $P_!$
gives a left adjoint to the functor $P^*$.

\begin{remark}
A construction $P_*$, which suitably gives a \emph{right} adjoint of
$P^*$, will be considered later in Section
\ref{sec:right-adjoint-of-restriction}.
This construction is not as obvious, and will in general, only produce
an ($m+1$)-theory from an $m$-theory.
\end{remark}

\begin{example}\label{ex:push-terminal-forward}
$P_!{\boldsymbol{1}}^m_{\mathcal}{V}={\mathcal}{V}$ for the terminal unenriched uncoloured
${\mathcal}{V}$-graded $m$-theory ${\boldsymbol{1}}^m_{\mathcal}{V}$.
\end{example}

\begin{example}
In the case where ${\mathcal}{V}$ is the terminal uncoloured
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory enriched in groupoids, $P$ is an
equivalence, and $P^*$ and
$P_!$ are the mutually inverse equivalences giving the identification
of Example \ref{ex:terminally-graded}.
\end{example}

\begin{example}\label{ex:left-push-kan-extension}
Consider the case where ${\mathcal}{U}$ is an initially graded $1$-theory
enriched in groupoids, and $m=0$.
In this case, a ${\mathcal}{U}$-monoid ${\mathcal}{V}$ is a groupoid-valued
functor on ${\mathcal}{U}$, and the projection
$P\colon({\Delta}_{\mathcal}{U})_!{\Theta}_0{\mathcal}{V}\to{\mathcal}{U}$ is the
corresponding op-fibration (fibred in groupoids).
For a ${\mathcal}{V}$-graded $0$-theory ${\mathcal}{X}$, the op-fibration
prevtext:
\end{definition}


\subsubsection{}

The following definition essentially achieves (more than) our initial
goal of the discussions here.

\begin{definition}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in
groupoids.
Let $m\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{X}$ be a
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory enriched in groupoids.
Then for an integer $\ell\ge 0$, an {\textbf}{${\mathcal}{X}$-graded}
$\ell$-theory is a ${\Delta}_!{\Theta}^N_m{\mathcal}{X}$-graded
$\ell$-theory, where $N:=\max\{m,n\}$, and
${\Delta}\colon{\Theta}^N_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^N_{\mathrm}{Com}$.
\end{definition}

\begin{example}\label{ex:terminally-graded}
Let ${\mathcal}{X}$ be the terminal uncoloured ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory
enriched in groupoids.
Then we have ${\Delta}_!{\Theta}^N_m{\mathcal}{X}={\Theta}^N_n{\mathcal}{U}$,
so an ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded
$\ell$-theory is equivalent as a datum to a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$\ell$-theory, as had been predicted.
\end{example}


\subsubsection{}

In order to analyse the notions further, we shall next consider how
gradings can be altered.

Given a functor $F\colon{\mathcal}{V}\to{\mathcal}{U}$ of $n$-theories enriched in
groupoids, it
is clear that a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory ${\mathcal}{X}$ gets pulled back
by $F$.
Let us denote the resulting ${\mathcal}{V}$-graded $m$-theory by
$F^*{\mathcal}{X}$.
In the case where $m=n$, and ${\mathcal}{X}$ is unenriched, the projection
$({\Delta}_{\mathcal}{V})_!F^*{\mathcal}{X}\to{\mathcal}{V}$ (where
${\Delta}_{\mathcal}{V}\colon{\mathcal}{V}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$) is the base
change of the projection $({\Delta}_{\mathcal}{U})_!{\mathcal}{X}\to{\mathcal}{U}$ by $F$
in a suitable sense.
In the case where $m\le n-1$, one has
${\vphantom{{{\Theta}}}{^{\mathcal}{V}}\!{{{\Theta}}}}^n_m(F^*{\mathcal}{X})=F^*({\vphantom{{{\Theta}}}{^{\mathcal}{U}}\!{{{\Theta}}}}^n_m{\mathcal}{X})$,
where the superscripts to ${\Theta}^n_m$ indicate the gradings
considered.
If $m\ge n+1$, then $F^*$ is the pull-back by
${\Theta}^m_nF\colon{\Theta}^m_n{\mathcal}{V}\to{\Theta}^m_n{\mathcal}{U}$.

\begin{example}
For an $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{V}$ enriched in groupoids, and an uncoloured
${\mathcal}{V}$-monoid ${\mathcal}{X}$ defined by a functor
$F\colon{\mathcal}{V}\to{\field{\deloop}}^{n-1}{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$,
we have an equivalence
${\Theta}_{n-1}{\mathcal}{X}=F^*({\Theta}_{n-1}{\mathbb{U}}^{n-1})$ of
(simply coloured) ${\mathcal}{V}$-graded $n$-theories, where
${\Theta}_{n-1}{\mathbb{U}}^{n-1}$ has been described in Proposition
\ref{prop:universal-theorization}.
\end{example}

Let again ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in groupoids.
For an integer $m\ge 0$, suppose that ${\mathcal}{V}$ is a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$m$-theory enriched in groupoids, and denote by $P$, the projection
${\Delta}_!{\Theta}^N_m{\mathcal}{V}\to{\Theta}^N_n{\mathcal}{U}$, where $N\ge
m,n$, and ${\Delta}\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$.
Then also clearly, one obtains from an unenriched (possibly higher
categorified) ${\mathcal}{V}$-graded $m$-theory
${\mathcal}{Y}$, its push forward $P_!{\mathcal}{Y}$ as a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$m$-theory, generalizing the construction ${\Delta}_!$.

In the case $m=n$, $P_!{\mathcal}{Y}$ has the same underlying symmetric
$n$-theory as that of ${\mathcal}{Y}$, with projection to ${\mathcal}{U}$ given by
the projection to ${\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{V}$ composed with
$P\colon{\Delta}_!{\mathcal}{V}\to{\mathcal}{U}$.

In the case $m\le n-1$, the description of $P_!{\mathcal}{Y}$ is as
follows.
\begin{itemize}
\item[($0$)] For an object $u\in{\operatorname{Ob}}{\mathcal}{U}$, ${\operatorname{Ob}}_uP_!{\mathcal}{Y}$ is the
  collection whose member is a pair $(v,y)$, where $v\in{\operatorname{Ob}}_u{\mathcal}{V}$
  and $y\in{\operatorname{Ob}}_v{\mathcal}{Y}$.
\end{itemize}
Let $k$ be an integer such that $1\le k\le m$, and suppose given the
type $u$ of a $k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{U}$ whose arity is given as
$(I;\pi,\phi)$.
Then by induction, the type of a $k$-multimap in $P_!{\mathcal}{X}$ of the
same arity of degree $u$, is specified by
\begin{itemize}
\item the type $v$ of a $k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{V}$ of the same arity of
  degree $u$,
\item the type $y$ of a $k$-multimap in ${\mathcal}{Y}$ of the same arity of
  degree $v$.
\end{itemize}
\begin{itemize}
\item[($k$)](Inductively for $1\le k\le m-1$.)
  Suppose given
  \begin{itemize}
  \item a $k$-multimap $u^k$ in ${\mathcal}{U}$ whose arity and type
    are given respectively as $(I;\pi,\phi)$ and $u^{\le
      k-1}=(u^\nu)_{0\le\nu\le k-1}$,
  \item the type $(v,y)$ of a $k$-multimap in $P_!{\mathcal}{X}$ of the same
    arity of degree $u^{\le k-1}$.
  \end{itemize}
  Then ${\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{P_!{\mathcal}{Y},u^k}[(v,y)]$ is the collection whose
  member is a pair $(w,z)$, where $w\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{V},u^k}[v]$ and
  $z\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^\pi_{{\mathcal}{Y},w}[y]$.
\item[($m$)] Suppose given a datum similar to an input datum for
  ``($k$)'' above, but with $k$ substituted by $m$.
  Then

colim}}_{w\in{\operatorname{Mul}}^{\pi}_{{\mathcal{}}{V},u^{m}}[v]}{%
\operatorname{Mul}}^{\pi}_{{\mathcal{}}{Y},w}[y]." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>Mul</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>P</mi><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">!</mo></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>Y</mi></mrow><mo>,</mo><msup><mi>u</mi><mi>m</mi></msup></mrow><mi>π</mi></msubsup><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>v</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mo>colim</mo><mrow><mi>w</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo>Mul</mo><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>,</mo><msup><mi>u</mi><mi>m</mi></msup></mrow><mi>π</mi></msubsup><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>v</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></msub><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo>Mul</mo><mrow><mi>Y</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>w</mi></mrow><mi>π</mi></msubsup><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

describing the ${\mathcal}{U}$-monoid $P_!{\mathcal}{X}$ is the composite of the
op-fibrations $({\Delta}_{\mathcal}{V})_!{\Theta}_0X\to{\Theta}_0{\mathcal}{V}$
and $P$, agreeing with the alternative description of the
${\mathcal}{U}$-module $P_!{\mathcal}{X}$ as the left Kan extension along $P$ of
the $({\Delta}_{\mathcal}{U})_!{\Theta}_0{\mathcal}{V}$-module $X$.
\end{example}

The version of this connection for ${\mathcal}{U}={\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$, has been
concretely expressed in Proposition
\ref{prop:universal-theorization}.

Proposition \ref{prop:graded-is-overlying} generalizes as follows.

\begin{proposition}\label{prop:graded-projection}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in
groupoids, $m\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{V}$ be a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$m$-theory enriched in groupoids.
Then an unenriched ${\mathcal}{V}$-graded $m$-theory is equivalent as a
datum to an unenriched
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory ${\mathcal}{X}$ equipped with a ``projection''
functor ${\mathcal}{X}\to{\mathcal}{V}$.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
We may assume $m\le n$ without loss of generality, and the case $m=n$
may not be tautologous, but is obviously true.

For the case $m\le n-1$, denote by $P$, the projection
${({\Delta}_{\mathcal}{U})}_!{\Theta}^n_m{\mathcal}{V}\to{\mathcal}{U}$, where
${\Delta}_{\mathcal}{U}\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$.
Then, from an unenriched ${\mathcal}{V}$-graded $m$-theory ${\mathcal}{Y}$, we
obtain a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory $P_!{\mathcal}{Y}$ equipped with the
functor
prevtext:
\end{itemize}
The composition is given by the composition in ${\mathcal}{Y}$.

It is immediate to verify that we have an equivalence
${\vphantom{{{\Theta}}}{^{\mathcal}{U}}\!{{{\Theta}}}}^n_m(P_!{\mathcal}{Y}){\simeq}
P_!{\vphantom{{{\Theta}}}{^{\mathcal}{V}}\!{{{\Theta}}}}^n_m{\mathcal}{Y}$.

In the case $m\ge n+1$, the description above applies after ${\mathcal}{U}$
is replaced by ${\Theta}^m_n{\mathcal}{U}$.

In general, between suitable categories, the construction $P_!$
gives a left adjoint to the functor $P^*$.

\begin{remark}
A construction $P_*$, which suitably gives a \emph{right} adjoint of
$P^*$, will be considered later in Section
\ref{sec:right-adjoint-of-restriction}.
This construction is not as obvious, and will in general, only produce
an ($m+1$)-theory from an $m$-theory.
\end{remark}

\begin{example}\label{ex:push-terminal-forward}
$P_!{\boldsymbol{1}}^m_{\mathcal}{V}={\mathcal}{V}$ for the terminal unenriched uncoloured
${\mathcal}{V}$-graded $m$-theory ${\boldsymbol{1}}^m_{\mathcal}{V}$.
\end{example}

\begin{example}
In the case where ${\mathcal}{V}$ is the terminal uncoloured
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory enriched in groupoids, $P$ is an
equivalence, and $P^*$ and
$P_!$ are the mutually inverse equivalences giving the identification
of Example \ref{ex:terminally-graded}.
\end{example}

\begin{example}\label{ex:left-push-kan-extension}
Consider the case where ${\mathcal}{U}$ is an initially graded $1$-theory
enriched in groupoids, and $m=0$.
In this case, a ${\mathcal}{U}$-monoid ${\mathcal}{V}$ is a groupoid-valued
functor on ${\mathcal}{U}$, and the projection
$P\colon({\Delta}_{\mathcal}{U})_!{\Theta}_0{\mathcal}{V}\to{\mathcal}{U}$ is the
corresponding op-fibration (fibred in groupoids).
For a ${\mathcal}{V}$-graded $0$-theory ${\mathcal}{X}$, the op-fibration

The version of this connection for ${\mathcal}{U}={\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$, has been

\ref{prop:universal-theorization}.

Proposition \ref{prop:graded-is-overlying} generalizes as follows.

functor ${\mathcal}{X}\to{\mathcal}{V}$.
\end{proposition}

{\oldsection{{Enrichment of higher theories}}\setcounter{subsection}{-1}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}\setcounter{equation}{-1}}
\label{sec:enrichment}

{\oldsubsection{{Introduction}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}

The subject of this section will be a general notion of enrichment for
graded higher theories.
We shall show how some previous notions such as grading by a graded
higher theory, can be compactly understood using the new notions
introduced in this section.
We shall also show how the new framework helps with considering
push-forward construction `on the right side', along some functors of
higher theories.
We shall also discuss a construction for higher theories which is
related to the Day convolution for symmetric monoidal categories, and
leads to a notion of algebra over an enriched higher theory.



{\oldsubsection{{Enriched theories}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}
\label{sec:enriched-theory}
\subsubsection{}

Given a kind of algebraic structure, one motivation for theorizing it
was to generalize it to similar structure definable in a theorized
form of the same kind of algebraic structure.
Specifically, we would like to define the kind in question of
algebraic structure in a theorized structure ${\mathcal}{V}$, as a
(coloured) morphism to ${\mathcal}{V}$
from the terminal unenriched theorized structure.

For example, for an $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{U}$ enriched in groupoids, we
would like to define the notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra in a
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory, since ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory is the
kind of structure which theorize the structure of a ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra.
More generally, the following definition seems reasonable, which can
be considered as giving a quite general manner of \emph{enrichment},
of the notion of graded higher theory.

\begin{definition}\label{def:enrich}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in
groupoids.
Let $m\ge 0$ and $M\ge m+1$ be integers, and ${\mathcal}{V}$ be a
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $M$-theory.
Then an {\textbf}{$m$-theory in ${\mathcal}{V}$} is a functor
${\boldsymbol{1}}^M_{\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$ of ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $M$-theories with
strata of colours for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory.
Namely, it consists of
\begin{itemize}
\item a system of colours up to dimension $m-1$ for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
  higher theory,
\item a functor ${\Theta}^M_{m+1}{\mathcal}{T}\to{\mathcal}{V}$, where
  ${\mathcal}{T}$ denotes the terminal unenriched ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
  ($m+1$)-theory on the chosen system of colours.
\end{itemize}

The system of colours will be called the system of colours {\textbf}{of}
the $m$-theory defined.

In the case $m=n-1$, $m$-theory will also be called an
{\textbf}{algebra}.
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}\label{rem:terminology-redundancy-enriched-algebra}
In order to avoid redundancy, we call the defined kind of object
simply an ``$m$-theory'' (or ``algebra'') instead of a
``${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory'' (or ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra) when it is
understood that a ${\mathcal}{U}$-grading is contained is the datum
${\mathcal}{V}$.
We may explicitly refer to the $m$-theory as a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$m$-theory when ($M\ge n$ and) ${\mathcal}{V}$ is a priori, just a symmetric
$M$-theory, and different higher theories may be being considered
over which we would like to grade ${\mathcal}{V}$, perhaps including the
commutative operad ${\mathrm}{Com}$.
This would clarify that a ${\mathcal}{U}$-grading is considered for
${\mathcal}{V}$.
Note however, that this would be still ambiguous if more than one
${\mathcal}{U}$-gradings are being considered for ${\mathcal}{V}$.
\end{remark}

Similarly to the definitions in Section \ref{sec:stratum-for-colour},
there are also less coloured versions of the notion of enriched graded
theory.
These are the cases where the ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded theory ${\mathcal}{T}$ which
were considered in Definition \ref{def:enrich}, are less coloured.

There is also a lax generalization.

\begin{definition}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in
groupoids.
Let $m\ge 0$ and $M\ge m+1$ be integers, and let ${\mathcal}{V}$ be a
possibly higher categorified ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $M$-theory.
Then for an integer $\ell\ge 0$, an {\textbf}{$\ell$-lax} $m$-theory
in ${\mathcal}{V}$ is an $m$-theory in ${\Theta}^{M+\ell}_M{\mathcal}{V}$.
\end{definition}

${\mathcal}{V}$ needs to be at least $\ell$-categorified in order for this
to be properly more general than the ($\ell-1$)-lax notion.

If ${\mathcal}{V}$ is represented by a once more categorified
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($M-1$)-theory ${\mathcal}{W}$, then an
$\ell$-lax $m$-theory in ${\mathcal}{V}={\Theta}_{M-1}{\mathcal}{W}$, is also
an ``$m$-tuply coloured'' ($\ell+1$)-lax ($m-1$)-theory in ${\mathcal}{W}$.


\subsubsection{}

As we have discussed in Section \ref{sec:introduction}, we obtain the
following in a low ``theoretic'' level of algebra.
For a functorial formulation of the following, see Proposition
\ref{prop:enriching-multicategory}.

\begin{proposition}
For every coloured symmetric operad ${\mathcal}{U}$ in groupoids, the notion
of coloured
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded operad in a symmetric monoidal category has a
generalization in a (${\mathcal}{U}{\otimes} E_1$)-monoidal category.
Namely, there is a notion of coloured ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded operad in a
(${\mathcal}{U}{\otimes} E_1$)-monoidal category, such that the notion of
coloured ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded operad in a symmetric monoidal category
coincides with the notion of coloured ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded operad in its
underlying (${\mathcal}{U}{\otimes} E_1$)-monoidal category.
\end{proposition}

Indeed, for a (${\mathcal}{U}{\otimes} E_1$)-monoidal category ${\mathcal}{A}$, it
sufficed to define a coloured ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded operad in ${\mathcal}{A}$ as
a $1$-theory in the ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $2$-theory
${\Theta}^2_0{B}{\mathcal}{A}$, where ${B}{\mathcal}{A}$ denotes the
${\mathcal}{U}$-monoidal $2$-category obtained by categorically delooping
${\mathcal}{A}$ using the $E_1$-monoidal structure (or a suitably
``trapped'' (See Section \ref{sec:functor}) functor
${\boldsymbol{1}}^2_{\mathcal}{U}\to{\Theta}^2_0{B}{\mathcal}{A}$, to be more
precise).

In the case where ${\mathcal}{U}={\mathrm}{Init}, E_1, E_2$, this coincides with the
familiar notion.
See Example \ref{ex:graded-multicategory}.

\begin{remark}
It seems natural that the notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded multicategory can
further be generalized to be enriched in a (${\mathcal}{U}{\otimes}
E_1$)-graded multicategory.
We hope to come back to this in a sequel to this work.
\end{remark}


\subsubsection{}

We can more generally consider the similarly general enrichement of
the notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded higher theory in the
case where ${\mathcal}{U}$ is graded by an $N$-theory, where $N\ge n+1$.
In this case, a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded higher theory in the previous sense
was simply a ${\Delta}_!{\Theta}^N_n{\mathcal}{U}$-graded higher theory.

The notion is therefore a special case of the notion defined in
Definition \ref{def:enrich}.
To be explicit, we have the following.
(There will be changes in the notation.)

Let
\begin{itemize}
\item $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched
  in groupoids,
\item $m\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{X}$ be a
  ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory enriched in groupoids,
\item $\ell\ge 0$ and $L\ge\ell+1$ be integers, and ${\mathcal}{Y}$ be an
  ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $L$-theory.
\end{itemize}
Then ${\mathcal}{Y}$ is a ${\Delta}_!{\Theta}^N_m{\mathcal}{X}$-graded $L$-theory,
where $N:=\max\{m,n\}$, and ${\Delta}\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$, so
an $\ell$-theory \emph{in ${\mathcal}{Y}$}
makes sense according to Definition \ref{def:enrich}.

\begin{definition}\label{def:algebra-in-graded-theory}
Let
\begin{itemize}
\item $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched
  in groupoids,
\item $m\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{X}$ be a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
  $m$-theory enriched in groupoids,
\item $\ell\ge 0$ and $L\ge\ell+1$ be integers, and ${\mathcal}{V}$ be a
  ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $L$-theory.
\end{itemize}
Then an {\textbf}{${\mathcal}{X}$-graded} $\ell$-theory in ${\mathcal}{V}$ is an
$\ell$-theory in the ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $L$-theory $P^*{\mathcal}{V}$, where
$P$ denotes the projection
${\Delta}_!{\Theta}^N_m{\mathcal}{X}\to{\Theta}^N_n{\mathcal}{U}$, where
$N:=\max\{m,n\}$, and
${\Delta}\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$.

In the case $\ell=m-1$, an ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theory will also be
called an {\textbf}{${\mathcal}{X}$-algebra}.
\end{definition}

Thus, a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory in ${\mathcal}{V}$ is an uncoloured
${\mathcal}{T}$-algebra in ${\mathcal}{V}$ for an unenriched ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
($m+1$)-theory
${\mathcal}{T}$ which is terminal on a system of colours up to
dimension $m-1$.

\begin{remark}
For the notion of Definition \ref{def:algebra-in-graded-theory}, we
are refraining from saying ``\emph{${\mathcal}{U}$-graded}
${\mathcal}{X}$-graded'' theory when we do not intend to emphasize
the ${\mathcal}{U}$-grading, and this is part of our convention on the
terminology.
See Remark \ref{rem:terminology-redundancy-enriched-algebra}.
\end{remark}

\begin{example}\label{ex:enrichment-in-groupoid}
For ${\mathcal}{U}$ and ${\mathcal}{X}$ as in Definition
\ref{def:algebra-in-graded-theory}, a ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theory
enriched in a multicategory ${\mathcal}{M}$, is equivalent as a datum to an
${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theory in the ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
($\ell+1$)-theory ${\Delta}^*{\field{\deloop}}^\ell{\mathcal}{M}$, where
${\Delta}\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$.
\end{example}

\begin{example}
In Definition \ref{def:algebra-in-graded-theory}, if ${\mathcal}{X}$ is the
terminal uncoloured ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory enriched in groupoids,
then $P$ is an
equivalence, and an ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theory in ${\mathcal}{V}$ is
equivalent as a datum to an $\ell$-theory in ${\mathcal}{V}$.
\end{example}



{\oldsubsection{{Graded theories as lifts of an algebra}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}
\label{sec:graded-theory-as-lift}

\subsubsection{}

Using Definition \ref{def:algebra-in-graded-theory}, an
${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theory in ${\mathcal}{V}$ in the notation there, can
be written as an appropriate coloured functor of ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
higher theories.
On the other hand, ${\mathcal}{X}$ itself may be defined by a coloured
functor
$F\colon{\boldsymbol{1}}^{m+1}_{\mathcal}{U}\to{\Delta}^*{\field{\deloop}}^m{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$ of
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded theories.
In this situation, one might wish to describe a higher theory graded
by ${\mathcal}{X}$, directly in terms of $F$.
We shall show that it can indeed be described as a coloured lift of
$F$.

Note that we may assume $m=L$($\ge \ell+1$) without loss of
generality.
We shall first discuss a result in this situation (\emph{Proposition
\ref{prop:graded-low-theory-as-lift}}).

For application in Section \ref{sec:right-adjoint-of-restriction}, we
shall also give an analogous result \emph{Proposition
\ref{prop:graded-theory-as-lift}} for the case ``$\ell=m$''.


\subsubsection{}

Let us first recall common notation.

If ${\mathcal}{C}$ is a category and $x$ is an object of ${\mathcal}{C}$,
then we denote by ${\mathcal}{C}_{/x}$, the category of objects of
${\mathcal}{C}$ lying over $x$, i.e., equipped with a map to $x$.
More generally, if a category ${\mathcal}{D}$ is equipped with a functor to
${\mathcal}{C}$, then we define
${\mathcal}{D}_{/x}:={\mathcal}{D}\times_{{\mathcal}{C}}{\mathcal}{C}_{/x}$.
Note here that ${\mathcal}{C}_{/x}$ is mapping to ${\mathcal}{C}$ by the functor
which forgets the structure map to $x$.
Note that the notation is abusive in that the name of the functor
${\mathcal}{D}\to{\mathcal}{C}$ is dropped from it.
In order to avoid this abuse from causing any confusion, we shall use
this notation only when the considered functor ${\mathcal}{D}\to{\mathcal}{C}$ is
clear from the context.


\subsubsection{}

To get on the task now, let us denote by ${\ccat{CAT}}$ the very large
category of large categories.
Consider this as symmetric monoidal by the Cartesian structure, and
give the functor category ${\mathrm}{Fun}({\mathrm}{Gpd}^{\mathrm{op}},{\ccat{CAT}})$ the structure of a
multicategory by the Day convolution.
Namely, we consider the structure of a multicategory underlying (or
``represented'' by) the symmetric monoidal structure given by the Day
convolution.
Then the Grothendieck construction defines a functor
$G\colon{\mathrm}{Fun}({\mathrm}{Gpd}^{\mathrm{op}},{\ccat{CAT}})\to{\Theta}_0({\ccat{CAT}}_{/{\mathrm}{Gpd}})$ of
multicategories, where ${\ccat{CAT}}_{/{\mathrm}{Gpd}}$ is made symmetric monoidal by
the structure
induced from the (Cartesian) symmetric monoidal structure of ${\mathrm}{Gpd}$.

Furthermore, considering ${\mathrm}{Gpd}$ as a symmetric monoidal (full)
subcategory of ${\ccat{CAT}}$, we obtain the composite

by the Day convolution.
We denote this functor by
${T}\colon{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}\to{\Theta}_0({\ccat{CAT}}_{/{\mathrm}{Gpd}})$,
$X\mapsto{T}_X$, so ${T}_X$ is defined by the forgetful functor
${A} X:={\mathrm}{Gpd}_{/X}\to{\mathrm}{Gpd}$.

Now let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory.
Then for an integer $m\ge 0$, we obtain from a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$m$-theory ${\mathcal}{V}$ enriched in ${\mathrm}{Gpd}$, a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory
${T}_*{\mathcal}{V}$ enriched in ${\ccat{CAT}}_{/{\mathrm}{Gpd}}$, by postcomposition with
${\field{\deloop}}^m{T}\colon{\field{\deloop}}^m{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}\to{\field{\deloop}}^m{\Theta}_0({\ccat{CAT}}_{/{\mathrm}{Gpd}})$.

${T}_*{\mathcal}{V}$ can be considered as a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory
${A}_*{\mathcal}{V}$ enriched in ${\ccat{CAT}}$, equipped with a functor
${A}_*{\mathcal}{V}\to{\Delta}^*{\field{\deloop}}^m{\mathrm}{Gpd}$, where
${\Delta}\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$.
In particular, we obtain a functor
${\Theta}_m{A}_*{\mathcal}{V}\to{\Delta}^*{\field{\deloop}}^m{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$ by
Lemma \ref{lem:deloop-forget-commutation}.

\begin{proposition}\label{prop:graded-low-theory-as-lift}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in
groupoids.
Let $m\ge 1$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{T}$ be a
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($m+1$)-theory enriched in groupoids.
Suppose that an uncoloured ${\mathcal}{T}$-monoid ${\mathcal}{X}$ is defined by a
functor
$F\colon{\mathcal}{T}\to{\Delta}^*{\field{\deloop}}^m{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$,
where ${\Delta}\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$, of ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
($m+1$)-theories (e.g., these data may be specifying a
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory).

Then, for an integer $\ell$ such that $0\le\ell\le m-1$, an
${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theory in a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory
${\mathcal}{V}$ enriched in groupoids, is equivalent as a datum to a lift
with strata of colours up to dimension $\ell-1$, of $F$ to
${\Theta}_m{A}_*{\mathcal}{V}$.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
Since ${\mathcal}{X}$ is uncoloured, a system of colours for an
${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theory (up to dimension $\ell-1$) is
equivalent as a datum to a system of colours for an ${\mathcal}{T}$-graded
$\ell$-theory.
If ${\mathcal}{J}$ is the terminal unenriched ${\mathcal}{T}$-graded
($\ell+1$)-theory on a
system of colours up to dimension $\ell-1$, then, from the
definitions, a correspondence is immediate between the structures on
this system of colours, of ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theories in
${\mathcal}{V}$, and lifts of $F$ to functors
$P_!{\Theta}^{m+1}_{\ell+1}{\mathcal}{J}\to{\Theta}_m{A}_*{\mathcal}{V}$,
where $P$ denotes the projection
${\Delta}_!{\Theta}^N_{m+1}{\mathcal}{T}\to{\Theta}^N_n{\mathcal}{U}$,
$N\ge m+1,n$.
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary}\label{cor:ab-ba}
Let $F$, ${\mathcal}{X}$ be as in Proposition.
Then, for an integer $\ell$ such that $0\le\ell\le m-1$,
an ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theory enriched
in a symmetric multicategory ${\mathcal}{M}$ is equivalent as a datum to a
lift with strata of colours up to dimension $\ell-1$, of $F$ to
${\Delta}^*{\field{\deloop}}^\ell{\Theta}_{m-\ell}{A}_*{\Theta}^{m-\ell}_1{\mathcal}{M}$.
\end{corollary}

\begin{proof}
An ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theory enriched in a symmetric
multicategory ${\mathcal}{M}$, is an ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theory in
${\Delta}^*{\mathcal}{W}$, where ${\mathcal}{W}$ denotes the symmetric
($\ell+1$)-theory ${\field{\deloop}}^\ell{\mathcal}{M}$.
Proposition identifies this with a coloured lift of $F$ to
${\Delta}^*{\Theta}_m{A}_*{\Theta}^m_{\ell+1}{\mathcal}{W}$.
Moreover, there is an equivalence
prevtext:
from which the result follows.
\end{proof}



{\oldsection{{Enrichment of higher theories}}\setcounter{subsection}{-1}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}\setcounter{equation}{-1}}
\label{sec:enrichment}

{\oldsubsection{{Introduction}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}

The subject of this section will be a general notion of enrichment for
graded higher theories.
We shall show how some previous notions such as grading by a graded
higher theory, can be compactly understood using the new notions
introduced in this section.
We shall also show how the new framework helps with considering
push-forward construction `on the right side', along some functors of
higher theories.
We shall also discuss a construction for higher theories which is
related to the Day convolution for symmetric monoidal categories, and
leads to a notion of algebra over an enriched higher theory.



{\oldsubsection{{Enriched theories}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}
\label{sec:enriched-theory}
\subsubsection{}

Given a kind of algebraic structure, one motivation for theorizing it
was to generalize it to similar structure definable in a theorized
form of the same kind of algebraic structure.
Specifically, we would like to define the kind in question of
algebraic structure in a theorized structure ${\mathcal}{V}$, as a
(coloured) morphism to ${\mathcal}{V}$
from the terminal unenriched theorized structure.

For example, for an $n$-theory ${\mathcal}{U}$ enriched in groupoids, we
would like to define the notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra in a
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory, since ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $n$-theory is the
kind of structure which theorize the structure of a ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra.
More generally, the following definition seems reasonable, which can
be considered as giving a quite general manner of \emph{enrichment},
of the notion of graded higher theory.

\begin{definition}\label{def:enrich}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in
groupoids.
Let $m\ge 0$ and $M\ge m+1$ be integers, and ${\mathcal}{V}$ be a
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $M$-theory.
Then an {\textbf}{$m$-theory in ${\mathcal}{V}$} is a functor
${\boldsymbol{1}}^M_{\mathcal}{U}\to{\mathcal}{V}$ of ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $M$-theories with
strata of colours for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory.
Namely, it consists of
\begin{itemize}
\item a system of colours up to dimension $m-1$ for a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
  higher theory,
\item a functor ${\Theta}^M_{m+1}{\mathcal}{T}\to{\mathcal}{V}$, where
  ${\mathcal}{T}$ denotes the terminal unenriched ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
  ($m+1$)-theory on the chosen system of colours.
\end{itemize}

The system of colours will be called the system of colours {\textbf}{of}
the $m$-theory defined.

In the case $m=n-1$, $m$-theory will also be called an
{\textbf}{algebra}.
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}\label{rem:terminology-redundancy-enriched-algebra}
In order to avoid redundancy, we call the defined kind of object
simply an ``$m$-theory'' (or ``algebra'') instead of a
``${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory'' (or ${\mathcal}{U}$-algebra) when it is
understood that a ${\mathcal}{U}$-grading is contained is the datum
${\mathcal}{V}$.
We may explicitly refer to the $m$-theory as a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$m$-theory when ($M\ge n$ and) ${\mathcal}{V}$ is a priori, just a symmetric
$M$-theory, and different higher theories may be being considered
over which we would like to grade ${\mathcal}{V}$, perhaps including the
commutative operad ${\mathrm}{Com}$.
This would clarify that a ${\mathcal}{U}$-grading is considered for
${\mathcal}{V}$.
Note however, that this would be still ambiguous if more than one
${\mathcal}{U}$-gradings are being considered for ${\mathcal}{V}$.
\end{remark}

Similarly to the definitions in Section \ref{sec:stratum-for-colour},
there are also less coloured versions of the notion of enriched graded
theory.
These are the cases where the ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded theory ${\mathcal}{T}$ which
were considered in Definition \ref{def:enrich}, are less coloured.

There is also a lax generalization.

\begin{definition}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in
groupoids.
Let $m\ge 0$ and $M\ge m+1$ be integers, and let ${\mathcal}{V}$ be a
possibly higher categorified ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $M$-theory.
Then for an integer $\ell\ge 0$, an {\textbf}{$\ell$-lax} $m$-theory
in ${\mathcal}{V}$ is an $m$-theory in ${\Theta}^{M+\ell}_M{\mathcal}{V}$.
\end{definition}

${\mathcal}{V}$ needs to be at least $\ell$-categorified in order for this
to be properly more general than the ($\ell-1$)-lax notion.

If ${\mathcal}{V}$ is represented by a once more categorified
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($M-1$)-theory ${\mathcal}{W}$, then an
$\ell$-lax $m$-theory in ${\mathcal}{V}={\Theta}_{M-1}{\mathcal}{W}$, is also
an ``$m$-tuply coloured'' ($\ell+1$)-lax ($m-1$)-theory in ${\mathcal}{W}$.


\subsubsection{}

As we have discussed in Section \ref{sec:introduction}, we obtain the
following in a low ``theoretic'' level of algebra.
For a functorial formulation of the following, see Proposition
\ref{prop:enriching-multicategory}.

\begin{proposition}
For every coloured symmetric operad ${\mathcal}{U}$ in groupoids, the notion
of coloured
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded operad in a symmetric monoidal category has a
generalization in a (${\mathcal}{U}{\otimes} E_1$)-monoidal category.
Namely, there is a notion of coloured ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded operad in a
(${\mathcal}{U}{\otimes} E_1$)-monoidal category, such that the notion of
coloured ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded operad in a symmetric monoidal category
coincides with the notion of coloured ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded operad in its
underlying (${\mathcal}{U}{\otimes} E_1$)-monoidal category.
\end{proposition}

Indeed, for a (${\mathcal}{U}{\otimes} E_1$)-monoidal category ${\mathcal}{A}$, it
sufficed to define a coloured ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded operad in ${\mathcal}{A}$ as
a $1$-theory in the ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $2$-theory
${\Theta}^2_0{B}{\mathcal}{A}$, where ${B}{\mathcal}{A}$ denotes the
${\mathcal}{U}$-monoidal $2$-category obtained by categorically delooping
${\mathcal}{A}$ using the $E_1$-monoidal structure (or a suitably
``trapped'' (See Section \ref{sec:functor}) functor
${\boldsymbol{1}}^2_{\mathcal}{U}\to{\Theta}^2_0{B}{\mathcal}{A}$, to be more
precise).

In the case where ${\mathcal}{U}={\mathrm}{Init}, E_1, E_2$, this coincides with the
familiar notion.
See Example \ref{ex:graded-multicategory}.

\begin{remark}
It seems natural that the notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded multicategory can
further be generalized to be enriched in a (${\mathcal}{U}{\otimes}
E_1$)-graded multicategory.
We hope to come back to this in a sequel to this work.
\end{remark}


\subsubsection{}

We can more generally consider the similarly general enrichement of
the notion of ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded higher theory in the
case where ${\mathcal}{U}$ is graded by an $N$-theory, where $N\ge n+1$.
In this case, a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded higher theory in the previous sense
was simply a ${\Delta}_!{\Theta}^N_n{\mathcal}{U}$-graded higher theory.

The notion is therefore a special case of the notion defined in
Definition \ref{def:enrich}.
To be explicit, we have the following.
(There will be changes in the notation.)

Let
\begin{itemize}
\item $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched
  in groupoids,
\item $m\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{X}$ be a
  ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory enriched in groupoids,
\item $\ell\ge 0$ and $L\ge\ell+1$ be integers, and ${\mathcal}{Y}$ be an
  ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $L$-theory.
\end{itemize}
Then ${\mathcal}{Y}$ is a ${\Delta}_!{\Theta}^N_m{\mathcal}{X}$-graded $L$-theory,
where $N:=\max\{m,n\}$, and ${\Delta}\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$, so
an $\ell$-theory \emph{in ${\mathcal}{Y}$}
makes sense according to Definition \ref{def:enrich}.

\begin{definition}\label{def:algebra-in-graded-theory}
Let
\begin{itemize}
\item $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched
  in groupoids,
\item $m\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{X}$ be a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
  $m$-theory enriched in groupoids,
\item $\ell\ge 0$ and $L\ge\ell+1$ be integers, and ${\mathcal}{V}$ be a
  ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $L$-theory.
\end{itemize}
Then an {\textbf}{${\mathcal}{X}$-graded} $\ell$-theory in ${\mathcal}{V}$ is an
$\ell$-theory in the ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $L$-theory $P^*{\mathcal}{V}$, where
$P$ denotes the projection
${\Delta}_!{\Theta}^N_m{\mathcal}{X}\to{\Theta}^N_n{\mathcal}{U}$, where
$N:=\max\{m,n\}$, and
${\Delta}\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$.

In the case $\ell=m-1$, an ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theory will also be
called an {\textbf}{${\mathcal}{X}$-algebra}.
\end{definition}

Thus, a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory in ${\mathcal}{V}$ is an uncoloured
${\mathcal}{T}$-algebra in ${\mathcal}{V}$ for an unenriched ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
($m+1$)-theory
${\mathcal}{T}$ which is terminal on a system of colours up to
dimension $m-1$.

\begin{remark}
For the notion of Definition \ref{def:algebra-in-graded-theory}, we
are refraining from saying ``\emph{${\mathcal}{U}$-graded}
${\mathcal}{X}$-graded'' theory when we do not intend to emphasize
the ${\mathcal}{U}$-grading, and this is part of our convention on the
terminology.
See Remark \ref{rem:terminology-redundancy-enriched-algebra}.
\end{remark}

\begin{example}\label{ex:enrichment-in-groupoid}
For ${\mathcal}{U}$ and ${\mathcal}{X}$ as in Definition
\ref{def:algebra-in-graded-theory}, a ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theory
enriched in a multicategory ${\mathcal}{M}$, is equivalent as a datum to an
${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theory in the ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
($\ell+1$)-theory ${\Delta}^*{\field{\deloop}}^\ell{\mathcal}{M}$, where
${\Delta}\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$.
\end{example}

\begin{example}
In Definition \ref{def:algebra-in-graded-theory}, if ${\mathcal}{X}$ is the
terminal uncoloured ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory enriched in groupoids,
then $P$ is an
equivalence, and an ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theory in ${\mathcal}{V}$ is
equivalent as a datum to an $\ell$-theory in ${\mathcal}{V}$.
\end{example}



{\oldsubsection{{Graded theories as lifts of an algebra}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}
\label{sec:graded-theory-as-lift}

\subsubsection{}

Using Definition \ref{def:algebra-in-graded-theory}, an
${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theory in ${\mathcal}{V}$ in the notation there, can
be written as an appropriate coloured functor of ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
higher theories.
On the other hand, ${\mathcal}{X}$ itself may be defined by a coloured
functor
$F\colon{\boldsymbol{1}}^{m+1}_{\mathcal}{U}\to{\Delta}^*{\field{\deloop}}^m{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$ of
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded theories.
In this situation, one might wish to describe a higher theory graded
by ${\mathcal}{X}$, directly in terms of $F$.
We shall show that it can indeed be described as a coloured lift of
$F$.

Note that we may assume $m=L$($\ge \ell+1$) without loss of
generality.
We shall first discuss a result in this situation (\emph{Proposition
\ref{prop:graded-low-theory-as-lift}}).

For application in Section \ref{sec:right-adjoint-of-restriction}, we
shall also give an analogous result \emph{Proposition
\ref{prop:graded-theory-as-lift}} for the case ``$\ell=m$''.


\subsubsection{}

Let us first recall common notation.

If ${\mathcal}{C}$ is a category and $x$ is an object of ${\mathcal}{C}$,
then we denote by ${\mathcal}{C}_{/x}$, the category of objects of
${\mathcal}{C}$ lying over $x$, i.e., equipped with a map to $x$.
More generally, if a category ${\mathcal}{D}$ is equipped with a functor to
${\mathcal}{C}$, then we define
${\mathcal}{D}_{/x}:={\mathcal}{D}\times_{{\mathcal}{C}}{\mathcal}{C}_{/x}$.
Note here that ${\mathcal}{C}_{/x}$ is mapping to ${\mathcal}{C}$ by the functor
which forgets the structure map to $x$.
Note that the notation is abusive in that the name of the functor
${\mathcal}{D}\to{\mathcal}{C}$ is dropped from it.
In order to avoid this abuse from causing any confusion, we shall use
this notation only when the considered functor ${\mathcal}{D}\to{\mathcal}{C}$ is
clear from the context.


\subsubsection{}

To get on the task now, let us denote by ${\ccat{CAT}}$ the very large
category of large categories.
Consider this as symmetric monoidal by the Cartesian structure, and
give the functor category ${\mathrm}{Fun}({\mathrm}{Gpd}^{\mathrm{op}},{\ccat{CAT}})$ the structure of a
multicategory by the Day convolution.
Namely, we consider the structure of a multicategory underlying (or
``represented'' by) the symmetric monoidal structure given by the Day
convolution.
Then the Grothendieck construction defines a functor
$G\colon{\mathrm}{Fun}({\mathrm}{Gpd}^{\mathrm{op}},{\ccat{CAT}})\to{\Theta}_0({\ccat{CAT}}_{/{\mathrm}{Gpd}})$ of
multicategories, where ${\ccat{CAT}}_{/{\mathrm}{Gpd}}$ is made symmetric monoidal by
the structure
induced from the (Cartesian) symmetric monoidal structure of ${\mathrm}{Gpd}$.

Furthermore, considering ${\mathrm}{Gpd}$ as a symmetric monoidal (full)
subcategory of ${\ccat{CAT}}$, we obtain the composite

nexttext:
of unenriched ($m+1$)-theories lying over
${\field{\deloop}}^m{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}={\field{\deloop}}^\ell{\field{\deloop}}^{m-\ell}{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$.
\end{proof}


\subsubsection{}

In Section \ref{sec:right-adjoint-of-restriction}, we shall use a
natural analogue of Proposition \ref{prop:graded-low-theory-as-lift}
for $\ell=m$.
The way how we obtain it will be by restricting the context.

Let us denote by ${\closedcat{CAT}}$ the very large \emph{$2$-category} of large
categories extending the $1$-category ${\ccat{CAT}}$.
In order to formulate the result, we first extend ${T}$ to the
composite
prevtext:
where the structures of multicategories on the functor categories are
by the Day convolution.
We denote this functor by
${T}\colon{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}\to{\Theta}_0({\ccat{CAT}}_{/{\mathrm}{Gpd}})$,
$X\mapsto{T}_X$, so ${T}_X$ is defined by the forgetful functor
${A} X:={\mathrm}{Gpd}_{/X}\to{\mathrm}{Gpd}$.

Now let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory.
Then for an integer $m\ge 0$, we obtain from a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
$m$-theory ${\mathcal}{V}$ enriched in ${\mathrm}{Gpd}$, a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory
${T}_*{\mathcal}{V}$ enriched in ${\ccat{CAT}}_{/{\mathrm}{Gpd}}$, by postcomposition with
${\field{\deloop}}^m{T}\colon{\field{\deloop}}^m{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}\to{\field{\deloop}}^m{\Theta}_0({\ccat{CAT}}_{/{\mathrm}{Gpd}})$.

${T}_*{\mathcal}{V}$ can be considered as a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory
${A}_*{\mathcal}{V}$ enriched in ${\ccat{CAT}}$, equipped with a functor
${A}_*{\mathcal}{V}\to{\Delta}^*{\field{\deloop}}^m{\mathrm}{Gpd}$, where
${\Delta}\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$.
In particular, we obtain a functor
${\Theta}_m{A}_*{\mathcal}{V}\to{\Delta}^*{\field{\deloop}}^m{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$ by
Lemma \ref{lem:deloop-forget-commutation}.

\begin{proposition}\label{prop:graded-low-theory-as-lift}
Let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory enriched in
groupoids.
Let $m\ge 1$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{T}$ be a
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($m+1$)-theory enriched in groupoids.
Suppose that an uncoloured ${\mathcal}{T}$-monoid ${\mathcal}{X}$ is defined by a
functor
$F\colon{\mathcal}{T}\to{\Delta}^*{\field{\deloop}}^m{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$,
where ${\Delta}\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$, of ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
($m+1$)-theories (e.g., these data may be specifying a
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory).

Then, for an integer $\ell$ such that $0\le\ell\le m-1$, an
${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theory in a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory
${\mathcal}{V}$ enriched in groupoids, is equivalent as a datum to a lift
with strata of colours up to dimension $\ell-1$, of $F$ to
${\Theta}_m{A}_*{\mathcal}{V}$.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
Since ${\mathcal}{X}$ is uncoloured, a system of colours for an
${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theory (up to dimension $\ell-1$) is
equivalent as a datum to a system of colours for an ${\mathcal}{T}$-graded
$\ell$-theory.
If ${\mathcal}{J}$ is the terminal unenriched ${\mathcal}{T}$-graded
($\ell+1$)-theory on a
system of colours up to dimension $\ell-1$, then, from the
definitions, a correspondence is immediate between the structures on
this system of colours, of ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theories in
${\mathcal}{V}$, and lifts of $F$ to functors
$P_!{\Theta}^{m+1}_{\ell+1}{\mathcal}{J}\to{\Theta}_m{A}_*{\mathcal}{V}$,
where $P$ denotes the projection
${\Delta}_!{\Theta}^N_{m+1}{\mathcal}{T}\to{\Theta}^N_n{\mathcal}{U}$,
$N\ge m+1,n$.
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary}\label{cor:ab-ba}
Let $F$, ${\mathcal}{X}$ be as in Proposition.
Then, for an integer $\ell$ such that $0\le\ell\le m-1$,
an ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theory enriched
in a symmetric multicategory ${\mathcal}{M}$ is equivalent as a datum to a
lift with strata of colours up to dimension $\ell-1$, of $F$ to
${\Delta}^*{\field{\deloop}}^\ell{\Theta}_{m-\ell}{A}_*{\Theta}^{m-\ell}_1{\mathcal}{M}$.
\end{corollary}

\begin{proof}
An ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theory enriched in a symmetric
multicategory ${\mathcal}{M}$, is an ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $\ell$-theory in
${\Delta}^*{\mathcal}{W}$, where ${\mathcal}{W}$ denotes the symmetric
($\ell+1$)-theory ${\field{\deloop}}^\ell{\mathcal}{M}$.
Proposition identifies this with a coloured lift of $F$ to
${\Delta}^*{\Theta}_m{A}_*{\Theta}^m_{\ell+1}{\mathcal}{W}$.
Moreover, there is an equivalence
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex56.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\Theta}_{m}{A}_{*}{\Theta}^{m}_{\ell+1}{\mathcal{}}{W}={\field{\deloop}}^{%
\ell}{\Theta}_{m-\ell}{A}_{*}{\Theta}^{m-\ell}_{1}{\mathcal{}}{M}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Θ</mi><mi>m</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>A</mi><mo>*</mo></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Θ</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">ℓ</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>m</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>W</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\field</mtext></merror><mo>⁢</mo><msup><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\deloop</mtext></merror><mi mathvariant="normal">ℓ</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Θ</mi><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">ℓ</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>A</mi><mo>*</mo></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi mathvariant="normal">Θ</mi><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">ℓ</mi></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>M</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

of functors of categorified multicategories, where ${\mathbf}{Fun}$ indicates
the $2$-categories of functors extended to categorified
multicategories by the Day convolution, and ${\mathrm}{Gpd}$ is considered as a
symmetric monoidal subcategory of ${\closedcat{CAT}}$.
Thus, for ${\mathcal}{C}\in{\closedcat{CAT}}$, the object ${T}_{\mathcal}{C}\in{\closedcat{CAT}}_{/{\mathrm}{Gpd}}$
is defined by the forgetful functor
${A}{\mathcal}{C}:={\mathrm}{Gpd}_{/{\mathcal}{C}}\to{\mathrm}{Gpd}$.

Now let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory.
Then as before, for an integer $m\ge 0$, we obtain from a
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory ${\mathcal}{V}$ enriched in ${\closedcat{CAT}}$,
\begin{itemize}
\item a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory ${A}_*{\mathcal}{V}$ enriched in

\item a functor
${\Theta}_m{A}_*{\mathcal}{V}\to{\Delta}^*{\field{\deloop}}^m{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$,
\end{itemize}
by considering ${T}_*{\mathcal}{V}$.

\begin{proposition}\label{prop:graded-theory-as-lift}
For ${\mathcal}{U}$, $F$, ${\mathcal}{X}$ as in Proposition
\ref{prop:graded-low-theory-as-lift}, an ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $m$-theory
in the ($m+1$)-theory represented by a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory
${\mathcal}{V}$ enriched in ${\closedcat{CAT}}$, is equivalent as a datum to a lift with
strata of colours up to dimension
$m-1$, of $F$ to ${\Theta}_m{A}_*{\mathcal}{V}$.
\end{proposition}

The proof is similar to the proof of Proposition
\ref{prop:graded-low-theory-as-lift}.

\begin{corollary}\label{cor:graded-theory-as-lift}
For $F$, ${\mathcal}{X}$ as in Proposition
\ref{prop:graded-low-theory-as-lift}, an ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $m$-theory
enriched in a symmetric monoidal category ${\mathcal}{A}$, is equivalent as
a datum to a lift with strata of colours up to dimension $m-1$, of $F$
to ${\Delta}^*{\field{\deloop}}^m{\Theta}_0{A}_*{\mathcal}{A}$.
\end{corollary}

\begin{proof}
This is the case ${\mathcal}{V}={\Delta}^*{\field{\deloop}}^m{\mathcal}{A}$ of Proposition
since we have an equivalence
prevtext:
of unenriched ($m+1$)-theories lying over
${\field{\deloop}}^m{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}={\field{\deloop}}^\ell{\field{\deloop}}^{m-\ell}{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$.
\end{proof}

{\oldsubsection{{The right adjoint of the restriction of degrees}}\setcounter{subsubsection}{-1}}
\label{sec:right-adjoint-of-restriction}

\subsubsection{}
\label{sec:right-push-begin}

In Section \ref{sec:iterated-monoid}, we have considered the
left adjoint to the functor `restricting' the degrees for graded
theories.
We would like to consider the \emph{right} adjoint in the following
situation.

Let
\begin{itemize}

\item ${\mathcal}{X}$ be an unenriched ${\mathcal}{V}$-graded $m$-theory.
\end{itemize}

${\Delta}_!{\Theta}^N_m{\mathcal}{V}\to{\Theta}^N_n{\mathcal}{U}$, where $N\ge
m,n$, and ${\Delta}\colon{\mathcal}{U}\to{\boldsymbol{1}}^n_{\mathrm}{Com}$.
Then it turns out that we can construct a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded
\emph{($m+1$)-theory} $P_*{\mathcal}{X}$ having an appropriate universal
property.

We shall do this construction in two steps.
The key observation is that we can reduce the situation above into two
simpler situations according to the factorization of $P$ as
prevtext:
of functors of categorified multicategories, where ${\mathbf}{Fun}$ indicates
the $2$-categories of functors extended to categorified
multicategories by the Day convolution, and ${\mathrm}{Gpd}$ is considered as a
symmetric monoidal subcategory of ${\closedcat{CAT}}$.
Thus, for ${\mathcal}{C}\in{\closedcat{CAT}}$, the object ${T}_{\mathcal}{C}\in{\closedcat{CAT}}_{/{\mathrm}{Gpd}}$
is defined by the forgetful functor
${A}{\mathcal}{C}:={\mathrm}{Gpd}_{/{\mathcal}{C}}\to{\mathrm}{Gpd}$.

Now let $n\ge 0$ be an integer, and ${\mathcal}{U}$ be an $n$-theory.
Then as before, for an integer $m\ge 0$, we obtain from a
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory ${\mathcal}{V}$ enriched in ${\closedcat{CAT}}$,
\begin{itemize}
\item a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory ${A}_*{\mathcal}{V}$ enriched in
  ${\closedcat{CAT}}$,
\item a functor
${\Theta}_m{A}_*{\mathcal}{V}\to{\Delta}^*{\field{\deloop}}^m{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$,
\end{itemize}
by considering ${T}_*{\mathcal}{V}$.

\begin{proposition}\label{prop:graded-theory-as-lift}
For ${\mathcal}{U}$, $F$, ${\mathcal}{X}$ as in Proposition
\ref{prop:graded-low-theory-as-lift}, an ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $m$-theory
in the ($m+1$)-theory represented by a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory
${\mathcal}{V}$ enriched in ${\closedcat{CAT}}$, is equivalent as a datum to a lift with
strata of colours up to dimension
$m-1$, of $F$ to ${\Theta}_m{A}_*{\mathcal}{V}$.
\end{proposition}

The proof is similar to the proof of Proposition
\ref{prop:graded-low-theory-as-lift}.

\begin{corollary}\label{cor:graded-theory-as-lift}
For $F$, ${\mathcal}{X}$ as in Proposition
\ref{prop:graded-low-theory-as-lift}, an ${\mathcal}{X}$-graded $m$-theory
enriched in a symmetric monoidal category ${\mathcal}{A}$, is equivalent as
a datum to a lift with strata of colours up to dimension $m-1$, of $F$
to ${\Delta}^*{\field{\deloop}}^m{\Theta}_0{A}_*{\mathcal}{A}$.
\end{corollary}

\begin{proof}
This is the case ${\mathcal}{V}={\Delta}^*{\field{\deloop}}^m{\mathcal}{A}$ of Proposition
since we have an equivalence

where ${\mathcal}{T}$ denotes the ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory enriched in
groupoids which is
terminal on the system of colours of ${\mathcal}{V}$, so ${\mathcal}{V}$ can be
identified with an uncoloured ${\mathcal}{T}$-graded $m$-theory.

The two cases which we shall treat separately below, will imply
respectively
that we obtain a ${\mathcal}{T}$-graded ($m+1$)-theory $R_*{\mathcal}{X}$, and
that we obtain from this, a ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($m+1$)-theory
$Q_*R_*{\mathcal}{X}$.
Moreover, it will follow that the construction $P_*:=Q_*R_*$ has a
universal property desired of the right push-forward.

\begin{remark}
As we shall see in the construction, $Q_*$ will produce an
($m+1$)-theory in which the groupoids of ($m+1$)-multimaps may not
necessarily be small, even if the groupoids of $m$-multimaps are all
small in ${\mathcal}{X}$.
\end{remark}

Let us see the constructions $Q_*$ and $R_*$.


\subsubsection{}

In order to construct $R_*$ above, it suffices to construct a
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($m+1$)-theory $P_*{\mathcal}{X}$ in the spacial case of
the original situation where ${\mathcal}{V}$ is an \emph{uncoloured}
${\mathcal}{U}$-graded $m$-theory.
This can be done with the following construction at the universal
level.

Recall from Section \ref{sec:iterate-theorize-algebra} and Corollary
\ref{cor:graded-theory-as-lift} that ${\mathcal}{V}$ corresponds to a
functor
$F_{\mathcal}{V}\colon{\Theta}^N_n{\mathcal}{U}\to{\Theta}^N_{m+1}{\field{\deloop}}^m{\Theta}_0{\mathrm}{Gpd}$,

$F_{\mathcal}{X}\colon{\mathcal}{J}\to{F_{\mathcal}{V}}^*{\field{\deloop}}^m{\Theta}_0{A}_*{\mathrm}{Gpd}$
of unenriched ${\mathcal}{U}$-graded ($m+1$)-theories, where ${\mathcal}{J}$ is
terminal on the system of colours of ${\mathcal}{X}$.

Let ${\closedcat{Cocorr}}$ denote the symmetric monoidal $2$-category of groupoids
and cocorrespondences.
Thus, its object is a groupoid, and for groupoids $X,Y$, the category
${\mathrm{Map}}_{\closedcat{Cocorr}}(X,Y)$ is the category formed naturally by the
diagrams of the form
prevtext:
of ($m+1$)-theories enriched in ${\ccat{CAT}}$, lying over ${\field{\deloop}}^m{\mathrm}{Gpd}$.
\end{proof}
